Cloudy Orange/Yellow almost like a dark champagne which is why I made the appearance so low.Taste: Very, very sweet tasting which is good.  I like sweet beers as long as they are balanced properly.  This is balance perfectly.Palate: The flavor is amazing, stings the taste buds with citrus and hops.Overall: Id have it again, especially if the price is right!

Bottle. Pours a cloudy orange color, with a hughe white marshmellowy head. Aroma is really sweet with alot of fruity esters like citrus, peach, orange and apple. I also get some spice like coriander and clove. Flavor is also very sweet and sugary with loads of citrus along with peach and orange. It also has a slight peppery spice with some coriander and clove. The body is medium with a dry mouthfeel. Overall a pretty good Tripel, that is slightly champaign like.

I had this one last night at the Cincinnati Beerfest on Fountain Square downtown ... Alright, this nearly a perfect beer! A deep fruit and grass flavor is a big plus for this abbey triple, and I was astounded by its lasting balance and body!

750 mL bottle from the LCBO, served in a snifter. Pours hazy golden with a fine frothy head. The head has great retention and leaves a good amount of fine lace. On the nose, there are aromas of yeast, citrus, clove and flowers, along with grain and apple. The flavour starts out with a light sweetness but becomes moderately bitter and slightly acidic and sour towards the end. The finish is long and spicy. On the palate, it is medium in body with a dry texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is a very nice tripel. It has a very nice fresh aroma and a nice finish. 2010-09-10

330 ml bottle. On the Sea of Åland (M/S Silja Symphony).
Hazy amber colour with no head.
Yeast, berries, mild sugar and some spices in aroma.
Flavour is Belgian yeast, some malt, notes of alcohol and sugary sweetness. Easy for a 9% brew.

Pours a cloudy golden color. 
Nice thick white head. Slight fruity aroma. Easy drinker. Clove and corriander taste, Belgian yeast taste. Some citrus and bananna. Alcohol not evident. This one really goes down easy and is one of my all time favorites.

Bottle.

A - Very light, clear golden color with a huge, thick, creamy, frothy, meringue-like head. Incredibly thick head. Very good retention that finally settles into a nice creamy layer of lace.

S - Pretty typical for a BSPA with a lot of golden fruit (apple, orange, apricot). Insane amount of Belgian yeast aroma with a fair amount of candi sugar aroma as well. Slight musty aroma as well.

T - Similar to the nose with a good amount of golden fruit (see above). Also a lot of yeasty flavor as well. Pretty good amount of spice and candi sugar with the sweetness slightly outweighing the spicy flavor. Some pale malt in the background.

M - Lighter side of medium body with about average carbonation. Sticky feel.

D - Nice tasting beer with a nice body, but nothing outstanding. Still pretty easy to drink and I enjoyed drinking it, although it wasnt overly inspiring in regards of making me want another.

Notes: A pretty good BSPA with a bit more of a mild flavor. Not my favorite beer, or even my favorite of the style, but it is quite a tasty beer. Definitely worth trying, and possibly worth getting again if the price is right.

750 ml bottle. Pours a hazy straw yellow color with a huge white head. It has the aroma of banana, lemon, yeast, clove and coriander.  It tastes of cream of wheat, hay, honey, lemon and apple. The is a very good beer. Its not the best triple Ive ever had but it is very satisfying. I look forward to trying more beer from this brewer.
UPDATED: FEB 16, 2015 One of the wifes favorites. Pops up in our fridge every so often.  Really an excellent beer. Slightly tart. Serving: Bottle and tap

1 year old bottle.  Pours a cloudy gold with a frothy white head that lasts ages (even when poured slow.  Aroma of green apples, pears, brie, mushrooms, and hay.  Flavor begins earthy and more malty than the fruit-dominated aroma suggests.  Theres wheat, breadcrust, pears, earth, cinnamon, and a leafy dryness.  Finishes with the fruit drying out, the spicy and pungent yeast qualities sticking to the throat, and bready, slightly sweet flavors laying on the tongue.  Aftertaste kinda cloys, but only when you sip infrequently.  High carbonation, creamy, medium bodied, fluffy mouthfeel, effervescent.  Always good, but I think Id prefer it fresh.

App:  Color: golden Liquid: hazyHead: white  Aroma :  Malt: cereal Hops: floral Other: alcohol, clove
Taste : Initial: light sweetness Finish: light sweetness Finish Duration: short Palate : 
Body: medium Carbonation: lively Finish: alcoholic O:  My best from this brewery. Superb balanced alcool is well hidden. Aroma is floral almost perfumy and very pleasing. What I like: the balance and complexity What I would change ; nothing

pours a cloudy, blonde ale with a large, quickly disappaiting, tight white head. There was little lacing. There is a light hops and heavy floral and citrus notes, I would say Pear scent. Palate entry is fairly sweet, but there is a residual sweetness due to bottle fermentation. Grapefruit citrus flavors predominate in the mid-palate, but I also detected essences of coriander and clove spice. Very strong effort here.
Pours gold with enormous white head. Aroma is lemony and yeasty with some very light malt. Flavor is also yeasty, with a sweeter, sharper fruitiness. Pretty heavily carbonated.

Poured from bottle. Pours a clear gold with a bright white pillowy head. Nose is fruity and toasty -- I get apple and peach overtones. The beer is tight and clean on the palate, with herbal and some citrus notes. Very dry. Finishes crisp, with strong carbonation.

Bottle. Big fan of the big beers (triple, Quad, Imperial Stouts) so this is always good treat.  Pours cloudy and murky deep amber with crisp foam. Other reviewers are right gas is perfect to deliver the intense and satisfying flavors of this brew.  I am glad that this is as common as it is.. a solid and respectable product.
Bottle. Hazy orange with white fast disappearing head. Fresh aroma of metal and fruits. Sweet in taste, some banana alcohol and fudge. Well carbonated, medium body.

(bottle at Seans Unibroue tasting).  Pours straw yellow with white head.  Aroma is yeasty, citrus and perfumy.  Taste is sweet with some bitterness.  Light bodied and thin and oily.  One of the pioneers of North American belgian-style ales.  La Fin du Monde is a very good tripple.

Pours a slightly hazy golden yellow with a creamy white head that recedes to a thick collar and thin cover of bubbles across the top.  Lots of bubbles streaming to the top.

The aroma is sweet with belgian yeast dominating alongside light fruits, especially pears and apricots, and plenty of grass and lightly toasted malts.

Taste has a biting sweetness up front with tons of fruity esters, bananas namely.  The Belgian yeast is there in the background as is the hints of earthiness, but theyre really overtaken by the sweetness.  The finish is sweet and sugary, not dry.

The mouthfeel is medium bodied and sticky sweet for the style.  Again, finish is less dry and more sweet with the alcohol lingering in the aftertaste.

This is a decent tripel but not one of the best Ive had.  Having just had the Westmalle tripel tonight, this doesnt quite measure up.  Its really sweet and less balanced than the best in the style.
Crisp, full flavored beer with a nice after taste. yeasty, so a bit heavy but very nicely balanced

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a Chimay goblet. Best by date 09-24-12.

Appearance: Pours an opaque golden orange with a 1/4 finger foamy white head which dissipates almost instantly. No lacing at all.

Smell: Quite sweet with banana, yeast and citrus dominating with just a hint of phenols.

Taste: Yeast and malt up front followed by a burst of banana and citrus esters in the middle then finishes with malt and dry phenols. Aftertaste is a mixture of sour citrus and phenols. The high alcohol is well hidden by the tremendous flavor of the beer.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied with a high amount of carbonation. The carbonation bursts through from the get go.

Drinkability: Excellent drinkability. You dont really notice the alcohol at all so this one could very well sneak up on you.

Overall: Excellent beer overall. Buy it if you see it. It is one I thoroughly enjoyed.

Served in a Unibroue tulip 

A: Golden going amber with a big white head that leaves behind a watery spiderweb lace, theres some visible carbonation and sediments.

S: Sweet, banana, bread, some orange (citrus), alcohol, flowery.

T: Sweet, citrusy, alcohol, little bit bitter aftertaste thats inviting to have some more.

Overall: very fine beer with a lot going on, kind of sweet and very warming that could sneak on yo giving you a fine buzz, would have it again without thinking.

Pours a hazy light orange with a thick foamy ivory head.  The aroma is powerful fruity, a bit yeasty.  Taste is a bit spicy with lots of orange and herbs. Strangely sweet too, but thats pretty faint.  Hops add a leafy flavor before the yeast comes back out for the slow lingering finish. The texture is smooth yet mildly carbonated. In all, outstanding.
Deep orange hazy body and a small white rocky head. Spiced aroma, coriander, wheat fruity and yeasty. The taste is rather sweet in the beginning but the finish i spiced, bitter and warming.
Poured a cloudy pale yellow with a nice, yet mildl head. A subtle hint of citrus. Very nice after taste.

NOTE: I simply am not a fan of tripels so my rating is biased

Have had numerous times in the bottle and finally rating this.

Pours hazy golden orange with an abundance of foam that disappears quickly.

Aroma is very floral, but a ton of bready yeast present.  Some hints of lemon and cinnamon.

Flavor is mild sweet honey, then a pretty well balanced bitterness, but the yeast really dominates the flavor.

Medium bodied, lively carbonation that accentuates the flavor.

Overall, probably a very solid example of the style, but this is not a beer I return to often.

Bottle (a little too old, according to the bottle). Clear golden yellow, modest white foam. Aroma of yeasty sourness, flowers, sour grapes, wet bread, very belgian indeed. Also some cardboard and honey-like sweetness. Not overly pleasant. Taste is quite sweet and rich on flowery freshness, along with yeast, malts and citrus. Not very bitter. Medium body, high carbonation.

The cork almost killed me as it popped out of the bottle as soon as I uncaged it. Pours yellow with a soapy white head. Aroma is really weird. It has a yeast component that has cardboard, the essence of old urin and wet wood. Really weird and rather unpleasant. Besides from that it has all the normal tripel qualities with flowery yeast,, honey and elder flower. The taste is without the cardboard and the urin, fine malt component, slight hop bitterness and the classic yeast characteristic. The aroma really pulls this beer down for me.

From the 750 ml. corked bottle dated 07-02-12.  The bottle fermented pour is cloudy, pale yellow with a silky and smooth looking one inch thick off-white head.  Excellent frosting-like lacing. The aroma is vibrant with yeast, grains with a wheat-like character, and malts. The mouthfeel is chewy.  The taste has a nice malty-hoppy character with a decent masking of the 9% ABV.  A truly likeable brew.

Bottle thanks to Danny. Slightly hazy light orange colour with largish cream coloured head. Some lacing. Aromas are dominated by doughy yeast, spice (mainly cloves) and plenty of slightly sour oranges. Good stuff. Flavour wise the doughy yeast is definately there as are the cloves. The citrus is also there and more tart than in the aroma. Mouthfeel is quite full and really suits the style. Good beer.

750ml bottle in a tulip.  Pours nice golden with a thick, white head.  Aroma of spicy yeast, dough, a little citrus and light fruit.  The sweet caramel/light fruit malt flavor is first apparent, with the yeasts spiciness underlying it and leading the finish.  Full bodied with a nice texture.  A very good tripel, especially for not being Belgian.

Easily one of the greatest brews I have ever enjoyed.  Not for the light drinker, this beer is strong and has a very complex flavor profile that I can not even begin to do justice when describing.  I have had a very difficult time locating places that sell this, but it is around.  If youve never had it, you should... it is the end of the world after all.
33cl bottle (Spain) Pours hazy orange with a white head. Strong retention. Citrusfruit nose, very sugarish alcohol imo. very sparkling, lively and a bit harsh.
UPDATED: NOV 21, 2010 Bière très forte en alcool...épicé avec saveur de houblon Chinook...parait quelle est meilleur à consommer après 3-5ans.

First time I had this, not knowing anything about beer, I thought it was foul.  So best have some idea what a trippel is meant to be before you try it!  Anyway, big alcohol, wild fruity and spicy aromas, with big crazy yeasts as youd expect
Just because it is 9% alcohol doesnt mean it deserves a great rating, but this is a pretty good Tripel.

Finally! I have wanted to try this for a long time, and, thankfully, it has lived up to all I have heard. Let me begin by saying that I love beers with lots of hops, but this beer was a real eye-opener. This beer gives me no aroma or taste of hops, rather the taste and aroma are driven by yeast and malt. This beer is very refined, very smooth, and very good. There is some citrus taste in there somewhere, and no hint of the alcohol. A great beer.

UPDATED: JUL 23, 2010 Pours a pale yellow with a nice white head and thick sheets of lacing are left hanging to the sides of the glass.  The smell is rather soft showcasing spices like coriander.  A small amount of apple as well in the nose.  The flavor is just wonderful.  Lovely spices, yeasty fresh bread, soft and sweet fruits like apples and bananas, chewy caramel, and its just a touch dry in the finish.  A terrific tripel.

A good friend of mine recently purchased this bottle for me for my birthday.  He was told that I liked good beer, so he googled "fancy beer" and this came up alongside Delirium Tremens.  I do like this stuff, not my favorite style but it is pretty good.  Aroma is of Belgian yeast, banana, and clove.  Appearance is a very cloudy yellow with a thin white head.  Taste is very rich in clove, somewhat fruity, rather sweet.  Like I said, I like it, but would choose other beers before this one.
Im no professional beer taster, but this brew was a treat.  Smooth, discreet, and delicious.

A-hazy golden yellow color that has a big, bubbly white head that has some lingering but leaves very little lacing on the glass

S-the smell is of orange peel, a touch of spicy clove, notes of belgian yeast.

T-very sweet, a little one dimensional, tons of citrus orange peel with a light herbal spice and touch of bready malt.

M-very smooth with a nice amount of carbonation and a full medium body, somewhat creamy with a crisp finish that has a drying effect on the throat

D-the alcohol is hidden very well and this has a sweetness after the initial yeast the is quite nice.  one dimensional but still tasty.
Pours hazy golden with a thick white head and spotty lacing.  aroma is citrus, belgian hops and yeast,  Wet mouthfeel. taste is pale malt, hops, coriander and yeast.  long bittersweet finish.

Pours nice with a golden color and a hug head. Sour yeasty smell that carries over into the taste with fruit and spicy notes. High carb and clean sweet finish. Not a fan of  triples, but this was tasty.

I have always been interested in the Unibroue beers simply because their labels look like something straight off an eighties rock album.  But there is nothing cheesy about this beer.  Its the real deal.  Pours a hazy light amber with a beautiful froth to the head.  Smells of yeast, citrus and banana.  The flavor is excellent and the small bite that just precedes the finish is nice.  Goes down really smooth and doesnt disappoint.  An excellent triple.

Pours a very murky, burned blonde with a fairly large, foamy off-white head. Nose is classic abbey tripel, with spiciness, a touch of hops, a little yeast, and a ton of candied sugar malt in it. Flavor also goes down a typical abbey tripel road; lots of bready and sugary malt with some coriander, bitter citrus peel, bittering hops, and distinct alcohol modifying it. Finish is lacking a little and is short and a little sticky. This is, however, a very balanced tripel and a solid beer.
Bottle 33cl. A yellow amber beer with nice white head. Smell is on citrus and Belgian yeast. Aroma is typically on Belgian triple, medium body, very astringent, dominant notes of agrumes and spices.
much better than expected. am new at rating beer but this was a pleasant surprise. pours light hazy brown, relatively light taste and best shared with a friend. (big bottle!) overall very good.
Quite thick and creamy in the mouth (thats what she said! lame i know) with fruity and spice flavours, that finish with a citrusy kick. very nice, bought a 2 pack with Unibroue glasses.

12oz bottle from total wine in norfolk. pours a hazy, yellow-gold with a thick, creamy, white head leaving sticky lacing. aroma is great, very fruit forward, with notes of pear, apple skins, lemon zest, and sweet, white grapes with light sugar, yeast, and cedar with hints of clove and dry hops. flavor is wonderful as well with a great balance of sweet fruits, dry, bready yeast, and spicy cloves with a hint of tropical fruits and grass on the swallow. palate is medium bodied and crisp with high carbonation and a dry, fruity finish. overall, a delicious tripel.

Appearance:  hazy, buttery golden with a bubbly two-finger head that disappeared to a collar; light lacing.  Aroma:  yeast, sweet alcohol, cloves, pine.  Taste:  lightly sweet, with cloves and some citrus bite.  Finish:  medium of length, bittersweet, tongue-tingling; hint of light sweet crackery grains, then a warming of alcohol in my belly.  Me likey.  An extremely drinkable tripel.
Over the years its gotten a bit watered down from where it started, but overall this is still quite the amazing and now fairly widely spread brew.

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2010 Large, corked bottle.  Very easy to drink, but itll get you if youre not careful.  Would be good with a dinner with friends, but I cant imagine drinking the entire thing, especially in enough time to keep it from getting too warm. Great if everyone is having it, probably not a good idea is youre the only one.
Wheaty. Not bad. Hhhhhhhhhhh&bbhjddsjsjjjjjjjjjhgggggggggghhhh 75 characters

Hazy golden color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of yeast, clove, fruit, & spice; Flavor of sweet malt, yeast, fruit, clove, some citrus, hops, and spice; Nicely balanced & complex; Very good overall - I enjoyed this one.

750ml corked bottle.  Thick, unfiltered, golden-orange.  Big, steady, foamy head.  Bright lemony citrus and Belgian yeast aroma.  Big, thick and creamy Tripel.  Orange-liqueur aftertaste, with some dry wheat(?) tones, and a mellow bitterness.  Rich and rugged.  Intense yeast character.  A classic Tripel.

22oz bottle from Willow Bend in Lutz, FL. Pours a golden-yellow with a medium white head and lasting carbonation. Aroma is lots of citrus, flowes, and pepper. Flavor is sweet citrus fruits and lots of pepper. Great warm mouthfeel with a pleasant puckering feeling. Medium mouthfeel. Very good.
Appearance was cloudy and fizzy, orange-yellow.  Sour and fruity with noticeable alcohol.  Very refreshing and enjoyable to sit and sip.

bottle.  for once it didnt spill all over the place, yay!  Pours dark orange and moderately cloudy with energetic white foam.  Aroma is alcohol and something akin to "basement aromas".  Tastes is pleasant though a little sour.  Aftertaste is hard to identify; it changes as it goes down.  medium body, soft carbonation, long finish.  Im biased towards this one due to the nostalgia it brings, but it seems pretty flat, almost too powerful and a little tin-y.  However, in about 15 minutes, it wont matter one bit.  I love this beer.

Pours a light orange-amber with a nice white fluffy head. 

Nose is orange, sour apple, slate, lime, and a hint of toast. 

Taste is orange pith, lemon, sour apple, and a bit of vegetation. Nice long finish as well. 

Palate is crisp, clean, carb is balanced well, alcohol is noticeable for sure, but not unpleasant. 

Overall a solid tripel, I prefer the punch of Karmaliet but this is definitely no slouch and very drinkable.

Refrigerated bottle poured into a trappist glass.  Pours a cloudy light orange with slightly small fluffy off-white head.  Taste is fruity orange, some apricot, and hint of sour apple.  Good Tripel, can only think of a couple that I prefer.

33cl bottle @Silja Symphony ferry. Poured cloudy, light brown color. No head. Aroma is yeasty and of apple and bread. Flavour is bready and spicy, quite complex. Oily palate. Smooth finish, hint of alcohol. Nice carbonation. Very enjoyable.

A. Cloudy, amber to light orange appearance with nice fluffy white head. Spotty lacing. 

S. Belgian style nose all over this one - yeasty charcoal, toasted bread, mild citrus and clove. Very pleasant fragrance.

T. Similar taste profile to the nose - malts and mixed fruits upon entry and then some prickly hops and a lingering banana/yeastiness on the finish. Flavor stays with you for a while

M. Medium bodied with good carbonation - feels quite nice across my entire palate. 

D. This is an easy to drink beer that is very enjoyable. Keeps you warm from the first sip. A wonderful sipper.  My first Unibroue beer and one that I will buy again. Highly recommend.
Light golden opaque with a small white head. Yeasty and fruity aroma. Flavor is initially sour with a nice sweet aftertaste. Clean. dry and effervescent body. Excellent beer.

Bottle. How have I not rated this yet? I drink it pretty close to weekly. Odd. Pours hazy bright gold/yellow, with a thick white head that laces well. Nose is lemons, spice (especially pepper), bubblegum, and the usual Unibroue "conquers all" yeast aroma. Flavors are balanced, but slightly towards the phenolic end, with more lemony citrus and yeasty characters towards the finish. A very reliable "go-to" Tripel.

341ml Bottle. Pours opaque, yellow-light orange with well laced head and spicy, bready aromas on the nose.  Medium-high mouthfeel as expected being a tripel with a complex flavour experience. In no way is the strength of the beer hidden, but showcases its depth and character in each and every way. I really love the unibroue beers. In my opinion this one tops many of the classic tripels.

Bottle with due date of 22/10/08. Pours a murky brownish orange, no head, small floaties. Aroma is winey, old, fruity, past it´s due date all right.
Flavour is fruity sweetness with a weak bitterness, hint of vinegar and liquorice. Need to try a fresh bottle, this has clearly lost it´s taste.

Bottle at tasting, thanks dEnk! Best before august 08. Hazy golden color with a thin white head and floaties. Aroma of slightly aged tripel, fruits, vinegar and licorice. Flavor is fruity and mild, slightly bitter and a bit sour, slightly over its prime. Should try a fresh one sometime.
Pours a nice orange apricot with a frothy head. Nose and taste is sweet brown sugar, sour apples, citrus and roasted breads. Rated 1/16/2000

Bottle, 341ml. Pours an opaque orange colour with no head at all, Im guessing its because the cap was twist, WTF. Aroma is citrus with some roasted character, lots of alcohol. Taste is robust and heavy, some citrus and floral notes. Low bitterness. I expected more.

Medium creamy white head for amber-golden beer. Aroma is malty and spicy with a bit alcholic feeling. Peaches-apricots fruitness and honey too.
Taste is sweet dominant but well sustained by sourness and bitterness.
Great carbonation mouthfeel, but not aggressive at all. Some warm too.
Full body. An excellent tripel!

Pours dark golden with lots of white head. Aroma of citrus and apples. Tastes of citrus as well with a lot of carbonation and bubbles. Full mouth feel with a smooth aftertaste. Disguises the high alcohol content very well.

Preface:  It took a long time to get Unibroue into the liquor store in which I work.  I have been waiting for some time to get my hands on some.  Anywho, here goes.

12 oz bottle, 40-45* in stone I.R.S. Tulip.  Pours hazy yellow-orange with a giant, foamy head.  Looks like the Duvel advertisements.  A lovely aroma consisting of orange, lemon, banana, yeast, and honeysuckle follow.  Strangely, the yeast isnt as prominent as in other tripels.  The taste is lemon-banana, with orange in the background.  The finish is floral and clean.  The carbonation stays with the brew throughout the experience.  A lovely warming effect follows.  This is worth all the hype.  This is the best tripel Ive ever had (trumping chimay, duvel, piraat, tripel karmeliet, etc).

As a critic of many mediums for almost 20 years now Ive come to realize that not everything is everyones cup of tea. Certain things can be outstanding examples of whatever it is they represent, but only to specific audiences. But there are also certain items which are indeed acquired tastes but also transcend to the mainstream as at least a quality product. Unibroues La Fin Du Monde is a perfect example of this in the world of beer. Its a French-Canadian take on a Belgian Trappist tripel style  now if that description alone doesnt indicate how niche of a beer this is, I dont know what will. APPEARANCE AND AROMAThe name of this beer literally translates to The end of the world, and considering that name you might expect something dark and bloody like an amber ale, but the opposite is actually true. Perhaps they should have called this The beginning of the world since the color is a golden maize hue like the rising sun on a hot summer day. The body itself is very hazy to the point of actually being opaque despite its light, apricot-skin color. Since this beer is bottle-fermented there is noticeable carbonation due to the heavy yeast addition although the bubbles are tiny. The head is surprisingly fizzy and evaporates quickly and leaves very little lacing on the glass.The aroma is very spicy with hints of banana and clove not unlike a hefeweizen, but not quite as strong. Theres also a bread-like component and maybe a bit of dryness, as well as some alcohol. Its inviting, but the scent alone tells me this is no light brew.TASTEThe hardest part of being a beer critic is describing flavor since language and the human sense of taste are vastly different things. Some flavors are difficult to describe and Id say La Fin Du Monde is a great example of this. But to state it as plainly as possible, Id say this beer is very spicy. I do get a bit of banana and clove but they take a back seat to a mélange of spices. In fact, theres so many of them I dont think I can detect or distinguish any individual flavors (nutmeg and cinnamon perhaps). I do appreciate the fact this beer has such a complex palate because the overall taste did indeed change as I drank. It starts out rather light with a slight fruity/citrusy taste which quickly retreats as the spices take over. Theres also some vanilla to the palate which gives the beer a sweet taste. However, once the yeast makes itself known, the palate then becomes much drier and words like bready, powdery, and doughy come to mind. La Fin Du Monde is all about the malts, but even more so the yeast (it is triple-fermented with live yeast added to the bottle, after all). As I hop head Id probably prefer something more bitter, but because its so tasty I found it enjoyable. The only caveat (and this is a biggie), is that its so spicy it can be overwhelming. Not that the spices are bad, just that theyre a lot to take in all at once. This is an example of where having the proper acquired taste would make the beer seem even better, but its at least enjoyable.DRINKABILITYTrying to describe the ease of drinking this beer may sound like an oxymoron, but its not. There are two distinct factors here: the mouthfeel itself is soft and gentle and for such a potent beer does not warm as it goes down. However, it is the spices that dance on the palate and the yeast leaves a dry, powder-like aftertaste which I dont care for. I almost wanted to follow every swig with a sip of water. The spices also pack such a punch that its difficult to drink this beer in anything larger than medium sips (and for a beer geek like me who usually drinks by the gulps thats really saying something).WEIGHTIm not a fan of big beers, since the alcohol tends to outshine the palate and the potency can make a beer too filling too fast. For a beer that is quite heavy at 9% ABV, Unibroues tripel does a great job of masking it in both the flavor and the weight. Really, the only thing heavy about this beer is the palate, but otherwise its fairly light on its toes. FINAL THOUGHTSAs a budding beer connoisseur I was able to enjoy Unibroues La Fin Du Monde for what it was. As much as I understand and appreciate the craftsmanship and the distinction to a beer of this style and by a brewery with such a good reputation, I wouldnt honestly consider it among the best of the best. Its a very good beer, though. What I do like is its ability to perform that rare feat of satisfying the pedestrian drinker while also working as a connoisseurs delight.NOTE: Watch the video version of this review at:http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Fkd1PhziXM4 (original)orhttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1F36xOnehik (re-review)

Hazy deep golden straw, nice head. Aromas of perfumed lilac, banana bread, and spice. Taste of crisp malt and light spice hop. Finish is crisp but sweet. Lght fizzy body.  Belgium should be proud of this Canadian counterpart.

Amber with small vanishing head. Aroma hops, yeast, sweet fruit. Taste hops, yeast, fruity banana, apricot, bitter grape. Medium body. Texture smooth. Carb average. Finish bittersweet. Delicious but low on appearance.

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2010 "Its all about mouthfeel," Sasha Grey once told me. (What an enigma  she is, right? That movie, followed by those clips?... Its  impossible to reconcile.) This is a  really nice beer. Appealing blonde pour (like that chef from Treme)  with medium head (like that chef from Treme?). Lively, with plus  carbonation. Sweet enough, if not too. Its a trippel, if lighter,  bearing cirtus, even lemongrass. Lingering finish. Dont take me too  seriously (Buck Dharma: ŏbvē-əs-lē) as I havent seriously  studied, but I have had many beers and find this is better than most
A crisp trippel--yes, the fine folks at Unibroue have a sparkling product, light straw color, modest white head, light and well-carbonated. a honeyed sweetness with a little citrus edge.

Liquide doré et légèrement embrouillé.  Collet blanc.  Bonne effervescence.  Complexité évidente aux niveaux des arômes : la grande famille des agrumes, malt, épices douces et piquantes, levure belge.  Les saveurs sont en équilibre entre le malt, les fruits tropicaux épicés et lalcool.  Légère amertume en finale.  Liquide soyeux et réconfortant.  Toujours un plaisir.

Beer three in my Unibroue assortment... my favorite yet.  Has the distinctive Belgian taste, but not quite as sweet as some of their other varieties.  A taste of melon, almost.  Moderate carbonation, very smooth.

Dammit Unibroue.  This is only the second beer in their lineup Ive managed to obtain in Alabama...and it is quite possibly my favorite beer ever.  It has all the sweetness, alcohol, and brandy tastes of the abby ales I typically love...but theres something malty and deep in it that really tastes terrific.  Head is moderate and carbonation is moderate, the palate is perfect for the style.  Beautiful golden (pale) color.   Love it.

La Fin Du Monde is one of my favorite beers. It is not necessarily the best beer in the entire world, but its widely available, comes in large and small singles and is a tremendous tripel, no mean feat. Unibroue beers have superb feel and delicious flavors. Its certainly the best tripel that Ive tried that is not from Belgium. The beer has a somewhat inconsistent look. The head bubbles up, but it settles into a calm champagne look without much lacing. The misty liquid is quite appealing, on the other hand. The nose is earthy and spicy. It has a genuine Belgian flavor that is subtle and often lacking from American versions of Belgian styles. The flavor has this same Belgian earthiness, that quality that marks some of the best beers in the world. The feel is of a billion tiny needles gently exploding.
Pours a hazy golden color, with a medium head.  Scents of fruit are prominent, and is very flavorful with a very bubbly finish.  Excellent triple.
Cloudy orange with a nice head.  Spicy, citrusy aroma.  Great carbonation and mouthfeel.  Heavy, thick, complex and delicious.  Love it.

0,33 l bottle as a gift.
Poured hazy orange-golden with a nice foamy offwhite head. Typical belgian yeast character in the nose with fine citrusses, orange peel, mild spicies like clove, coriander. Sweet caramel and honey leads the complex flavor with small co2-bubbles. Flowers and vanilla, some mild coriander with a grainy background. Little bit too sweet but pleasant.

~Yeasty aroma of pepper and spicy phenols, moderate fruity aromas of pear and apple.
~Pours a light yellowish gold color with little to no head. Not very bubbly, possibly old or bad bottle...
~Balanced flavor of yeasty phenols of fruit and spice, pear and pepper, some lemon, slight alcohol.
~Light bodied with med CO2. A bit disapointed with carbonation. Dry, yeasty fruit spice finish.
~Enjoyable brew. As a triple nothing really stands out and sets this apart from others. Seems a bit muted..
Bottle. Orange gold pour with a thin white head. Aroma and taste of spice/clove, yeast, and bread. Very nice beer.
Orange yellow and creamy head. Fruity, spicey & yeasty. Smooth dry finish & wonderful bitterness. Quality sipper.

12oz bottle from LCBO. Golden uniformly opaque appearance. Disappointingly weak aroma, but surprisingly complex taste of citrus, acid, and honey. Fizzy on the tongue with a clean palate. Overall delicious.
Probably the beer that turned me into the lover i am today!  Lots of memories!

A-cloudy pale yellow with thick white head. great retention.

S-some yeast, citrus and spices.

T-great blend of citrus and spices with a backgroud of yeast. Clean finish. Alcohol is barely noticable.

P- high carbonation and fairly thick body. goes down pretty smooth

O- I cant tell this is 9% ABV and it is very delicious. I will try this one again. Another great offering from Unibroue

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-30-2007 17:13:26

Color is similar to apple cider vinegar with a thin and quickly disappearing head. Tastes of sweet malts, citrus, and floral. Body is oily and complex, strangely heavy. Smells of sweet malts and citrus.

Bottle. Exactly what I want out of a tripel. Pours a lovely, glowing orange with a fluffy white head. Nice aroma of banana, yeast, bread and some spice. Flavor is rich, with some nice fruity sweetness, like banana and orange. Lingering spiciness, too. Medium to full in body, very smooth, lightly warming. A true delight.

Bottled. From the Sanctuary Hotel in SC. Yellow to orange with thin white head. Aroma is citrus yeasty, wheaty, and as general spice with touch of coriander and also hint of banana. Flavors include orange, yeasty fruit esters and yeasty spice (coriander). Also apple sauce with cinnamon, leather, and general citric zest. Finish is spicy and nice.

UPDATED: OCT 12, 2010 Bottle pours medium yellow slightly cloudy moderate white head with good persistence and lacing.  Aroma of fruits.  Taste of clove, spice,fruits.  Mildly bitter finish but not overpowering.  Nice beer.

12oz. Bottle. 
Pours a hazy bright gold with fairly minimal head. Nose is all fruit with an underlying hint of spice. A nice curve ball in the mouth, sweet up front but a lingering bitter/sour finish. Surprisingly little alcohol burn for the strength. Overall, dangerously drinkable.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2011 Hazy gold, short-lived white head. Smells of grapes, kumquats, earthy yeast and cloves. Flavours of those plus peaches and more spices. Taste is mildly sweet and quite spicy. Quite carbonated mouthfeel, but very soft and tiny bubbles. A deceptively light and gracious brew.  [3.8]750ml bottle. Very hazy gold, dense white head. Aroma is fruity and floral with earthy yeast and some spices. Sweet taste with stone fruits, candi sugar and considerable doughy and earthy yeast is balanced with nice carbonation and gentle spicy bitterness. Still quite a sweet finish, but spices poke through. Classy drop.

12oz bottle 
Appearance: Hazy yellow/golden with a nice fluffy white head, some lacing. Tons of bubbles coming up from the bottom, it looks like champagne. 
Aroma: Sweet, yeasty, citrus and earthy 
Taste: Yeast and malts, citrus and bready 
Very refreshing beer. Crisp and clean, well balanced. I cant taste any alcohol, be careful with this one.

Pours a light-yellow cider color with a very healthy foamy white head. Aroma has a mix of apple, some citrus and floral hints to it.  Taste is a mix of apples, spice, and some malts. Alcohol is there also, but not too strong, which is surprising considering its 9% ABV.  Good thickness and carbonation. Definitely a drinkable beer for any occassion, but pricey.
Pours a beautiful, cascading blonde color with a fluffy white rimmed head.  Taste is of crisp grapes, spice, yeast and medium carbonation.  Highly enjoyable.
Sweet fruity nose.  Amber with descent head.  A sweet, candy sugar, malt flavor...still a bit light.

Hazy yellow color, small white head; sweet and very fruity aroma with notes of yeast and spices; medium body, oily palate with moderate carbonation; heavy sweet, somewhat sugary flavor with again lots of fruits, yeast and spices. I actually wouldnt judge the waiter if this was to be served to me as a weizenbock - a very good one, that is - as I didnt detect a faintest amount of hops. Which is pity because I feel this still needs something to balance its sweetness to be truly awesome.

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2012 Soft sour sweet belgian aroma. Pours from the bottle very clear with a huge head. Hazy dark yellow color. Takes a few minutes for head to disapate so you can drink. Head is like meringue mushroom.  Sweet sour flavor. Very belgian. On the sweet side. Head still wont disapate. Some clove, spicy, fruity, maybe honey... sweet. Medium palate, many flavors linger... belgian backbone. Overall a great belgian. Flavors far too complex for my palate, but they work. Likely the most enjoyable and balanced belgian I have had.

12 ounce bottle drink by Sept 12. Pouring into a La Fin du Monde tulip glass produced a commanding head. Crackling fizz. Aroma and first half of the taste are very fruity in a citrus/peach/apricot sort of way...witbier like. A touch sweet, but with some finishing coriander and clove spice. Some salty/spicy hops (Saaz or Styrian Goldings). As it warms, the yeast takes center stage and becomes too much, IMO. The ideal tripel might lie somewhere in between. Some gut warming alcohol too.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2010 Poured an almost opaque brownish gold with a eggshell white head (the head goes away fairly fast leaving a thin layer behind). The aroma was curious... can not really put my finger on it.... sour fruit, clove and a hint of alcohol stand out. Taste is: sweets, spices and fruit (grapefruit). Decent body with some depth. Overall a nice beer... but a little too sweet for my taste. Glad I tried it but dont know if I would buy another.
Pours a light yellow with some carbonation.  Nice aroma of fruit.  Very smooth and delicious.  Easy to drink.

Possibly my favorite by Unibroue brewery..  I *always* have bottles of this in my stash here at home, and always have a cold one in the fridge.  Golden yellow, looks delicious.  Smells amazing, some fruit, some spice, maybe some vanilla?  I dont have the greatest sense of smell but I know what I like, and I love this beer.

One of my all-time favourites.  Unibroue does wonderful work.  Aroma - caramel, bread, roasty, citrus, herbs, dough, leather. Appearance - brown, hazy, tan foam. Taste - heavy cloying sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour.  Palate - full body, creamy, sticky, lively, long finish.

Bottle 750ml. Delicious. Aromas of butter, apple, and spice. Taste is sweet, with a touch of sourness, and long-lasting bitter finish. Silky palate, medium-to-full body. Yellow and cloudy, frothy white head.

This is a great beer in the 750ml corked bottle. I recently purchased it in the smaller 12oz crown capped bottles and it was horrible. Flat, lifeless, no head. Very untypical of the beer from the corked bottle. I would advise avoiding the Unibroue products in the crown cap packaging and stick with the corked Belgian bottles.

750mL bottle.  Pours a slightly hazy yellow-gold with quite a small head.  Aromas of Belgian yeasts, citrus oils and volatile spices.  Flavours of tropical fruit with low acidity, medium sweetness, fairly mild bitterness and a little floury.  Medium bodied, lively carbonation and fairly creamy with a short, slightly sweet finish.

A: Bottle poured into my Koningshoven chalice to reveal a clear golden beer with a thin but sturdy layer of white foam on top.

S: The smell of sweet apples, clove, yeast, and a bit of white grapes. There is also a touch of alcohol.

T: The spice comes out much more in the flavor than it does in the aroma. A lot of clove and nutmeg are complimented nicely by some fruity esters and a hint of yeast. There is a very well balanced sweetness to bitterness ratio that Ive found to be lacking in other Tripels.

M: Very nice body on this beer; medium to full, in fact. The carbonation appears very lively in the glass but is a bit muted on the tongue itself. A bit of alcohol heat hits the back of the throat as well.

D: This is one of the first Tripels Ive really enjoyed. Good solid Belgian yeast character and a fruitiness and sweetness that is well balanced. The only knock on the drinkability of this beer comes from the alcohol, but still easy to drink.

man, the twist top gets me every time! little bottle bb 2/17/2012 consumed 12/5/2009. 

pours hazy burnt golden with a soft white head. 

the nose is intensely yeasty... autolyzed, woody, smoky, apples and tons of spice.

the yeast causes the flavor to be smoky earthy and woody along with other notes of cloves, floral esters, pale malt, apples and tons of spice before the dry finish. 

the medium body is prickly and crisp... light enough to drink a ton of (@9%!... ouch). 7.5/4/7/4/16/3.85
Just not my cup of tea. While the overall flavor was subtle the spicy bite was just not fun to drink for me.

A light orange body with a very pillowy white head.  Lots of medium-sized bubbles.  Very citrusy aroma, with notes of orange peel, clove and other spices.  Complex yet not overpowering.  Sweet and slightly tangy, a bit of barnyard and hay along side the sweet almost doughy flavor.  Finishes out with a semi-sweet aftertaste and very little bitterness.

Pours a hazy, golden color with a fizzy head. The aroma reminds me of canned clams for some reason. Very similar to a dry champagne. I really didnt care for this beer during the first half of the bottle. It started to grow on me as I drank the second half. Its not bad, but not nearly as good as some of the other tripels Ive had.

A cloudy Gold color, with a HUGE  frothy, white foam head. Plenty of Tropical fruits, mostly Passion Fruit, framed with a Yeasty aroma. There is bottle variations because of the Bottle Conditioning. Most of the time, a memorable Ale any time of year
Cloudy gold in colour. Refreshing mouth feel with hints of citrus and apple, hides its alcohol well. Very drinkable!

(bottle, sampled 1/29/10). Cloudy yellow/orange color. Medium off white head, which is mostly diminishing. Doughy aroma. Dough/bread flavor. Avg duration. Smooth finish. Thin texture. Moderate/fizzy carbonation. Spare lacing.

This and Maudite on sale at the supermarket. 33cl bottle. Overall a very good triple. Nice aroma of sweet spicy slightly metalic tart fruit; green apples maybe? Golden appearance with a decent head that fades but never leaves. Yeasty complex sweet fruity spicy taste. Good blend of spicy sweetness(Belgian Candi sugar) and hops. I liked this one, but very heady at 9%.

I find it difficult to rate LFDM completely objectively. Its such a great well balanced triple and has been one of my top ten beers for a decade. Sweet, fragrant, touch of clove scent, light, subtle. Beautiful color. Not exported much to Europe, UK in particular. I guess with Belgium almost in sight it seems pointless to import a triple from Canada. Such a mistake. Brilliant and consistent.

Bottle.  Pours a beautiful gold with a fluffy, lasting white head.  Aroma is bright, fruity, and spicy, with fruity apricot, peach, apple, and coriander.  Tastes sweet but not cloying, with a pleasant level of carbonation.  The aforementioned fruity notes and spicy yeast come through in the flavor, with perhaps some more juicy tropical tones.  Finishes a little dry, with a nice, warming bit of alcohol and a touch of citrus.  I waited too long for my first Unibroue, and it is leaving me thirsty for more.

Bottle from a sampler poured into a La Fin Du Monde tulip--what symmetry! Pale yellow with a massive, creamy white head, this looks fairly impressive. Real fruity on the nose, with bananas, apples and grapes showing the most. Faint spice with a nice blast of yeast -- very nice. Sweet, with some honey, touch of booze, and light spice. Much better as it warms up, as it bites with carbonation when its cold. Overall, sweet and tasty!

Chilled in a pint glass. Pours quite hazy yellow with a large thick head.  Lots of yeast and bread notes with some some spice.  Taste is very well balanced between sweet (banana/passion fruit, light vanilla), spicy (coriander, ginger), and savory (bread/yeast).  There is some heat from the alcohol but is fairly well masked.  Its a very nice beer overall.  Its not my favorite tripel but its a nice change on occasion.
Poured hazy yellow with a full, fluffy head. Semi-sweet malts with some coriander spice. Tastes like a real Belgian triple. Well balanced, well crafted and a great brew.

Bottle. Gift from Pinball. Hazy golden body with a longlasting white head. The aroma is citric and yeasty with a good fruity background. Some hops and peach. The flavour is malty and spicy with notes of coriander, citrus and yeast. A very fine tripel.
Wonderfully balanced example of a strong beer....citrus, spices, and that ineffable finish reminiscent of Hoegaarden, despite the difference in style. Canadas best!

75cl bottle shared. Pours cloudy golden with a frothy white head. The aroma of yeast and orange was present. taste of yeast, lots of yeast and malt, a sweet beer. Overall and very nice unibrew example, strong but the alcohol does not kill the flavour.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2010 750 mL bottle pours yellowish amber with plenty off white head into a tulip.  Nice lacing once the head dissipates.  Richly malted aroma with dried bananas, apricots, clove, vanilla, quite yeasty.  Taste starts with banana chips and dried apricots, almost like bubblegum.  Blends into sweet malts, pineapple juice, vanilla, clove.  Yeasty profile with lemon and herbs kick in towards the finish, with quite a bit of a mandarin taste coming in the rear.  Hides the abv very well and is exceptionally balanced.  Fizzy mouthfeel, medium bodied with mid-high carbonation level; leaves a refreshing clean feeling on the palate.  I’m not a fan of many tripels, but this is quite lovely.  I would love to have this on a warm summer night; delicious.

750ml bottle. into tulip glass, pours a hazy yellow with lots of yeast floating around. gorgeous bouquet of yeast, citrus, and spices. particularly coriander. taste is very spicy, lots of yeast. lots of carbonation. despite being one of Unibroues top rated beers, its not my favorite from them.
Bottle pours a hazy golden with a white head. Aroma is fruity, belgian spice, sour wheat, and bready yeast. Flavor is fruity, bready yeast, and a bit of citrusy hops.

UPDATED: APR 14, 2010 Pours a golden blonde fizzy kind of pale white head .... aroma of spices and fruits ...... taste of yeast spices and grapes or apples ... not too heavy very nice spicy dry finish ...... a well balanced beer and the alcohol is hidden well
Bottle.Hazy yellow colour with large white head.Aroma is fruity with hint of yest,citrus and wheat,good lively mouthfeels and tasty warming stuff.

Pours a clear, golden color with a tall, pillowy, white head that fades slowly. Aroma has a  hefty cherry and apple fruitiness, a bready malt profile with a mild spicy, yeasty note to round out the nose. Flavor starts off with a nice biscuit presence which moves to a sweet fruity middle with a some solid yeasty tang to it at the end. Body is moderate to heavy in feeling with a creamy texture and high carbonation. Overall a very enjoyable brew and one that I enjoy savoring on many occasions.

A fruit bouquet, with notes of spice and malt.  Hazy golden appearance with a very thin head.   Sweet taste with a slightly bitter finish, very slight.  A full body with a clean finish, well carbonated.  A very excellent beer, great balance.  One of my favorite tripels.

(Sample Date: 10/9/2009   Source:Other)   12 oz bottle 9%. Grainy bready and fruity yeast aroma. Almost clear golden straw with fluffy white head. Spicy yeast character with a very light fruitiness. Grainy, candi sugar sweetness. Perceptible alcohol warming. Finish is medium with moderate residual bitterness.

I bought this beer in a pint bottle sealed with a cork. The cork was extremely hard to pull out,, taking about five minutes between me and my roommate prying it out. Finally, the cork pipped out, along with a splash of beer and a ton of foam.

Thankfully, the beer was worth it. Very subtle sweet fruit notes in the taste, along with a pleasently sweet aroma. The alchohol is blended nicely, espcecially for a beer that boasts a 9% alchohol by volume. The color is a pale cloudy orange. One of the better beers I have tasted. Flavors are not too strong or overwhelming, but still delicious, making for a very drinkable and enjoyable brew. Highly recommended.
Pours a yellow orange color with a bitter spice taste.  Tastes of coriander and spice.  A zesty orange peel aftertaste throughout the beer.

Yellowish pour with a white head. Aroma is fruity, yeast, spicy. Flavor is yeasty, sweet fruit, nicely carbonated. Alcohol is well balanced within the beer. Another tasty Unibroue product. Thanks Canada!

Pours is yellow with small off white head. The nose is yeast and fruit (white grape and berry). The taste is belgian yeast, fruits (similar to the nose), and some spice. Palate is thin to moderate. A great Tripel.

Pours clear yellow with a white head. The aroma is yeasty with some fruity characters. he taste is lots of fruit with Belgian yeast. You get a little bit of alcohol as well. The fruit is apples and white grapes as well as possibly some citrus. Thin bodied and medium to high carbonation. Finishes very dry.

12oz. Bottle from VBM in Buffalo. Pours a bubbly, cloudy yellowish orange body with a huge, long lasting white head. Aroma is full of yeast, banana, malts with a slight sweet background. Flavor is a great balance of spices and sweet malts, again yeasty. Full bodied, sweet finish. Long lasting, easy drinking beer with almost no sign of 9%ABV. Good Tripel

Poured into a snifter a murky light orange with a thin white head.  Had this back to back with St. Bernardus tripel and liked this better.  Nicer citrusy sweet aroma, spicy full bodied taste with subtle but pleasant alcohol notes and a great finish that stays sweet.  Nice

Very complex strong belgian beer. Spicy and sweet throughout. A tad too sweet for my liking, but it doesnt stop me from realising that this is a fantastic beer. Ripe fruits all over. I strongly recommend anyone to get a hold of it.
Mild, subtle, sweet and remarkably satisfying. Nice undertone of cittus. Strong but not overwhelming.

Pours out a cloudy yellow with a decent white head. Aroma is fruity and the taste is the same, and some spices are present. Very smooth mouthfeel and easy drinking. The 9% alcohol is very well masked.

Poured from a 12oz. bottle into a small wine glass.

The color is a clear gold with a slight white head that disapeared quickly. No lacing.

The smell is pretty darn fruity with a nice white grape flavor and sweet green apple flavor.

The taste is again fruity with a nice bubbly sweet taste. A grape flavor is nice with a great green apple flavor and a slight hop bitterness on the back end.

The feel of this beer is really light and quite enjoyable. It has a nice ammount of carbonation that is really pleasant and gives each sip a fizzieness that lightens the feel of this beer.

A - Citrus with hints of banana
A - Orange and a touch hazy
T - Alcohol with a slight sweet middle and bitter finish
P - Soft, but ample carbonation
O - One of those beers I like, but cant figure out why. I enjoy it.

Bottle.  Pours a hazy orange body with an off white head.  Sweet with a light coriander sweet citrus warming, some pear and appleish tones but not ox-notes.  Spicy yeast character with some earth and herbal tones.  A modest warming to finish.  Great stuff.
"The end of the world. The excellence of triple fermentation through a blend of special yeasts gives this malt beverage an exquisitely robust flavor of exceptional refinement."

Pours hazy orange with a big foamy white head. Very strong aroma- yeast, orange, honey, bready malt. Taste is more bitter but still sweet with roast malt. Very high carbonation initially, gets thinner and flavor is more bold after sitting for a while. Medium body slight alcohol warming finish.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2012 Ive enjoyed this triple ever since it was available in California. Its one of the best ones of the style. And, its one of the least expensive! In Redding, California, its available at Cost Plus world market. (Rated on Friday, December 25, 2009) UPDATE: August 27, 2012. Its also available at BevMo, Liquor Barn, Tops Supermarkets, and Holiday Foods. Go enjoy this one!!

A wonderful golden, cloudy appearance with a small head.  A most amazing nose of toasted, biscuit malts,  citrus hops and barnyard aromas.  Lively carbonation and a smooth texture make for a nice palate.  Bold and complex, this is one of the best beers Ive had.
Lighter color, not clear. Light amber. Not very hoppy, nutty. Has the aftertaste I am looking for.

Poors cloudy orange, with one-finger of white head. Aroma is fruit and spice and unfiltered yeast.  Mouth feel is effervescent and complex.  Wonderful.  Starts with citrus and spice, with subtlety sour yeast and tart lemon.  Excellent Tripel.

This beer is orange with a white, fluffy head that literally lasts for over an hour.  Theres the aroma of citrus, yeast, and spices, and the taste is spicy and of citrus with plenty of carbonation on the tongue.  I enjoyed this beer more as it got warmer.

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2010 opq-gl, ^eff, thin-wh-head, med-body, ^co2.

^fruity apple-tart aroma.
citrus §tart-apple T1 spicey fruity §malty dry-musty T2 sweet alchl-warm T3.
simple, seems like less-apple more-alchl version of Ephemere.
sweet and clean and full, carmel notes as well as strong malts, full flavor, very good
UPDATED: JAN 21, 2011 Bottle. Pours golden with a big head that dissipates slowly and leaves plenty of lacing. Taste is sugar, lemon, spice. Yum
750 mL bottle. Hazy golden pour with medium white head. Buttery lemon aroma. Tastes like a carbonated lemon Christmas cookie. I like it.

33 cl bottle, Fargo, ND, USA via Winnipeg. Cant believe I hadnt rated this yet. Slightly hazy pale golden colour, energetic carbonation culminating in a frothy uneven head. Citrus and bread aroma; smooth tight carbonation on the first sip with some sweet/alcohol dominating. Bread and earthiness, satisfying warming finish.
Yellow pour with suspended particulate. Potent and very flavorful. Dry finish with a defined hop flavor.

A: Cloudy yellow in color with a medium head that fades down to a ring around the edge with a pad on top.

S: Lots of aroma here. Tons of malty yeasty sweetness, with bubble gum, clove, banana and tart apples leading the way.

T: Very easy drinking brew for the ABV. Starts off with the nice yeasty sweetness that was apparent in the aroma. I taste candy sugar, lemon rind, and it finishes with the tartness of fresh green Granny Smith Apples.

M: Medium bodied, yet light. Very smooth drinking beer.

it pours a clear pale gold producing a nice white head that was kind of bubbly and fell on the fast side.  the body is a hazy gold with a lot of bubbles rising up on the sides of the glass.  the aromas are pretty sharp with some citrus, almonds, white grapes and green apples.  it is pretty fruity in the nose.  it is medium bodied with a bitter yet sweet aftertaste.  it is sweet on the tip of the tongue and some what fruity yet light.  i taste some bitter fruits, sugar, unsweetened apple juice,   and some light nuts.  the aftertaste is dry and is short lived.

Bottle. Cloudy light amber with big head. Some lace. Very yeasty aroma, with some spice and banana and apple scent. Beautiful mouthfeel. This beer feels alive. Malt is sweet and fruity, with some spice, citrus, banana and apple flavours.  Not a hoppy beer. 9% Alcohol is masked very well. Wonderfully complex and beautiful beer.

Bottle at fondue dinner. Pours a hazy gold with small off white head. Yeast and bread aroma mixes well on top of sweet spices. Yeast and grains dominate with light flavors of fruit at the end. A bit of alcohol presence as well. Refreshing and crisp.

Hazy yellow color with a rather big ivory-colored head that stays on for a while and leaves a nice lid of lacings.

A fine-tuned smell, complex with every piece at its place. Some gentle clove-like spices mix with pleasant fruit aromas of mostly tangerines and lemon peel. The wheat and fragile malts provide a nice clean background. Quite a lot of phenols and some alcohol. When tripels showcase smells like this, they are really great. Clean, refreshing and complex. Well balanced. (As a note, you could almost feel the gas in the nose from the carbonation in this one).

In the mouth, gentle spices (mostly cloves) and fruit esters of tangerine, pear and lemon peel lead the way to a nice semi-sharp malt and wheat character. Its a kind of sweet taste, but the spices act as a good counterweight. Bread crumbs, grass and a mild taste of earthy yeast. The wheat gets a little more pronounced towards the end, resulting in that semi-tart taste sometimes noticeable in wheaty beers. The finish holds some notes of herbal alcohol, phenols, a gentle spicy hop bite and bitterness and lingering fruity notes. In general, a complex and well balanced taste.

Moderate body, nice slick mouthfeel with a generous amount of lively carbonation.

Tripels are probably my least favorite style of the high ABV Belgian styles, but I think I can go as far as saying that this is one of the best tripels Ive ever had. Complex and balanced, yet with plenty of that Belgian edginess. This one is really easy to drink, but deserves to be sipped and savored at a gentle pace.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)

Best Before 04-24-11

Pours a slightly hazy, golden orange color. One-finger head of loose white foam. Leaves a light frothy covering. Lacing is spotty and somewhat slick.

Nice banana and citrus notes come on strong. Pears, apples, oranges and peaches. Nice spiced presence, also. Corriander and hints of clove. Very inviting belgian yeast profile. Slight presence of phenols. Light barnyard funk.
This is the nose of an excellent Belgian Tripel.

Sweet fruitiness opens this one. Apples, bananas and citrus flavors. This is quickly balanced by a nice smooth spiciness. Light pepper and cloves. Nice medium malt profile. Great belgian yeast presence. 
Very nicely balanced.

As a Tripel should be, this is one smooth and creamy brew. Highly carbonated, with lots of tiny little bubbles. It feels so good in your mouth, you almost dont want to swallow it. Just let it sit there, for a while, and enjoy it.

Very tasty, smooth, and quite drinkable. It hides the 9%abv so well. I cant even tell that its there. Im betting that it will sneak up on you, though. Be careful with this one.

Bottle/tulip glass. The beer has a transparent gold color with a fluffy white head with plenty of carbonation apparent from the bubbles. For being triple-fermented, the aroma was light on alcohol and heavy on yeast, spice, hand fruit, and banana. The taste is both sweet and sour with a fruity linger on the palate. Definitely worth a try.

(Bottle poured into Trappist glass)  Poured a beautiful golden color with small creamy head that faded fast.  Aroma provided a good deal of sweet notes, most notable a strong fruit and flowery hint.  Full bodied, the drink was very smooth with a very average carbonation -- there was just enough here!  Overall the flavor did not disappoint in the sweet department, but it was not overly sweet.  A great compliment to the hearty stew I had it with!  This is one to go back to over and over again!

Bottled poured into a tulip.  ULFDM pours nice and light like grapefruit juice with a wonderful white head fluffy head.  This is a beautiful beer.  The nose contains hints of peaches, alcohol, canned cherries and a lager-like hint of mineral water.  The body is light but viscous with a nice amount of carbonation.  The taste is refreshing and reminds me of a watered down grapefruit juice concoction.

This beer is intimidating in its bottle. Triple fermentation! Ive been eyeing this one for a while every time i was at the super market. Pours with plenty of carbonation in a cloudy brown haze. Aroma have hints of clove and banana. starts off bubbly and for a while i was thinking that i was drinking cider. slight hints of fresh wood and fruity tones. Complex and grainy as the wonderful laxer is swooshed around my mouth.  The alcohol warms the throat making this beer a great slow sipping beer. This one will be purchase for special occasions.

Bottle. Pours  slightly cloudy light gold with a thick white head that slowly dissipates. Aroma is full of fruit notes with banana, apple, peaches and sweet yeast notes as well. Flavor has similar notes, it begins a bet tart but sweetness quickly takes over. Nice and light on the tongue.
Pours a cloudy gold with a thick white head.  Heavy carbonation.  Aroma is musky.  Tastes great.  Very good beer.

Bottle.  Pours a hazy gold with a  thick white head.  A little grainy at first, but opening up into some light pear, caramel, and hay notes.  A faint light sourness at the start, more of a crisp acidity really.  Honey, hay, and light fruit.  Finishes dry and a bit sweet.  The abv on here is hidden quite well.
Cloudy gold color.  Citrus and spice flavors with a champagne-like flavor as well.  Well-made and quite enjoyable.
golden pour, tons of fluffy white head...great yeast and spice character...nice amount of malt sweetness

750-ml bottle Marcellos, Lafayette, LA - Aroma: orange, banana, lemon, spicey (ester); Appearance: hazy, pale golden, off-white head (disappears quickly), no laces; Flavor: sweet, salty (malt), orange, lemon, peppery (yeast), soft alcohol; Mouthfeel: light to medium bodied, slight creamy; Overall: nice balance of spicy, fruity, and alcohol aroma, and flavored beer. However, disappointing carbonation and head.
Great tasting beer.  Tried in a bottle at Knoxville, TN Brewers Jam.  Hazy, golden color with medium.  Spicy flavor with great finish.

Lovely yeasty Belgian aromas with chunky biscuit and lemony freshness.  Robust and tasty though it disguises its high ABV very well. Super relaxed and soft in the mouth with bready lightness and zingy citrus. The ABV comes up late in the throat with a light burn and delicious warming effect.  Not hugely deep and a bit stale overall to be honest.
Considering how alcohol-y most Unibroue beers are, this one is pretty smooth.  Funky with some fruit notes.

surprisingly light and citrusy on the nose. orange pour with frothy white head. The nose of this beer is absolutely amazingpossibly some weet citrus as well. taste of slight slcohol....citrus, spice....absolutely delicious. crisp and clean. refreshing on the palate.

I used to love this beer. Ever since the buyout by Sapporo this beers quality has declined. Which is a real shame. The flavour has changed. Also the sediment in the bottle is different. Seems artifical compared to the home made appearance it had before.  The cork does not have the pressure it used to when uncorking. Ive been drinking this beer since around 97. Im sad to say its not what it once was. Still better than alot of beer on the market but no longer great.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2010 Banana, clove and just a touch of vanilla in the aroma. Also a must note, which only shows in the initial smell. Pours a lovely champagne-like golden. Flavor is bursting with fruit notes - but not much burn. Much smoother than most Tripels.

A gret big strong heady smell of wheat and yeast assaults your nostrils. Hazy and almost coppery with reddish-gold and enough particulates to block clarity. Big bold taste of malt and unibroue yeast with notes of fruit and just a bit of alcohal taste. A very intoxicating bouquet of aroma, flavour and palate, this is almost like a champagne of beers.

Bottle.  Pours a hazy golden yellow with a foamy white head.  Aroma of spice, coriander.  Flavor is slightly malty and fairly spicy.  The warmth of alcohol can be felt when drinking.  This beer is definitely unique and worth a try.

Had this one awhile back in a bottle at Taco Mac. The best tripel Ive had next to Golden Monkey. Nicely spiced and well hopped. Also has that X factor from all the extra fermentation and special yeast strains. Would have to rate at the time of drinking for a proper review.

Brown bottle, 750 ml, purchased at IGA on October 24, savoured on October 25 2009; eye: golden, turbid, good effervescence, voluminous white head made up of rather large bubbles and that turns into a sheet, light lacing; nose: Belgian yeast, coriander, malt, orange zest; mouth: Belgian yeast, coriander, malt, orange zest, alcohol, pepper, alcohol warmth, finale in yeast-malt with presence of alcohol, full body, average carbonation, lightly sweet, slightly bitter, foamy texture; overall: quite good

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 750 ml, achetée chez IGA le 24 octobre 2009, savourée le 25 octobre 2009; il : dorée, trouble, bonne effervescence, mousse blanche abondante formée de bulles plutôt grosses qui se transforme en une couverture, légère dentelle; nez : levure belge, coriandre, malt, zeste dorange; bouche : levure belge, coriandre, malt, zeste dorange, alcool, poivre, chaleur dalcool, finale en levure-malt avec présence dalcool, corsé, carbonatation moyenne, légèrement sucrée, très légèrement amère, texture mousseuse; en résumé : bien bon
UPDATED: FEB 19, 2010 750ml pours a cloudy orange with a decent head.  Sweet aroma with a pleasant citrus taste. An outstanding beer.
smells like cheese, alcohol. its almost opaque hazy with a giant head that wont disappear. taste is funky, grainy, sour, feels oily, thick, pretty cool
One of my favorite beers.  Golden orange pour from 12oz bottle.  Citrus, spices and a nice balance of yeast.  9%abv gives it just enough kick without being overpowering.  Excellent beer!
UPDATED: NOV 5, 2009 Flavor mostly fruity and spicy with some alcohol. Pours a frothy white head and orange color.
A really nice beer, very unexpected in the pub i was in, malty but with a very good hop balance, great beer in october when its just a little cooler than normal.

Pours a hazy orange with a small white head that dissolved rather quickly. The aroma is on the sweet side with clove, banana, and light spices. The flavor is similar with some noticeable alcohol. The mouthfeel is creamy and frothy with some prickly carbonation. Has a slightly warm, crisp finish. Not bad, but I think its a bit past its prime.

Cloudy yellow-orange with a light-medium white head.  Aroma of yeast and citrus.  Flavor is distinctly sweet and bitter with some alcohol in the finish.  The sweetness comes on a little too strong, leaving a briefly cloying taste at the end.  Decent, but not among my favorite tripels.

Golden brown with an off-white head. Tasted notes of young white grapefruit, a mild floral arrangement, and light hops. Highly drinkable, but definitely not abrasive considering the high ABV. Great beer!

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2011 750mL bottle - pours a sharp golden into chalice. Very complex tripel, with lots of yeast, citrus, and some dry champagne-like qualities. One of my all-time favourites. Unibroue has brewed an amazing one here.

750 ml bottle from LCBO, served cold in a tulip glass. Often consumed before this rating.
App.:  Cloudy deep golden with a good tight white foam.
  
Aroma:  Earthy citrus, more fruity citrus, strong yeast and bread dough, lightly perfumed, sweet honey, some banana esters, some biscuit and toast, other, non-citrus fruitiness.
  
Palate:  Medium+ body, fairly full, fine effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Quite a bit like the nose, lots of citrus notes, some nice coriander, a bit more of the malts with more biscuit and toast, still some floral honey, yeast/dough are less present; fairly sweet with a touch of alcohol and light fruitiness to finish. 

A very lovely Tripel.

Wow. Smells of orange peel and amazingness. This brew has a golden cloudy color. Tastes of clove, banana, citrus, and a taste of the heavens. Active carbonation and tantalizing on the palate. All in all this is a great abbey tripel that is easy to drink and available at many stores.

Bottle. Golden/orange color, white head that didn´t last for a long time.

A lot of warming alcohol on the fellow. Yeast, grape, perfume, malt, honey, a nice mild acidity. Well balanced. A very good beer!

Bottle.  Pours golden-orange with ample, fizzy, lasting champagne head.  Aroma is sweet and tart at once, like oranges, grapefruits, and lemons all squeezed together. It almost reminded be of a sour ale when I first popped it open.  Initial taste is sufficiently bitter, all malt and citrus notes.  Good, but a little out of balance?  I agree with the rater who posted about there being a somewhat medicinal quality.  Its definitely there, but I think its just the high ABV occasionally peeking through.  Not a bad beer.  Definitely nice for a cooler night here in San Diego.

Bottle. 
Strong citrus in the nose, particularly grapefruit. Yeasty flavor with honey and citrus, slightly somewhat medicinal and a bit too sweet but decent enough for a new world tripel.
Electric orange, maybe in color, with a thin white head, lots of fruit in the aroma and taste, well balanced malt sweetness, good banana and spice notes on the palate.  A real pleasant surprise.

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2015 Wow. For someone who doesnt normally appreciate this style I was very surprised by this. Lots of apricot, apple and other fresh fruits on the tongue. Very complex. The only thing that i could say badly about it was that it was a bit over carbonated and felt a bit spritzy in the mouth. Otherwise fantastic.

I find this beer too sharp on the alcohol and too short on the flavour.  Nose is alcohol and malt.  Taste is yeast, malt and alcohol.  There is a fair bite to the alcohol and a lot of the fruitiness doesnt come through as it should.

Enjoyed from a 12oz bottle in an elongated tulip glass.  The beer pours the expected straw-colored yellowish/light golden color with a substantial and long-lasting fluffy white head.  The nose brings characters of tropical fruits and a touch of just-barely grainy pilsner malt.  The palate is relatively light on the palate, belying the beers strength.  I got strong notes of passion fruit/pearish esters, a nice level of malt complexity that alternated between pilsner grainyness and some deeper and more malty characters, and a high level of carbonation that helped to cleanse the palate.  Overall, very well crafted, and just short of the greatest examples of the style.
One of my faves for alltime. The variance from batch to batch is a little unnerving. Caramel and fruit, clean finish for any abbey, very little alcohol seems present.

750ml bottle. Pours a orange/yellow golden clear colour. Incredibly easy to drink. This is 9%? Seriously? No hint of the alc.% at all. Very solid beer all around. Definately a fruity taste to the after taste. Very nice beer.

12 oz bottle. Pours yellow with slightly bright amber tint.  White head that fades disappointing quickly. Funky Unibroue yeast and lots of Belgian sugar.  Orange and orange peel, but less lemon/apple/pear complexity than I hoped for. Some banana and clove.  Overall, though more sweet than tart or sour.  Finishes semi dry, but tasty.  Lovely soft palate.  I typically dont dig Unibroue yeast flavors too much, but this is one of the better ones.

Amber?  Did I have a different beer than the last two raters?  Mine was a fizzy straw yellow with a pillowy white head.

Fruity (banana?), yeasty, and musty aroma with a flavor of golden raisins and some orange peel.  Also a twist of typical belgian spices and a drying finish.  Light, effervescent, and not too heavy on the alcohol notes despite the ABV.

This is the first Unibroue beer Ive had that Ive actually liked!  Nice work.
Amber pour with white head.  Malty aroma, spices, and lemony citrus.  Flavor is semi sweet with malts, spices, and citrus.  Surprisingly dry finish.

750 mL bottle from Vons (good price at $5.99).  Pours a light prune-amber color with a finger and a half of white head.  Aroma of bready malts, musty yeast, pepper, and light citrus.  Flavor is lightly sweet with yeast, dusty malts, spices, and fruit (citrus, peach).  Light mouthfeel and dry finish with a hint of hoppy bitterness and light alcohol burn.
One of my faves. A complex swirl of sweet, spicy, fruity flavors that play off the palate.

Pours cloudy golden, with a lasting two-finger beige head, good lacing.  Aroma of citrus, biscuit, clove, banana and tobacco.  Medium body, tart, velvety and smooth.  Citrus and banana flavor, rich biscuit malt, clove and cardamom, and a note of straw.  Tart finish balances out the sweetness.

Bottle - Pours a hazy light yellow with a large white head. Spicy, Banana and yeasty aromas.  Sweet fruity flavour with a metalic hint.  Light bitter finish and a lingering flowery hop aftertaste.  Nice transition of the flavours from the first sip through to the finish.
Taste was good, but was overwhelmed by bad aroma and piss-poor almost burning aftertaste. Seems to be consistent with other Unibroue beers Ive had.

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2010 Bottle. Pours yellowish gold. Frothy white head, with great carbonation. Aroma of fruit, yeast, and a hint of spice. Body is firm, with a crisp finish. Fantastic tripel. 9/12/2009 Intial Rating: 4.

Re Rate: 
Bottle. 12 oz. Pours a hazy, dense orange with a one-finger, thick, creamy, white head. Insane amounts of sediment settles around the base of the glass. Aroma of dry grapes, yeast, candided sugar, lemon zest, sweet malts, and hints of banana and bubblegum. Fuller-medium bodied with a slightly spicy, sticky palate. Finishes with a nice burn and sweetness. Awesome tripel. Unibroue consistently delivers high-quality brews, they just need to get on with the new releases!

750ml bottle. Amber gold in colour with a frothy white foam cap that nestles on top. Citrus fruit and yeast aromas blend well together. Smooth and lively in the mouth, leaves a warm glow in the mouth . The longer it sits the better it gets.

This was one of the first brews I ever tried, and now Im just getting around to rating it. Pours a light orangeish yellow, with a large white head. The aroma has lots of yeast and light fruits, and some spiciness. Flavor has a lot of that yeast flavor as well, with a drier, spicier flavor up front - cardamom and coriander, moving into some sweeter fruits (peach, especially) on the finish. Nice, and better when you swirl a bit of the overly aggressive carbonation out, but feels a bit too heavy for what it seems like its going for.
The flavour is yeasty and spicy with a big bold taste. A little bit of alcohol as well. Very carbonated, but all round pretty good.

Bottle.  Strong fruity aromas, pours a very dark brown color.  The light tan head is thick and holds quite well.  There are flavors of spices, and a lot of yeasty malts.  Its a very good beer, the palate is a bit on the thin side for a beer this strong, but the alcohol is well hidden underneath the very smooth flavors.
Bottle, Flandres, Burgos. Cloudy amber colour, off-white head. Nose of fruits, spicy and yeast. Flavour is fruity, yeasty and malty. Sour and slightly bitter finish. Very nice.

750ml bottle. strong aroma of peaches when the bottle is first open, poured into a glass it gives off a very strong coriander smell. good cloudy color with a quickly collapsing head and much carbonation. coriander is still overpowering in the taste, but not as much as the aroma. has a bit of a bitter/sour towards the end and similar aftertaste, with the alcohol slightly burning the gums and the back of the throat as it slides down. a great beer, but too much coriander for my tastes.

Aroma is fruity, yeasty and lots of banana.  Taste is refreshing, light, fruity sweet, and little malt body.  There is a good complexity and palate to the drink.  Overall, a very enjoyable and evolving brew.
UPDATED: DEC 18, 2009 (bottle) hazy golden amber colour; lively carbonation; medium head; nose - lemon, apricot, bit of strawbery; flavour - sweetish, noticeable alcohol.

A bottle tasted at Silja Line. Mild slightly sour nose with some fruitiness. Slightly hazy golden yellow colour. Soft round fruity and slightly sweet taste. Mild hoppiness. Thin pale head. Sweet and spicey taste. Like belgian style.

Appearance: While Im used to a large fluffy head, this one poured with no head at all.  The body is a cloudy dark yellow gold.

Aroma:  Funky spicy fruity yeast. Its really pleasant, but I cant attribute it to a fruit or a flower.

Taste:  Fruity, spicy yeast and hops. Cloves, coriander and citrus rind are found as I further savor.

Mouthfeel: Thick and fizzy.

Overall:  A one of a kind, flavorful Belgian-style beer. Ive had this beer so many times, in different parts of the country, and its remained consistently good.
bottle, hazy orange-golden liquid, smells sweet and fruity, taste is very sweet and fruity. nice brew, though a bit too sweet

Bottle. Pours golden yellow with a frothy white head and good carbonation. Nose has citrus, banana, wheat and clove. Flavour is fairly similar, not overly sweet, with maybe a little more fruit and a little less grain. Palate is fizzy and smooth at the same time with a fairly long finish and a little lasting bitterness at the end. Overall a very good beer from the excellent Unibroue.

22-AUG-2009, bottle @Henriks.
Beautifull high white head on orangy colour.
