Yeasty nose with apricots and other fruits. Loads of fruits and spices, and then the wonderfull creaminess.
High, high carbonation, and yet very easy drinkability.
Best Tripel ever?

Pours a murky yellow with a nice finger of white froth. I have to comment on the insane carbonation, it looks like a fountain coming off of the etching in my Sam Adams Sensory glass. 

Smells of bread. Some citrus character but not hoppy citrus, more like orange peel? Very clovey.

Tastes very spicy, pretty dry on the finish. Orange ester is present again.

Mouth is extremely high carbonated, so much so that I had difficulty detecting the body, which is somewhere in the middle by the way.

Overall as far as tripels go I much prefer the St. Bernardus but even that is comparing apples to oranges, this is a very spicy example.

A respectable tripel...but lacking that typical licroice and wheat flavor and aroma.  Puours a golden color, with a touch of haze, but pretty clear.  White head of average size.  Flavor is on the sweet side, but is not cloying in any way.  An approachable tripel for those who arent wrapped up in what the style is supposed to tast like.  In other wrods, there were no strong wheat, alcohol or licorice flavors.  As with all Unibroue beers, extremely affordable!

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a golden yellow-brown with a full 1.5 inch head that dissipates quickly to a thin sparkly head.  Nose is faint, general citrus and acid.  Taste is complex, moving to a mix of lemon, clove, that dances in the mouth.  The triple fermentation is well worth it, as the taste lingers on my palate crisply.
This was a cloudy golden colour. It had an aroma of hops and wheat. It had a fruity taste with a hint of wheat.
This is such a refreshing beer, light and crisp with notes of ripened bananas and citrus.  I bet it would pair well with a white fleshed fish.

bottle thanks to boomer0813.  poured a hazy yellow with a white head that would not go away into the la fin du monde glass.  aroma was very upfront with banana, citrus, and clove.  the flavor was dominated by clove with citrus and banana shining through at the end.  i was drinking this while putting together my new grill in the heat of texas and found it rather refreshing.
Pours murky golden with a cream foam head. Yeast smell with light fruit notes. Spicy taste with well hidden alcohol , good carbonation. Very nice.

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2009 Bottle. Pale yellow pour with frothy white head and good lacing. Aromas of strawberries and bananas, unibroue yeast, coriander and cloves and alcohol. Taste is spicy-alcohol with banana yeast that lingers for a while. A beautiful beer, quebec pride.

Bottle.  Pours golden and cloudy with a big foaming head that settles into a thin persistent white band.  Banana dominates the aroma (not my favorite characteristic), but there is also some lemon, yeastiness, and even some alcohol.  The flavor is far more complex.  All the above flavors are there (still a bit too much banana for me), but there are lots of other interesting elements:  some spiciness (clove and lots of coriander), a little musty funkiness.  It starts a bit sweet and ends quite dry.  Very creamy on the tongue.  I can appreciate this, but its not my favorite set of flavors.
FCBF 09.  Pretty good tripel but a bit too spicy for my taste.  its very pleasant though with nice flavors of oranges and well integrated alcohol, a smooth body.
Had a bad day at work and this was a great beer!!!! Pours pale with white head. Complex aroma and the taste is just as complex and cleverly disguised the alcohol! Thank you Canada!

Draft.  Pours hazy golden orange with frothy off white head that hangs around for the ride.  Such a complex aroma and flavor, theres no way I can justify what this brings to the table.  Aroma of citrus, alcohol, spice, yeast, banana.  Flavor includes all of the above and then some bread and more that I need to put my finger on in later tastes.  The alcohol is definitely there but mostly hidden by the flavors.  Complex, tasty, and enjoyable- fun to drink and discuss, and even more fun once the 9% ABV catches up.

An intensely flavorful, complex beer. The flavor is intensely varied and youll note different flavors as you continue drinking and as it warms. Alcohol becomes more prevalent near the end of the glass. Otherwise, the typical flavors youd expect are here: spice, clove, some citrus notes. Also some darker fruit notes near the end. A very interesting Canadian tripel.
UPDATED: MAR 25, 2010 A simply fantastic beer... have had it many times and it is absolutely one of my favorite beers.  I would easily place it in my top 10.
UPDATED: NOV 15, 2009 Currently my favorite beer on the planet. Flavorful enough to make you forget the high alcohol volume and keep you drinking till the room starts spinning.

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2009 750ml bottle poured into a pint glass. Has a hazy yellow-orange color with a head with big bubbles that sticks around for a few minutes. Lots going on in the aroma but its surprisingly not overpowering: Spices, bananas, citrus, yeast and malty sweetness. So many different flavors hitting the tongue all at once its hard to distinguish them all: Sweet, malty, spicy, fruity sourness with a bit of an alcohol bite at the end. Has good carbonation and lots of malty creaminess to it. The complex flavors do a good job hiding the 9% ABV. By the time Im done the bottle Ill be felling it. First time I had one a few months ago, when I was starting to widen my tastes in beer,  I was thrown off by the taste so much that I couldnt finish it. Never had I tasted a beer so complex before. After trying it a few more times Ive learn to appreciate this brew quite a bit. Be warned, this is not a gateway beer for those new to craft.

This was a surprisingly wonderful beer.  The beer has a cloudy orange color and a citrus smell.  It is sweet, but not overly so.  Its so light and flavorful that youd hardly believe it has such a high alcohol content.

Beautiful cloudy orange beer that smells like citrus and spice...  Tastes more like spice than fruit and has some bite from the high ABV..  An amazing beer that would not have you believe its as strong as it is
Nice Tripel.  Pours a hazy golden-orange with nice frothy white head.  Typical of the style with plenty of spice, fruit and yeast in both the nose and flavor.  Good mouthfeel.  Very good Tripel.

UPDATED: AUG 7, 2009 Merci a Janvier de moffrir cette biere excellente. Bottle. 9%. Anglophones and francophones can unite in this glorious tasting beer. Pours a cloudy orange colour, with a frothy white foam. Aroma is yeasty, spiced with coriander, light citrus. Taste is absolutely superb. Delicious.

2 small bottles, in tulip glass.  Poured golden-orange with a little cloudiness.  Head frothy and effervescent, leaving some lacing on the glass.  Glorious smell, taste is quite overwhelming on first sip but further sampling gives rise to a very good yeasty, spicy triple.  Very enjoyable beer.

Golden straw, large fluffy head. Smell reminded me of a bakeshop i used to work in(go Cakewalkers!), yeasty, sweet spices, coriander, black pepper, baked bread, slight coconut?  Nice flavors, nice mouthfeel.  Very drinkable, light little bubbles. A happy drink. I believe this beer enjoys itself!
Bottle, pours a yellow golden orange beer with a massive head.  Aroma is fruit and yeast.  Just another tripel, very good though.
Bottle. Very solid tripel /trippel/triple how ever you want to spell it . Great flavor and aroma. My favorite so far from this brewer. Will have again and definitely worth a try.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a very hazy yellow orange with a huge, foamy white head.  Yeast, hay, dust, light lemon, and some earth in the nose.  High carbonation with a medium, slightly dry mouthfeel.  Orange, dust, boozy citrus fruit, a little candy sweetness, and dried apricot on the palate.  Very complex stuff.  Medium-short finish.  A little boozy, but it is quite delicious.  A pleasure to drink and certainly one I will get more of.

Pours a slightly hazy, golden body with an eggshell white head that has a fizzy ring and no lace.  Smells of dried fruit and yeast.  Flavor is spice, dried fruit, and yeast.  Fine carbonation in the mouth, like champagne.
One of the only examples of the belgian style available here. Overall Im quite impressed by it and I think Ill have another soon.
Very smooth drinking beer. I think I will be drinking more of this in the near future.
750 ml bottle. This beer is crisp and clean with a fruity, citrusy bouque. Very easy beer to drink for alcohol content. clean and refreshing. pour is golden with slight yeast haze.
Bottle.  Pours golden with thick white head.  Aroma of pepper, yeast, and pears.  Taste of  spices, bread, and yeast.  Easy drinking for 9%.  Not a huge fan of the style but this is good.

Poured from the large 750ml bottle (thanks, Unibroue!) in a rich, cloudy gold colour and an almost overwhelming foamy white head, that left some nice lacing.  Aroma was a tinge of yeast but mostly fruity.  Taste was strong yet fruity.  Id like more of this.

UPDATED: NOV 1, 2009 (12oz bottle) pours mostly clear dark yellow with 1 finger head that has lasting creamy bubbles.  Nose is complex, coriander, grass, Sweet malts, white pepper, and spices. Taste is white pepper, sweet malt well balanced with light hops. Finish is dry but quite creamy and well carbonated. A world-class tripel and given how much they produce makes it even more amazing how good it is.

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2009 Pours a beautiful hazy golden color with lots of fluffy white head, the aroma is of wheat, yeast, and a fruity bouquet. The taste is sweet and smooth, comprised of wheat and fruit (just as the aroma elluded to. Like all of the other Unibroue beers, I am extremely impressed, not my favorite style, but very good interpretation (improvement).

750 ml bottle.   This beer just tastes great.  Crisp and clean with a citrus carbonation.  Very easy beer to drink.  Unlike the stouts and hoppy IPAs this beer would have a very wide audience.  Most non beer drinkers would like this beer.

Original review date 10/1/2008...

750 corked & caged into Ommegang chalice...

Clean, thin 1/2-1-finger yeasty even head with a clear seam topping a cloudy, honey body with quick carbonation. Looks like a good Trippel - last pour heads up a lot more but goes quickly.

Telltale Tripel signs of bountiful coriander, a little clove and ginger and nice yeast character. Hardcore electricity and wheat-ish bite. Strength dissipates with warmth.

The spicy tone of this is extremely solid and electric...clean, yeasty profile with mild malt sweetness. Solid carbonation gives this a slight saltiness that blends well to make a clean-drinking experiment in Beautiful Chemistry.

A hearty, husky malt/yeast/wheat profile gives this an extremely solid woody backbone. The spicy sweetness is balanced with the ample carbonation to provide a greay palate tingle. This exhibits quintessential Tripel mouthfeel.

This drinks at a very responsible pace. Not quickly but not too slowly. Matters, as its a pleasure to enjoy. One of the best all-around offerings that has been given a "good look" in some time...

33cl bottle at Old Bank. Hazy golden to amber, small pale head. Ginger and spritzy cooked pear in the aroma, little acidic notes and minerals, faint sweet maple syrup. Flavor is warming alcohol, sweetish sugary feeling, minerals, pear, light gingerbread spiciness. Club soda feeling all over. Medium to full bodeid, strong mouthfilling carbonation. Pretty hollow tripel, way overrated.

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2009 In a bottle at Rattle N Hum (Midtown, NYC): The aroma gives off a sour, liquid bread feel. Tastes  of hops, "different types of yeast", a faint hint of citrus/orange peel, but most of all, chewy, liquid bread... with a tart kick. Love the fantasy label. Downright epic tasting, Belgium style beer. Makes me happy. #050 on 06072009, DG.

Bottle (750 mL). Poured with a large, off-white head that eventually diminished to about one-finger size. Body was hazy, with light particles, and a dark yellow color. Lacing was fair. Very nice aroma... average yeast, some fruitiness as well. Great on the palate... full body, creamy, with lively carbonation. You can taste light alcohol, but its not overwhelming at all. The fruit comes through again, and stays with you for a good amount of time. Delicious. A fantastic tripel; Im very happy Unibroue is here in Canada to provide us with authentic-tasting Belgium brews.
golden pour with a nice offwhite head.  Fruity, yeasty aroma with some honey and booze.  Nice flavor, tangy and yeasty, typical Unibroue.  Warming finish of sweet booze

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2009 THIS BEER CHALLENGED ME, I BOUGHT IT OUT OF CURIOUSITY NOT KNOWING WHAT TO EXPECT. I POURDED IT INTO THE GLASS THAT WAS RECOMENDED ON THE BOTTLE AND I WAS TRULY AMAZED BY THE COLOR, (CLOUDY RUSTY GOLDEN) THE AMOUNT OF THICK FOAMY HEAD AND MOSTLY THE ABUNDANCE OF CARBONATION . WHEN I TASTED IT, I DIDNT KNOW WHAT TO THINK, I DONT LOVE IT AND I DONT HATE IT BUT I DEFINATELY FEEL CHALLENGED BY THE FLAVOR IT IS A  FAMILIAR TASTE  WHICH I HAVE YET TO PUT MY FINGER ON I THINK IT MAY BE CARROT, SWEET POTATOES ,YAMS OR SOME SORT OF ROOT VEGETABLES? (ACTUALLY I AM CERTAIN) VERY ODD GOOD BEER TO PAIR WITH FINE CUISINE , ALTHOUGH IT MAY NOT BE SO GOOD FOR CHILLING WITH YOUR PEEPS AND THROWING DOWN A FEW.
Drank these to death once upon a time. Great fluffy head, fruity aromas, nice complex taste of citrus, grains, and more fruity notes. Excellent stuff.

UPDATED: JUL 17, 2012 pours a clear golden color. Very clean, fruity and citrus-y. Nice, sufficient level of carbonation. Maybe a little bit of clove and spice with some hops

Bottle from tjs
Poured into Duvel tulip.  Tons of head.  Smells yeasty and fruity.  Citrusy flavor and somewhat sweet.  One of the best tripels around.

Pours a clear golden color with a massive head. Aroma is fruity, yeasty & sour. The mouthfeel is very carbonated almost similar to champagne. The taste is lightly fruity & almost tastes like sour apples.

750ml bottle from BevMo.  Pours a hazy honey color with one finger creamy head. Nose is cloves, yeast and fruit bubblegum. Taste is tangy citrus, spicy Belgian yeast and a souring finish that fades into sweet fruits again. Medium mouth feel. An easier drinker but quite warming at 9%.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2017 re-rate 12/16 and 1/17....4 pack due to prev. rating.  lowered some.  good, not great...........................................I just had a booklyn #1 last night and these 2 are very close; this might be slightly better but its damn close.

cloudy golden pour (12oz btle) with small head; NO alcohol taste or pepper like #1; very smooth and sweeter finish than #1.  very crisp finish also.

thats as good as I have had

When I tried this beer it was the best beer I had ever tried, it has since been superceded by some excellent imperial stouts and trappists, but it is still a great beer. Characteristically yeasty taste from Unibroue, and very nice and spicy. Despite the high alcohol content, it is not overly boozy. A brilliant orange colour.
My favorite all time beer!  I love Unibroue.  About 10 years ago I was introduced to their beers and I fell in love.  Not like a mother loves her child...its much more than this.

One of my favorites.  A golden color with a robust head, a little hazy; has a powerful nose of sweet fruits and citrus; flavors of grain, orange, spices, and yeast.  Finish is sweet and complex.  Excellent.
Pours a hazy golden color with a nice white head.  Aroma of fruity malts.  Flavors of citrus malts and spices. A little sweet sour ending.  A very good strong taste of a good triple.

Pours a pale gold with thick white head that dissipates quickly, but a lot of carbonation sticks around, minimal lacing though.  Aroma of citrus, wheat, spices, and a lot of yeast.  Flavor matches well, a solid belgian with a quite a bit of tartness, alcohol, and a lot of yeast.  Not something I would pick up very often, but definitely drinkable.

Orange-yellow pour.  Nice big head  cream white.  Fruity, but with a perfect spice involved.  Tastes like bread, citrus fruit + a good spice.  Exactly the spice you look for with a tripel  not overpowering, but enough bite.  Tons of yeast in the bottom of the bottle.  One of my favorite beersdelicious.

Very strong yeast flavor.  Poured from a bottle, and seemed kind of flat, very little head, no residue on the sides of the glass.  Color was a sickly between-amber-and-yellow.  Flavor was strong and yeast/wheaty, very much like a German Heffe-Weizen.  The beer also had a sharp bite and alcoholic aroma.  Overall good, not great.

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2009 750 mL bottle from Total Wine (best before 02-27-2011).  Golden yellowish-orange pour with a fizzy white head.  Aroma of bread, yeast, and light citrus.  Seems like Im being lazy but the taste is the same.  This is a very solid Belgian-style Tripel and very few are better...I had an older bottle of this beer last night (the best before date was 10/24/2009) and I must say it is better with a little less age.  There was some apple and pear that I detected that I do not remember from my initial tasting but overall I enjoyed this more when it was fresh.

Murky light orange brown brew. The pour produced a huge white rocky head with ok retention and a decent ammount of lacing. Huge HUGE amount of sediment. Pored it all in later on and the holes in the crown allowed the light to penetrate the murk like the sun breaking through the clouds. The aroma is musty, orange (barely there), cloves, cooked meat and strong overall. The taste is orange, light yeast, lots of spice and a bit tangy. Fruity too. Excellent flavour. My favourite Unibroue beer. The mouthfeel is very smooth, a bit dry and finishes with a nice bitterness. Medium to full bodied. Good stuff!

"Body looks to be a honey brown or maybe burnt gold the small but dense cap just wont go away and being constantly replenished by lots of bubbly carbonation, the body is very hazy with sand like sediment resting at the bottom of the glass. Strong aggressive aroma, wheat and yeast dominate with notes of caramel, and spices (probly cloves) the sent is a touch sour but very complex and yummy. The flavor is not as intense as the aroma but still very ample, alcohol is noticeable but blends nicely with the wheaty tasting malts, Im getting some citrus notes in the finish. This stuff has tons of flavor wheat, yeast, spice all blending together for a sweet smooth beer. Mouth feel is spectacular smooth full excellent carbonation and has a clean finish. High quality brew tasty and smooth, this was one of the very first high quality craft brews I ever had back in the day and its is just as good now as it was then."

Bottle. Pours a hazy, pale orange, thick, long-lasting white head, soapy lacing. Aroma is yeast and sweet fruit (tangerine, grapes and orange). Sweet fruit (same as above) and the ever present Unibroue yeast signature dominate the flavor profile, some very subtle spice notes (coriander, maybe clove ?). Finish is dry and yeasty.

Pours a hazy golden/orange with sizeable white head.  Very fruity aroma, lots of carbonation, spices, yeast evident.  Slight bit of alcohol comes through in the finish, which is moderately dry.  Good offering from Unibrou, but to me is does not fit the "Abbey Tripel" style.  More like a fruity version of a Duvel.

UPDATED: FEB 10, 2015 Golden pour, lots of yeast particles. Large, persistent, white head.
Aroma is mostly belgian doughy yeast and some spicy phenols. Classic Unibroue basically. Subtle alcohol, citrus, banana and herbal hops also present.
Flavour is more of the Unibroue doughy yeast, mild grassy hops and a hint of citrus. Some soft booze in the finish.
Carbonation seems a little excessive, flavours definitely open up once its died down a little.

Pretty good tripel but a bit too spicy for my taste, that combined with the Unibroue house yeast character makes it somewhat hard to drink. Other wise its very pleasant though with nice flavours of oranges and well integrated alcohol, a smooth body and a sexy look.

12 oz bottle.  Big malts, yeast, and a hint of alcohol in the aroma as expected.  Pretty nice aroma overall though, with more specifically pale grain malts, yeasty butter crackers, a slightly mix of grain and vinous alcohol, some herbal hop qualities and some other light spices.  Pour was nice, though not over-the-top like others of the style can be, with a wispy milk white head, good retention and lacing, cloudy body and orange gold in color.  No real surprises in the drinking of this beer either, but this isnt necessarily  a bad thing when beers actually live up to your exact expectations.  But anyway, medium body, a good tripel bite to it, and very good balance.  Flavor is a good combination of Belgian blonde pale malts, a nice herbal grass bitterness that spreads and balances the whole way through, minor citrus orange, yeasty crackers and popcorn, and some various savory spices.  So even though its really nothing too mind-blowing, it is still a very nice Belgian style ale.

Incredible beer from Unibroue.

When you live in a state with backwards liquor laws like PA, and you have to buy cases of beer, because the nearest bottle shop is either across state lines or over an hour drive, its beers like this that make you happy duriing "blind buys".

The tripel smell is present here, notes of honey/sugar and cloves are very present on it.

Pour is a nice hazy tripel yellow with a nice foam head. 

Tastes : Delicious. Very good version of a tripel, refreshingly sweet. Has a great overall presentation, and a fantastic aftertaste. 

This is one beer that will always have a place in my home.
Pours a hazy golden with a nice foamy head. Aroma is yeasty and fruity, one could smell tripel. Sweet fruity flavor upfront with a lingering dry finish. Flavorful, complex, balanced excellent brew.
Sweetly stale citrusy aroma.  Cloudy orange-yellow appearance.  Light, crisp, citrus flavor without the syrupy taste of some tripels Ive tried.  Very nice, crisp and refreshing beverage.
Poured a hazy golden yellow with a nice fluffy white head. Aromas and flavors of sweet citrus, yeast and some spices. This is an excellent tripel.

Pours a hazy golden orange.  Fluffy off-white head reduces slowly.  Aroma is spicy, doughy, and a bit fruity.  Sweet and spicy flavor leads into tart fruit.  Carbonation is lively.  Texture is lightly viscous and coats the mouth.  Overall, strongly flavorful, complex, and pretty well balanced.

I really enjoy this beer.  This is the second time I have had it, and it was really delicious both times.  It poured a hazy yellow color with a light head.  It smelled very much like bread and slightly fruity.  It is a heavily carbonated beer that tastes sweet and slightly fruity.  Its very tasty, and I guess much like a proper Belgian.  Very tasty and I would purchase again!
Bomber. Really nice summertime beer if youre looking to get f-ed up. Strong, but easy-drinking and very clean on the palate. Doughy, citrus, leaves the mouth clean. Nice stuff.

Pours medium golden, almost translucent, with a thickwhite had of both large and fine bubbles, dissipating into a nice thin rim of small bubbles.  Nose is very fruity, light fruits and some tropical qualities as well, and some yeasty esters are present also.  Palate is very sweet and fruity, some soft malt in there, very carbonated and prickly, and white pepper too.

Pours a hazy golden yellow with a fluffy white head. A sweet ripe fruit nose. Flavor is fruity malty and sweet. Medium body. Finishes with a little spice, very very light hops, and some sour notes on the tounge. An overall sweet flavored beer, with a good amount of alcohol content.
pours hazy orangeish gold color with a nice frothy head.  smells like orange, clove, and yeast. tastes fruitty, sweet, and balanced well with the yeast.  very good

Hazy golden-blond color, with huge booming faomy white head that stirried down. Yeasty, bread notes on the nose as well as bananas and some citrus scents. Rounded, full-bodied with yeasty flavors, liight citrus notes; grassy with a spicey clovieness. A very nice beer indeed. This has been one of my favorite triples.
12 oz bottle pours to nice orange body...very little head.  Taste is nice, nothing spectacular but a good tripel.  Reasonably priced so worth a try
23 oz bottle. Excellent, easy drinking Tripel. Nice carbonation and not overly spicy. Be careful though, at 9% it will get you.

At the World Beer Festibal in Raleigh NC this excellent tripel pours a dark cloudy yellow with lots of head.  Aroma of yeast, fruit, wheat and spices.  The flavor is everything you would expect from this outstanding beer - spicy, malty, yeasty.  You wont go wrong with this one.

Surpisingly, I have not tried too many Unibroue beers, but after enjoying this one, I will be trying them all.  This Tripel is cloudy and the aroma is of spice and yeast.  The flavors are bread, fruit, yeast and a small presence of spicy hoppiness.  I am very impressed by this Belgian style beer.  It is rare to get a beer of this syle outside of Belgium to taste authentic, and actually be as good or better than their Tripels.  A very impressive beer.  I now need to try Allagash to see how good they are.

Pours a hazy/wheaty pils color with less head than is usually expected from Unibroue beers. Reminds me quite a bit of their Don de Deue, but less smooth. There is much more spice and less wheat present here. Some rose/bubblegum/clove/banana in the aroma. Taste is very dry and spicy, but not overwhelmingly so.

12 oz. bottle poured into a tulip. Floral, citrus hops, bread yeast aroma. Gold color, very fizzy appearance. Thick white lingering head lasted the whole glass. Lightly sweet, med-light sour, light bitterness. Medium bodied, cream-like texture, fizzy carbonation, long sour finish. A great Belgian-style!

The first time I tried this beer, I thought it was a rather boring Belgian style blonde beer. This time though, I loved it. Full of flavour, rich and superbly made. Almost perfect. It shows the foolishness of those who review a beer the first time that they try it. Absurd! Madness! No true beer lover would ever do that.

VINTAGE 5 years old. Bought in Dole, France. [Bottle @ Odense Tasting, 14th February 2009, remembered for Carsten BeerMouths fantastic 3 meals highend gastronomy.] Although its long time Ive tasted these brewdrops I remember it as a fantastic olded one with oldfreshed fruits. One of my best triples ever!

Very nice color. Orange tint, a little cloudy with very little foam head to it. Definitly a little fruit in there, like apricots and a possibly a little orange. Hits your tounge with a full punch. So far a very relaxing and enjoyable beer.

Gah. Drain pour. This is the second, and probably last, beer Ill try from Unibroue. Rotten funky, fishy dishwatery gym sock beer. After drinking maybe half a bottle of the similarly nasty Pistoles, I didnt even bother with a second swallow of this one. Yuck.

33cl bottle.
cloudy yellow, thick white head.
acid/sour/citrussy/floral aroma resembling a very good witbier. also a little spices. aroma is very enticing, very refreshing and makes you think that no matter what, a 9%er cannot live up to this kind of freshness..
but it can.
flavor is strong, citrussy, spicy, "belgian blonde" like, yellow fruits, faint banana, lemon, lime, a little bitterness. this style doesnt get much better.

The  best tripel that Ive ever had.  Bread and apricots on the nose.  The perfect carbonation for the style lends greatly to the balance of the dryness and the soft supple body of the beer.  The flavor is yeast, raw barley,  and grassy exquisiteness. Thank You Unibroue.  2009 12 oz.

330 ml bottle. Hazy amber colour. Medium-sized white head that clings to the glass. Aroma is fruity with hints of oxidation and acetaldehyde. Ripe apples. Orange peel. Unlike most other tripels the yeast does not dominate. Nicely balanced flavour. Fruity and definitely on the complex side for a tripel. Some bitterness, but the hops meld nicely with the fruity esters. A classic.

12 oz bottle.  I passed on the large bottle with the cork in it.  I bought the 4-pack for nearly $10.  Poured into my favorite tulip snifter.  Poured a hazy gold with a fluffy, persistent head.  Nose is of fruity resin.  Lots of promise in the nose.  The flavor carries the promise to fruition.  Delightfully sweet tripel with the fruit on the tongue and the yeast in the finish.  Light tingle of alcohol lets you know that this is no ordinary drink.  Sipped it for an hour.  Savoring every drop.  Super offering from Unibroue.
Great desert beer. Great delivery of a sweet beer, not overpoweringly so. I will try another tonight, and start my evening with it.

pours hazy yellow with a good sized white head. aroma is fruity- banana, citrus, green melon, spices, and malts. drinks sweet and very fruity with a gritty yeast effect that i think compliments the viscosity of it. finishes dry, almost wine like with a yeasty after taste. very tasty!

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a hazy gold with a thin but frothy head.  Mmmm...yeasty.  Lots of fruit - citrus and banana - and spice in both the aroma and flavor.  The formidable alcohol content only registers as a warming in the gullet upon the finish.  Such a stellar Belgian-esque beer for both the price and availability

At 9.79 a 4 pack, La Fin Du Monde is a bargain. Thats as much beer as two 750mls of Westmalle tripel, but less than half the price. And I think it would be held in higher esteem by bierdos if it wasnt so ubiquitous. Anyway, its as sweet, fruity, and yeasty as you would expect from a tripel but with a spritzier mouthfeel and a sharp, dry aftertaste.

UPDATED: APR 11, 2009 341 mL Bottle. Murky gold body with a small but tenacious foamy head that kept the beers surface covered all the way to the last sip and coated the sides with very good lacing. The aroma is a bouquet of apricot, hints of banana and melons, spices, and the alcohol comes through with that 9-octane. The alcohol also comes through in the flavor, not in a way that assaults the senses but in a way that asserts: "Hey! My octane is 9, sip me like wine; dont guzzle me". Otherwise, the flavor is like a fruit salad in a bottle; apricot, peach, banana, green grapes, and plums followed by a citrusy aftertaste and a creamy-spicy finish. A great sipping beer for those tenacious wintry days that linger into the spring months.

The aroma is definitely with a yeasty, citrus, and slight alcohol aroma.  La Fin maintains an excellent full white head, over a cloudy golden color, finishing with a nice lace.  Its flavor is full of citrus, yeast, alcohol properties, and some spice.  The finish is smooth, a little too smooth, got me in a heap of trouble.  The carbonation is well balanced, and the flavors arent too strong.  Just right

An excellent beer from Unibroue, cloudy amber color, not a lot of nose but good carbonation and frothy head that leaves a good lace.  Higher ABV is hidden.  Flavor is sweet citrus and yeast, smooth. $5.79 for a caged and corked 750ml bottle from Concord Cooperative Market Concord, NH.
Perfect in my Unibroue tulip glass....  well balanced, flavorful... banana, orange and a little spice

La Fin du Monde smells like a strong hefeweizen with spicy notes.  It also pours like one with plenty of short-lived frothiness and cloudiness.  A warming alcohol glow permeates the clove, spice, and apricot flavors.  The palate is deceptively light, probably a result of the triple fermentation.  While lacking the firmness and character of Aventinus (still my reference for strong wheat beers), this is still a well-balanced, enjoyable beer.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2009 750ml corked bottle into a tulip glass. A hazy golden ale with a decent sized white head. Strong aromas of malty honey and oranges. Full mouthfeel with smooth taste of oranges, honey and nice warming spicy yeasts. The finish is quite dry. Nicely integrated flavours and very drinkable given the ABV. These Canadians know their stuff!
bottle in montreal with fuk squad..  Big head,  wish i would have made it out to the brewery

Pours a clear, bubbly, goldenrod yellow.  Nice dense white head that didnt stick around.  Aroma is wonderful yeast with light sweet malt and a tart fruitiness (higher temperature fermentation?).  Flavor is yeasty and tart as well, with an almost pilsner-ish crispness.  Not too sweet, and the aftertaste is pleasing.  It just lacks that special something to put it over the top.

Plenty of fruit in the aroma, particularly banana and orange, with trademark spicy yeast, of course. Appearance, though "blonde", was surprisingly opaque, good sized head,even though the girl couldnt pour to save her life. Flavor had plenty of yeasty character, along with orange, banana, apricot and other complexities. Palate was fairly lively, but not overwhelming, some alcohol presence. Good, but nothing too outstanding from other tripels on the block.

Location: on tab at the Waterfront Ale House in Manhattan, 11/08


Had this on tab at the Waterfront Ale House in Manhattan, and was really impressed, great beer. Had 2 beers while I was there, this and the Rochefort 10, Id call that SUCCESS!

Disclaimer - Abbey Trippels arent my favorite style.  But this was drinkable, and is probably an awesome one if these are up your alley.  Beautiful golden color, impressive head, yeasty and fruity aroma, very complex flavor.  Smooth, but packs a wallop.

lovely spices and citrus taste with a hint of cloves
yellowish color with thin laces of bubbles
smooth alcohol and yeast aroma in the aftertaste

750ml Pours clear golden with a white head. Settle quickly, little lacing. Soft feel in the mouth some light tickle on the tongue and the back of the throat.  Somewhat malty finish that thickens on the pallet. Uncomplicated nose (very slight urea) mostly a crisp spicy smell.  Taste is peppery, some yeast, and characteristic orange. Alcohol comes through more then i would like. All told it is a good beer and generally refreshing.
Bottle.  Light golden orange, medium puffy white head.  Smells strongly of clove, bread.  Bread, citrus, hint of brown sugar.  Somehow light and refreshing.  One of the better Unibroues.
Pours golden yellow with a nice white head.  Strong yeast aromas with floral hints.  Taste of sweet yeast, fruits (citrus?) and spices.  Nice blend.

12 oz bottle.  Pours very hazy yellow orange with a thick creamy off white head.  Smells of wheat, light fruit, and flinstone vitamins.  Tastes of light fruits, like banana, peach, and some berry.  Lots of yeast and vitaminy taste.  But very good, smooth, creamy, and not too sweet like other triples Ive tried.  Good job on this one.

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2009 Bottle courtesy of TearsForBeers. A well loved beer is always welcome as a bonus, thanks my freind. 
Pours a very attractive cloudy blond with a big fluffy white head producing a good lace. Aroma is sweet with notes of orange and some citrusy hops nicely aromatic with a little sweat and alcohol lingering in the background. The flavor is wonderfully sweet, one of the best sweet beers Ive had. There are notes of orange and some hops for balance. There are good yeast flavors overall very fruity and very nice.

Pours a nice hazy amber color with a foamy head. Very nice body. Malty, sweet nose with a loads of yeast to it. Very sweet taste on the tip of the tongue. Very fruity and a nice mouthfeel with a high amount of carbonation, but not damagingly so. Very crisp on the lips and the alcohol is tucked away nicely.
Great beer.  Pours cloudy golden color with great effervescence and carbonation.  Flavor is fruity with a nice mouthfeel.  Crisp.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2011 Very strong IPA taste. Not as prominent as in standard IPAs, but this Tripel still maintains a lot of hops. 3.0 
RE-RATE 1/23/11 Bottle from Central Market.  Been meaning to get around to re-rating this.  That stupid IPA comment has bugged me forever. 

This beer appears quite cloudy, with a golden color shining through.  The head response is very quick right from the moment of agitation.  I tried to keep most of the cultured yeast out of it but I think that is leading to the cloudiness.

The aroma is very fruity, with a spicy clove like nose and banana.  It is pretty spicy most definitely.  It is quite appealing, with a grainy backbone.

The flavor is spicy as well, with like a earthy ginger flavor.  Fruit also comes through on the palate, and remains till the finish.  There is a bit of alcohol tingle towards the back of the throat with a lingering dryness.  There is also a sweetness that has a soft, floral touch to it.

The alcohol on this is 9%, and it can definitely be felt in a warming fashion.

6L Bottle at Novare Res.
Ive heard great things about this beer for a long time, but for some reason I just never had it.  Well finally split a HUGE bottle of this with a friend.  Pours a nice golden orange cloudy color.  Aroma is yeasty with hints of spices.  Flavor is pretty much Belgian spices and yeasts.  Not my fav...
The classic Unibroue offering. Pours a nice gold colour, with very thin head. Aroma is mild, dominated by yeast, taste a bit spicy, lots of yeast, well balanced.

Bottle pours cloudy dark golden color with white head.  Aroma is yeast.  Has a medium light mouthfeel with a lot of carbonation.  Flavor is yeast.  Not as strong as some of the other brews by this brewer.  But it just dominates all their brews.

Appearance: Orange brown, quite cloudy. Little bit of fizzy white head.
Aroma: Bit of yeast. Ripe fruit.
Taste: Strong, warming. Hops, more fruit. Bit alcohol.
Info: 330ml bottle, 28/2-2009

750 ml bottle. Pours a beautiful gold with a thin white head that disappears almost immediately. Nose is citrus, banana, coriander and a hint of alcohol. You can really smell the yeast. Taste is sweet malts, citrus, and a pleasant hit of alcohol. Medium mouthfeel with a nice bubbly carbonation. I like the 3rd glass best because you can pour the yeast.

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2010 This beer absolutely blew me away. I gave it the marks because I dont recall drikning anything as satisfying as La Fin du Monde. Great carbonation with orange and spice flavours. It dances on your palate with the alcohol hidden very well. My favorite brew so far after sampling a lot of tripel stlye brews. Since tripels are my favorite style, this has go to be my top beer. I would have given it a perfect rating, but I dont think you can give a perfect rating since it is impossible to know what may be brewed next. Happy drinking.
Desde seattle parte del six pack que compramos con sici. Con el gordo y greg. Pura belga sin tanto citrico ni putrefaccion. Buena con mas hops mejor
75 cl bottle at Hopheads´ tasting 30.01.09 (Trygve). Golden orange color, fine white head. Aroma is spicy and yeasty, fruity. Flavor is the same, with sweet malt and a hint of sourness. Lovely.

Its a pleasing nice hazy deep yellow color.  There is a almost fruity aroma when you first smell it.  After the pour it holds a nice creamy head for a good while.  The taste is really good, I thought there would be a alcohol taste because of the high alcohol content but I never noticed this.  I would definitely buy this again, and at only $6.99/4 pack, pretty good price IMHO.

Bottle.  Pours a hazy, orangish color with a frothy, large white head.  Lacing is good.  Aromas of bananas, wine, orange, and a bit of honey.  Lively carbonation with a thick initial taste, then giving way to a slick and sticky finish.  Flavors of orange, bananas, and some port.  Very good beer and one that I will be enjoying again soon.

2005-11-5 750ml Bottle shared with Grand Genie.  Hazy dark golden appearance and very nice cediments with anice white head.  Aroma:  alcohol, cinnamon, coriander, orange zest, pine.  Flavor: peache, alcohol, pepper, coriander, orange, maple sugar.  Palate:  light body, soft carbonation and an oily citrus finish.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2010 Pours a very light yellow color with a large white head.  Tastes like a wheat beer with hints of fruit and the noticeable taste of alcohol.  Its very yeasty, but if thats your thing, then Im sure youd enjoy it.

hazy gold, strong active bright white head.  notes of white fruit, though very faint.  of course theres soft and gentle belgian yeast but also fresh cut green pine as well.  effervescent with notes of strawberry, hay, orange and honey.  this beer has become a template for others to follow in my mind when comparing the style, though no one component of this particular beer stands out.  the whole is bigger than the sum of the parts.

Slightly sweet; almost to the point of being obnoxiously so. Tastes like a loaf of bread smeared with a sort of peach or pear jam.  Can definitely taste the alcohol.  Very good beer; not great.  Unibroue Trois Pistoles, however, is fantastic!

750ml bottle - pours a light golden color with a small head.  Fruit  comes through nicely on the nose.  A very smooth tasting, medium bodied beer.  This is the first of the Unibroue brewery that Ive had and Im very impressed.  Will definitely be purchasing more.

Everybody likes this stuff, and for good reason.  Sometimes the ignorant masses are right.  Id go to the end of the world, or as the French - I mean Freedom - say, to "la fin du monde," to get this stuff. A solid tripel, cloudy golden appearance with a lacy white head.  Aroma of sweet malt, yeast, banana/clove, and other light fruits.  Flavor is highly yeasty with light fruits and spices. Refreshing as hell.  Smooth palate, carbonation pretty high.

750ml bottle. Pours golden, lots of carbonation, small white head. Palate is astringent, almost acid. Flavor starts sweet, very yeasty. Nice vanilla aftertaste. Aroma is fruity, with tints of alcohol.
Orange color pours a nice white head, sweet fruity aroma, starts sweet, but finishes fruity with well-hidden alcohol, finish is perfectly dry.

Dark golden with a uniform, thin white head. Quite carbonated.  Fruity and somewhat spicy, malty aroma.  Sweet but with a fairly light palate.  9% ABV packs quite a kick for such a light beer - kinda nice change, IMHO - the best part about this beer.  This beer couldnt stand up to the sharp cheddar I was munching on, but might do well against some of your less flavorful foods found in most pubs (eg. fries, fried cheeses, hummus/fruit plates, your mom).
bottle.  i just dont like these beers - waaay too yeasty and tough to drink - i understand these to be popular beers but just doesnt do it for me
750ml bottle, Pours golden orange with quite a bit of carbonation. Fruity and yeast aroma. Yeaste taste. Slight bitterness. Nice beer. Rating no 11. 070209

Very fruity, like sweet peaches. Very carbonated, a little spiced. Alcohol pretty well hidden. My only problem was the carbonation. It was almost frothy, and I dont really care for that. Otherwise, tasty.

Bottle  Pours a golden orange with a fluffy white head which leaves a good lacing. Aroma is spicy yeast and fruits.  Has a good mouthfeel and good carbination.  Has a smooth taste well blended and not strong.  A decent aftertaste.  Overall a very good beer.

Bottle. Dark golden color, semi hazy. Complex aroma of belgian yeast, spices, sweetnes and dry white wine. Elegant taste. Spices and honey with a hoppy bitterness in aftertaste. Well balanced and smooth (like all Unibroue brews seems to be),

Since I have started drinking beer, out of everything Ive had, this has by far become my favorite. So consistently good, I keep coming back to it. Poured from a 12 oz. brown bottle into a regular pint glass. Smells of yeast and fruit. Brilliant reddish-orange color with thick, frothy white head. The mouth feel is full, but alcohol is not dominant, if even noticeable, which is surprising for a beer with 9%. It tastes yeasty with hints of sweet fruits and a slight but brilliant bite from the hops to balance it out. Just indescribable. So much going on in this beer. Perfection in a glass.

Bottled. Pours opaque honey with a foamy white head that quickly subsides and laces somewhat. Aroma is spicy yeast, banana-strawberry, hay, and slightly phenolic. Flavor is sweet yeast-clove, banana-strawberry and apple fruity, citric, slightly mandarin orange and woody. Due to multiple fermentations, which I have experimented with, the palate is a lighter and densely carbonated throughout giving a creamy feel but also a slight bite and lasting oily tingle atop the tongue. Not as good as a Golden Monkey.
Slightly hazy golden honey color.  Thin whitish cover.  Aroma is very yeasty, spicy, bananas and cloves, biscuits.  Taste is spicy again, yeasty breadiness, sweet with a nice light fruit note.

Hazy golden color with a huge, fluffy white head that lasts forever. Nice lacing too. Taste is sweet and spicy like bannanas, cloves, oranges, and maybe a touch of honey. Alcohol is well-hidden and the palate is smooth with lively carbonation. Very drinkable and enjoyable.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2009 Poured a deep golden color with orange hues. The head was white and fluffy. The aromas were so inviting! The backbone was really sweet yeast with scents of honey, oranges, and alcohol all melding together perfectly! The flavor was strong on the honey flavor, but the palate was very nice. Nice carbonation and easy to drink.

750 ml bottle from LCBO.  Pours murky yellow with a small head. Aroma of  strong fruity/citrus along with some yeast.  Flavour a citrus and yeast along with some spice, finishes nice.  Overall a great beer.

12 oz bottle: pours a hazy yellow gold with a nice sized white head. Lots of distinctly unibroue yeast aromas with a little grapefruit and apple citrus. Earthiness, bread, orange peel, green apples, corriander and yeast are all over my tongue bouncing off with lots of carbonation. The fruity tartness fades to a hint of alcohol in the finish. Very nicely done.

12oz bottle served in the 2ng gen smokestack chalice. This is a beer that I have drank lots of but never rated. Aroma of spicy bananas, candi sugar, vanilla, some tartness, and a some lemon. Hazy orange color with a smallish head. Taste is banana, light fruit, white pepper, and warming alcohol. There is a nice amount of maltiness, biscut, and light residual sugars to make it a nice, if slightly overattenuated, tripel. Easy to drink but full of flavor. The alcohol may be a little too warm, but the beer seems to be able to take it.

(bottle - 12 oz) Cloudy golden color with an inch of white fizzy head. Flavor is very yeasty and spicy, exactly like a Belgian tripel, with lots of citrus, cloves, banana, and other spices. Flavor is incredibly spicy and sweet at the beginning with lots of yeast, banana, clove, and anise. The alcohol blends well and mixes with the yeast and lightly grainy middle and a spicy and sweet finish. Leaves a crisp aftertaste. One incredibly tripel.

Pours a big white head.  Smells almost sharply like bubblegum, clovey-spices.  Color of a classic abbey tripel, yellowish-gold with a hazy center.  Taste is indeed robust, a linear crescendo of flavor, crisp and spicy with a sweet aftertaste where alcohol is not present but definitely noticed soon after each sip.  The feel of this beer in your mouth is great.  Ill venture to say I like it better than trois pistoles.
Pours with a thick, frothy head.  It has a very yeasty aroma.  Warm initial taste with a dry, slightly unpleasant finish.  Leaves a lasting warmth.

750 ml bottle that I received as a gift.  Pours a hazy gold with quite a few floaties.  There is a large white head that lasted through through three-quarters of the glass and left large patches of lace.  Pleasant aroma of lemon, yeast and just a bit of spice.  The flavor is lemon, yeast, spice and some candi sugar. Dries out just a bit as it approaches the finish.  Lively on the palate.  I was frankly surprised to see that I hadnt rated this before now, as Ive had this several times.
Bottle. Kinda cloudy in color, but its all good. Citrus, almost spicy flavor. Beautiful head. Nice flavor.
Bottle pours out a cloudy gold topped with a sand head. Aroma was nice plenty spice and belg yeast. Tast was more spice, clove, yeast,  and some sweetness. A solid abbey

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2009 Violent start on a beer that looks innocent enough. You are immediately bombarded with spices and flavors of unmistakable anise/licorice. But, much like whiskey, the more you let it permeate your palate, the more you can enjoy the subtleties behind the fumes. A fun beer to enjoy on its own, cleanse your palate before downing something else- this will stay with you.

Pours golden and hazy with lots of foamy head. Considerable amount of lacing. Strong citrus and yeast smell reminiscent of a weiss beer. Complex, sweet flavor thats well balanced with subtle spiciness.

Pours a golden yellow with a two finger head with some spidery lacing on the glass. Drank out of a wine glass.

Aroma is very much like a belgian strong pale ale. The yeast and alcohol can be detected and the malt smells very sugary.

The taste is a lot of sweet, sugary malt balanced well with a spicey hop flavour. Interesting flavour and pretty complex while being smooth and highly drinkable. The alcohol is well hidden but the yeast flavour is definately there.

Great mouthfeel, smooth with a crisp carbonation. Medium bodied. Very nicely done.

Very drinkable, and highly recommended if youre into Belgian strong ales.

Bottle.  Hazy golden pour with a nice frothy head.  Aroma is sweet; light fruit, pear, citrus, bubblegum and a little spice.  Similar flavor with the 9% abv showing up for the finish.  Flavor is actually a bit too sweet for my taste.

Dégusté dans un verre de fin du monde. Bouteille dans un ensemble de dégustation 2009. Bière enbouteillé en novembre 2008. Bière de couleur or ambré avec des insertions de brun pâle harmonisant une bonne mousse, des dépôt de levure et une absence de bulles. Odeur de banane, houblon fleural, coriande. Une odeur ennivrante mais sans artifices, tous ce joue en subtilités. Le thym, le clou de giroffe, la muscade, le bois de cèdre et le citron font parti du second nez présent au réchauffement du liquide mais ne sont pas les ingrédients principaux de cette bière mais plutôt un ajoux imagé et de souvenir par rapport à dautres goût issus de cette cervoise. Un goût de levure et dalcool  suivis dun crémeux et dune amertume avec une bonne gazéfication. Un peu de banane, de lime , de thym et de coriande. Elle sera encore meilleur dans 5 ans.

Color is golden, cloudy.  Smell is too complex for me to sort out, but I put it fruity, flowery, with a mediciney/solvent sort of background.  Taste is sweet, acidic fruits, very minor bitterness, warming if you hold it on the tongue.  Moderate carbonation, sort of dry finish.  Very good

FRom 750ml bottle. Smells of orange peel and clove. Pours hazy yellow with a thick white head. High carbonation. Flavors of orange, cloves, spices, yeast.  And the flavor lingers for a long time. This is a great beer!
2008 Bottle - Pours pale and murky yellow with a massive head...aroma is grainy, spicy, some pear..flavour is similar, the booze is prevalent, cinnamon and clove, finishes a bit sticky...

Pours a pale straw yellow with a white finger and a half head.Poured into a tulip glass. Clove yeasty flavor much like a German or Bavarian hef but much cleaner. for an 9% alc brew this hides it very dangerously.This has the clean Canadian crispness with the Bavarian purity drinkability all wrapped in one beer!

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2011 96 is a very high score, despite many who hate this beer.  I would have rated it a lot lower a few years ago.  Because my tastes has changed.  Also, because now I know it is MADE TO BE DRANK WARMER than usual beers.  8 or 10 degrees celcius, around 45 farenheit.  Then youll discover the flavors that are smoothly fruity and both sugary, with not much bitterness.  It is a great beer to me, and I am saving some for aging. They say 5 years potential in a Unibroue booklet I got in a special package.
Tulip from bottle.  Pours a thick orange/tan.  Boozy aroma of yeasts, some tropical fruits.  Boozy flavor follows the aroma, with some clingy bourbon-esque aftertaste. Sticky.
Poured a hazy gold color with a fluffy white head. Spicy, citrusy aroma Spicy grapefriut flavor with maybe the barest hint of alcohol. Very easy drinking for an ale of 9%. Excellent

750 ml bottle that somehow was available for purchase in my uber religious hometown. Nice golden pour with a huge white head and a nice big amount of lacing left behind. Fruity smell with a big flavor of bubblegum and fruit with some wheat thrown in as well. Tasty little ale, would definitely drink again. This was the beer I chose to ring in the new year with, hope the name is no indicator of what will happen in 09!

12oz botthe: Appearance is hazy light brown with quick fading white head, aroma filled with spices and little bit of yeast, flavor pretty compex lots of spices again light bodied but full flavored. Doesnt taste ful belgian but i like it none the less.
bottle, Auchan Illkirch-Graffenstaden, 2007. Hazy golden yellow, large white head. Malty, slightly hoppy wiht a fruity character. The alcohol is well deisguised.
even better than the other one i tried.

UPDATED: MAY 21, 2009 Bottle pours a slighly cloudy golden color with a thin outer ring of head along the edge of the glass and a small island of head in the middle.  The aroma is yeast, wheat, spices, and some fruit.  Flavor is sweet and malty at first, followed by spices, a slight bitterness, and a dry aftertaste.  Lively carbonation on the tongue.  The 9% is well hidden.

750 ml. bottle.  Pours a deep cloudy yellow with a quickly dissipating white head.  Very typical belgian aroma of yeast, some wheat,   fruitiness and spices.  Tastes very sweet.  Apricot and pear, slight alcohol warmth, a good deal of bready malt and a hint of spices.  Some hop bitterness is present.  Flavor is better than the aroma suggests.  Medium bodied with a frothy, carbonated mouthfeel.  Lingering soapy belgian funkiness.
Bottled. Poured yellow mild head and some lacing.  Spiced and fruity, a very nicely balanced tripel in the end.

La Fin du monde fit mieux avec la levure unibroue que toute les autres bieres de la brasserie. Un peu malter avec une sensation rechauffante d alcool.

Unibroue s yeast fits better with La fin du monde than any other Unibroue s beer. A bit malty with a warming alcohol sensation.
Shared this with Oldrtybastrd.  This poured yellow with a small white head and no lacing to speak of.  There is a little spice aroma and the taste is also spice.  The alcohol comes out in the end.

bottle. has a very strong aroma of fruit and spice. pours a cloudy golden yellow with a frothy head. has a very unique flavor. cinnamon and other spices. has a very nice warm finish with very little aftertaste.

Bottle. Pours a hazy golden color with a nice frothy head. Aroma of roasted malt, spices, caramel and some wheat. Taste of  caramel malt,  coriander, yeast, alcohol and peaches.Has a nice crisp dry finish.

Thick white head with small bubbles, hazy and straw in color. Aroma is sour fruits, biscuity malts, alcohol. Flavor is faint sour fruits, white bread, green raisin, peppery spice. some of the alcohol is present but its welcome. Me liked it.

12oz twistoff bottle.  Pours a cloudy haze of deep golden.  Rich white creamy head.  Small bubbles cascading to the surface releasing a fruity bouquet.  Spicy and yeasty aroma.  full body.  Sweet flavor of light colored dried fruits, some alcohol, and a nice bit of of malt.  Hints of golden raisin, biscuts, and rich grains all blended nicely.  very well balanced.  finishes with a welcoming alcohol presence.  Cheers!

750ml bottle.  Poured a cloudy golden color with lasting creamy head.  The aromas were fruity with a slight hint of  alcohol.  A full bodied sweet and spice taste with moderate carbonation. Very perfectly balanced with many flavors dancing around.
Straw colored with thin white head.  Aroma of citrus and hay.  Medium body, malt flavor with lemon and grapefruit, dry hop finish.  Nice one.
Golden color with a thick creamy head.  Alcohol content is higher but you cant hardly notice it. Outstanding flavor.

300 mL bottle. Pours a beautiful cloudy golden with a modest white head and some yeast particulate floaties. Nose is spice, orange peel, yeast, granny-smith apples. Initial taste shows how high the carbonation is in this tripel. Lots of yeast, bubblegum, citrus, cloves, and tropical fruit. Very smooth and creamy rather than watery and acidic. Alcohol is perfectly hidden. Refreshing, not too light, and awesome!
Abundance of spices, citrus, and yeast in the aroma and flavor.  Pour great with a thick white head.  Good hop touch.  A bit more alcohol and it would be almost overwhelming. Almost.

Bottle@home - 2006 vintage

Apperance: Hazy golden orange with a ok sized head. Very nice lacing!

Aroma: Tropcial fruits, Yeast, Cloves, Citric notes. Wonderful!

Flavor: Honey, Fruit (Apple, Pears, Bananas), Spices (Pepper!), Yeast.

Palate: Carbonation is at a medium level. Very nice balance and absolutely no trace of alcohol. Very impressive!

This is a favourite that i keep on coming back to again and again. Insanely drinkable for a 9% brew. Has the typical Unibroue yeast-character but if you can’t get past that, you’re missing out! Recommended++!
Bottle. Aroma of spices, citrus, lots of musty yeast. Flavor the same, so much yeastiness. Definitely a good (or better) beer, but just a little too overwhelming with all the yeast for me.

Bottle.  Pours a golden yellow with a thick white head.  Aroma is sort of odd, skunky-ish, some spices (clove maybe?).  Flavor of a slight yogurt sourness, mint julep, melon, and yeast.   A little heavy to drink.  Decent tripel though!

Preface: I have enjoyed this beer for years, and having requested a case from brother Jer to celebrate my second son’s birth (Michael Mark, 10lbs., 12 oz.), I revisit Unibroue’s pride with a respectful confidence....thick, pillowy four-finger head froths the in THE La Fin Du Monde tulip... body is thick, orange/peach, and sediment-filled...tracings are like rhythmic ocean waves... flavorful, bright bouquet of yeast... hops are brisk and pleasant, with a slight citric injection... medium-bodied with a full finish--minimal alcohol presence, active but not obtrusive... reminiscent of the Schneider folk’s brews--refreshingly clean, crisp, complex with clove, spruce, cinnamon, vanilla, watermelon, pear, and citrus ... palate-cleansing and complimentary to a host of foods--most notably these nachos! Cools and burns at the same time... an almost unbelieveable combination of refreshment and taste, readily causing amnesia at the thought this was ever a tripel at 9%....beautiful.

There are multiple cliché images, songs, and phrases that run through my mind whenever I think of or see the La Fin du Monde from Unibroue. Literally it translates to The End of the World. Quite fitting I must say for a strong Belgian tripel worthy of the best of her native homeland, Belgium, even though she is from Quebec, Canada. Besides being fun to say and chuckle about, La Fin du Monde is also an excellent beer to drink. After all, if the world were truly ending, I know I would want a damn good beer in my hand, for which she perfectly fit the bill.She came to me in a bottle before emptying herself into my glass with a huge head of foam which rested most decadently on top of her hazy orange body. Bubbles stream from bottom to top, releasing an aromatic assault of spicy yeast notes, pungent wet sourdough, melon, apples, cinnamon, and leather. Some might say yuck, but I say yum. Her body and mouthfeel is as delicious as her nose, sweet and viscous with a mild chewiness. Weaving a subtle layer of spice and yeast, apples, melons, and pears also make their presence known in this varied and well-balanced palate. A lingering citric bite in the finish cleanses and brings me back for more. The further I go the more her warm embrace slowly pervades through my body, leaving a faint breath of spice. Rich, chewy yet smooth, yeasty with orange, melon, and pear essence, apples and spice, and a citric lemon nip hold this amazing Belgian-style tripel together. Hopefully the world never will end, though if there were to never be any more La Find du Monde that would surely be an end to my world as i know it.Unibroue never fails to always satisfy me, and more often than not, she blows my tastebuds away. La Fin du Monde falls squarely in tbe middle of said equation. While definitely more vibrant and faithful than some Belgian tripels I have quaffed, she doesnt quite equal her predecessors either. I wonder how she would age, so I must remember to set aside a bottle the next time I bring her home.

Solid. Perfectly appropriate and enjoyable aroma for this style.  Translucent, luminous peach color is perfect.  This would have been even better had it not been for the unfortunate sticky aftertaste that wasn’t all that pleasant.

Beautiful tripple style ale .Good shit. You can feel the erratic spicy alcohol jumping through your organs .I get excited drinking beerz like this. Dangerously eazy to swill .loved the bottle design.Orange peel esters and pepper corns with overweight Maltiness. Dry ,spicy -cultured glass of plonk.

The pour is a hazy golden color with a nice fluffy white head.

The smell is very floral with hints of fruits, mostly citrus. Also a bit of buttered biscuits as well.

The taste is initially a mix of tropical fruit with slight floral hints coming through. There is also the presence of cloves and other spices I can’t put a finger on. The finish is a blend of yeast that is warmed very slightly by the alcohol.

The mouthfeel is light and pleasantly light and fizzy.

This is an amazing brew overall. Very complex smells and flavors are found with every sip. Even towards the end of the glass I struggle to connect what I am tasting to other tastes and smells so I’m just going to give up and simply say that this is an excellent example of a tripel that I would gladly have any time.

Reviewed on: 06-17-2008

Bottle courtesy Naka.  Pours deep golden with 2 finger white head that dissipates slowly.  Nose of fresh baked raisin bread.  Mild cherry and yeasty notes.  Raising and cherry are predominant, then lots of alcohol heat and flavor accentuate the fruit, but mute most of the spiciness and malt profile.  Not bad.  Lots of flavor.  Would do well with some time.

Bottle.  Poured a hazy gold color with a fizzy white head.  Aroma of yeast, spices and citrus fruit.  Flavor was clean, with a slight hint of apple and yeast.  The carbonation level of this beer was a bit too high (It made me burp after every sip).

Pours a hazy wildflower orange-honey color with a huge foamy white head.  About 3 fingers and leaves some nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma is spicy yeast, apricots, and citrus.  The flavor is bright and crisp.  Yeasty flavor carries through into the taste.    A nice rich honey apple with some definite alcohol warmth.  The finish is a bitter dry with a great warming sensation.  Very well-balanced.  The body is medium but a tight carbonation keeps it feeling sort of light.  Quality, like most of the other offerings from Unibroue.

Shared this one w/ SkyCop32.  Picked up at Maruhn Getränke in Darmstadt.  Pours a hazy golden yellow color.  Aromas of yeast, some fruit and spice.  Taste is yeasty and medicinal, can really taste the alcohol in this one.
This certainly reminds me of high-grade Belgian brews.  Has a wonderful rose and peach scent and has a strong citrus/peach taste.  Quite good.
750 ml bottle.  Pours a honey golden yellow.  Flavor: Very belgian, with hints of yeast and lemon.

[Bottle] Pours a cloudy light gold with lots of floaties and a large off white head. Aroma is yeast, candi sugar, coriander, and leafy noble hops. Flavor is quite sweet, well carbonated, yeasty and lemony with some banana. Light mouthfeel but rich flavors.

Pours a medium bright gold with light honey colors, has a large creamy white head, lots of effervescence and leaves nice fine bubbled lacing on the glass, aromas of oranges, orange skin, peaches, lemons and yeast, light bread fragrances, has a pronounced dry citrus sweetness, some floral fragrances that remind me of Clover Honey, no alcohol on the nose, big flavor of light fruit of oranges, lemons and faint banana, has some pepper bitterness at the finish, lightly sweet, has light bread and malt flavors, no alcohol flavor, the alcohol is hidden well, not much alcohol warmth felt at all, mouth feel is a bit less then medium, feels light and creamy on the tongue, nice carbonation, a very nice tripel.

Soft aroma, yeasty, pears, banana.  Small bubbled, but thick white head, nice retention, nice lacing.   Hazy and pale appearance.   Bubbly, small bubble feel in the mouth.  I agree with the rater that said bubble gum taste in the palate.   I liked it.
Wow. A very light color. Ok to me this screams heffeweizen yeast. Oh its too tasty! I could drink this beer every day! It is gonna place in my top five favorites for sure.

Pours a cloudy lemony yellow, with a small white head made up of tons of tiny bubbles. On the nose there are citrus notes and a lot of yeast. Great mouth feel, it feels like chapagne. Citrus notes, yeast, a bubble gum taste in the beginning of the finish, subtle hints of ginger. Really good beer!

Another great beer from Unibroue.  Fruity with 9% alcohol and smooth as heck.  These guys seem to have this style of beer down.  I’m going to have to try a couple more from this brewery.  So far they’re a big 2 for 2! Can’t wait to try another brew!
12 oz bottle. Light and yellow/fizzyish. Nice musty, spicy, farmhouse nose. Slightly sweet and more like a farmhouse/saison ale rather than a triple. Very drinkable for a 9% beer. Nice.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Good beer, but totally overrated.  It smells nice, but really is too light to earn such a high rating.  It tastes of pears and other sweet fruitiness.  The finish is quick and not bitter.  A good beer if you are thirsty, but not complex enough or heavy enough if you want something you can really appreciate.

Pours an orange color with quickly dissapating white head.  Taste of fruit and cinnamon.  One of the most drinkable beers I ever had.  You would never know it has a 9% ABV.

12 oz. bottle

UPDATED: OCT 19, 2008 Orange beer with short lasting white head. Light, flowery and spicy aroma. Ginger snaps, brandy and spices lead to a somewhat metallic and orangey middle and pleasant malty end. Light and somewhat thin-bodied but delicious nonetheless.

Beatiful nose: pears, yeast and bread crumbs and a fake orange candy aroma
If you hate the dryness of beers than this is the beer for you.  This is like sweet candy and I’m not really feeling it.  This is a dssert beer. WOW. However, this is clean and smooth and the water is pure.  I’m kind middle of the road on this beer--its tooo sweet for me.
Not bad though.

Another solid offering from Unibroue.  
Pours a murky, cloudy light gold in color.  Two fingers of head forms on the pour.  Smell is highly yeasty, with some spice and a decent amount of lemon.  Taste has actually quite a bit of yeast to it.  There is more of the fruity overtones, with more than just the lemon flavor showing up.  Decent mouthfeel and highly carbonated.  Decent, but it’s not "The Don".
Very fruity and sweet, nice yellow color.This is one sweet and fruity beer, its good, but not that good. To me it takes like champagne.

Another wonderous beer from Unibroue. This breweryt can’t seem to make a bad beer. Had in bottle. At 9 % this is a bit steep. Can smell the alcohol, and the taste is strong and harsh. Aroma of fermenting fruit and alcohol. Yeasty and maltyt flavour is mixed among the stong 9 % abv flavour. Mouthfeel is unusual and completely standard for a unibroue beer. Wonderful beer overall.
Just like Duvel.  The 10th beer I tried at beerfest.  Wonderous flavor of yeast. Lite in power but packs a punch.  Pretty Damn Good.
Had a very nice pour and aroma to it. The flavor was that of a fransizkaner just a little bit more intensity but still easily drinkable.

Appearance: Pours lightly hazy, golden-orange body with a smallish, white head.

Smell: Fruit juice aroma smelling of pears, peaches, and pineapple -- really any fruit starting with ’p’ will do. Nicely spicy, hint of orange peel, too.

Taste: Pale malts and a large portion of candi sugar quickly followed by a flavorful medley of fruit juices from the nose, plus a greater portion of banana. A counterbalance of spices, bitterish orange peel, and hops try to match the sugars present. Slight yeastiness throughout, maybe a bit of bagel dough. Finishes crisp and quite fruity.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Slight stickiness to the mouthfeel. Medium-high carbonation.

Drinkability: So fruity! A delicate, delightful tripel.
A nice beer. A good clean taste, complex and not overwhelming. Underwhelming, perhaps, though worth appreciating. Good for a summer’s afternoon.

Pours with a murky golden color with a medium sized wide head that mostly diminishes after 1-2 minutes. 
A lot of fruit in the aroma - smells like apples, pineapples, oranges, lemon, and some honey. A little bit yeasty as well. 
A little bit of a dark fruit flavor with a sweet beginning, and it finishes off slightly bitter. I can taste all the fruits I mentioned in the aroma, as well as some grapes. A bread-like flavor is also prevalent. 
Medium palate with lively-fizzy carbonation. 
A really good beer! Was not expecting this to be this good!
Biere tres robuste mais quand meme rafinéé.   Legerement épicée.  Une triple digne de ce nom...

Finally! I’ve tackled Unibroue! I’m not sure why I’ve been putting this off for so long, but I’m a  little regretful that I didn’t try this earlier. It’s damn near perfect. It pours a hazy orangish-amber with a disappearing head. The aroma is of dark fruits, and sweetness. The flavor is just insane. It’s like a good cinnamon bread, with raisins and sugar. I just had the Dark Horse Sappient trip ale, which doesn’t even come close. I will definitely be getting all of the offerings from Unibroue as soon as possible. Cheers!

[Eyes] Cloudy golden straw color with a BIG head with good retention.

[Nouse] Full rich aromas ... yeast, esters, cloves...

[Mouth] Great, Malts and Belgian yeast, good fruitiness,apples, oranges, lemon, honey, sugary sweetness, fresh bread, some almond...Very carbonated with a fairly thin body. 

Serving type: bottle

Attractive, hazy pale poor. The aroma is melon and citrus and lots of yeast. Smells and tastes like a belgian blonde or tripel. Lots of exciting fruit flavours, but very yeasty throughout. Alcohol is also quite prevalent in the nose and the palate. The finish is pleasant.

Tasted 23/09/2008. 330ml bottle from Beerstore (if I remember rightly). Pours a lazy hazy pale yellow gold .  A little glue-like on the nose, reminds me of Westmalle yeast, with a rich sweetness of ripe fruit, alcohol and a background "white" spice. Hints of creaming soda or lemonade "spider" too.  Spicy and watm in the mouth, sweet but not as much as the nose suggests. alcohol is a little too prominent for my liking.  Loads of citrus. Oh hu her!!! Alcohol is too much. Hot and spicy.  I reckon this would be a nice beer with a milder fermentation profile.

Strong citrus aroma, though slightly malty.  Orange-yellow appearance, with some cloudiness and slight effervescence.  Thin but enduring white head with good lacing.  Taste is prominently citrus, grapefruit mostly.  Light spice follows, with the taste of hops and slight yeast flavor discernible.  Great flavor and perhaps even better mouthfeel.  A very fine tripel.

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2016 Initial rating 9-20-2008  Mild malty bready aroma.  Paleyellow, thin white head.  Nice depth of biscuit, toast, toasted malt, light caramel malt flavors with a distinct but understated "Belgian" yeast character mainly mild spice.  Wonderful mouthfeel with a dry finish for the style.  Overall a decent tripel.  More drinkable than some versions, but less complex than the best examples.  

Re-rating 7-16-2016: More complex than initial rating, improved, wonderful.  Nose abounds with grassy pilsner malt characters. Great balance of phenolics & esters.  No alcohol or hop character.  Mildly hazy, srm of 5 or so, straw colored, dense lasting beautiful impressive white head better than 99% of brews.  Flavors reflect aroma heavily, grainy richness, a little sweetness, estery fruitiness is somewhat muted in that no fruit flavors stand out yet you get pear, stone fruits, hint of leafy greens (guessing its hops derived), hints of citrus lemon-lime, apricots, berries.  Palate is wonderful, heavy yet very dry even with the grainy sweetness, medium-light heavy viscosity, very effervescent.  Overall very complex yet drinkable without taxing the palate.  Wonderful example of the style.
Awesome beer. Hoppy, for a triple, and the malt is great. Amazing hops, creamy mouthfeel, and overall awesome.

Poured from the bottle into a trappist glass.  The aroma had a citrus hops and yeast effect, with some banana and orange scents.  A cloudy, straw colored beer with a small white head that clung to the edges but had little retention.  The taste was sweet and candy-like with a milld sour effect too.  A thinner, dry mouthfeel with low carbonation.  Definitely a solid beer, a very good tripel, although not the best.
very smooth but you can taste the high alcohol content.  almost creamy with sweet wheat finish. crisp and not chalky at all.
Biere de couleur blonde brumeuse, avec un mince collet moyennement collant. Odeur de sel, semblant de gomme baloune, un peu d’alcohol et sucre. Gout un peu sucré, oranges, un peu poivré.

So Abbey Trippel is my new favorite style. This brew is a large part of that, although there are other trippels I slightly prefer (koenigshoeven comes to mind). Anyways, fin du monde is slightly sour (citrusy) and bitter, nicely carbonated. Very smooth drinking - despite the high alcohol content. FYI, I’m convinced it’s even better from the large bottles.

Bottle. Quite yeasty smell, light sour and citrus. A cloudy light orange body and a small frothy white head, which is normal long lasting. The taste is heavy acidic and light bitter with a medium duration. Lively carbonation, a creamy texture and a medium body. A nice Belgian-styled beer.

750 ml bottle split in Chimay glass.  Hazy orange with fizzy, quickly disappearing white head.  Peach orange marshmallow spice yeast aroma.  Sweet vanilla orange flavor, very orange, sa if there is added orange.  Lingering orange spicy finish.  Medium-full body, fuller than expected, medium carbo.  Excellent flavor.  Decent texture.

Very good and highly drinkable. Lightly sweet, complex taste of spices and bananas. A light peppery finish that is slightly dry. Surprisingly light bodied for a stronger beer. Perfectly carbonated. No taste of alcohol anywhere.

Pours a hazy orange colour with a thick white head that wears out pretty quick.  Nose is very much yeasty and a little bit spicy, like bananas and cloves.  Taste is fairly sweet with some very nice lemony notes, and a fair bit of the same banana kind of stuff present in the nose.  Very smooth drinking, and plenty creamy.  Carbonation is spot on.  Not a bad beer by any stretch.

750 ml. bottle. Pours a nice creamy, rapidly collapsing head, pleasant pale, slightly cloudy yellow...nose rather mild, yeasty, citrus, bit of spice, especially clove...tastes of yeast, citrus, ? lemon primarily, malt sweetness, and a mildly bitter finish. A really nice subtly balanced beer. Somewhat later the empty glass smelled of heather honey, a wonderful added aroma.

chiara buona schiuma piuttosto p
persitente il naso è molto invitante speziato fruttata sembra quasoi una blanche sembrerebbe dolce in bocca amcora spezie meno fruttta malto frumento non molto amara ma abastanza secca le spezie danno freschezza corpo medio l’alcol non si sente molto
Another job well done by Unibroue. Citris, alcohol, pepper,yeast. Definitely will  have again

Pours milky peach with lots of head, some lacing. Aroma is very yeasty, banana, black pepper, citrus hops like orange glazed dinner rolls. Flavor is hearty but candy like, lemon heads, banana bread, cloves, sweet anise, a little bitter hops and root beer maltiness to finish. Mouthfeel’s a little thin for a triple but not a bad beer all around.
Pours a darker orange color, aroma is yeasty and sweet, with alcohol present, taste of peppery clove and other spices, aforementioned fruits, and sweet malts on the finish....one of my fav beers.

Pours hazy gold with white head that doesn’t stick around.  Slight banana aroma over hops.  Nice crisp banana-bubblegum flavor with a decent amount of carbonation and a definite alcohol kick.  Good balance and the lacing, as usual for Unibroue, is amazing.

Very nice, malty, banana-like aroma. Fairly thick head, pours an opaque gold color. Delicious taste, predominantly fruity, masks the alcohol fairly well for this style. A bit too carbonated for my taste. Usually tripels are too strong for me, but this one is incredibly balanced, an all around great drink.

Bottle. Pours a darker orange copper color. Has sediment in the bottle and leaves lacing on the glass. Very sweet taste that has hints of fruit, like raisan and plum. The alcohol is also present in the beer, as it leaves a light warming sensation. Very carbonated beer. A decent beer.

Pours hazy orange under a thin white head.  Aroma is yeasty and sweet, with alcohol present.  Flavors are sweet on the front, with moderate alcohol, finish is slightly bitter, with herbal notes.  Some woody notes from the subdued hops, but mostly the yeast takes center stage, bringing out the flavors of this malty beer.  Mouthfeel is thicker than expected, with just about the right amount of carbonation (Unibroue sometimes seems over carbonated to me).

aparência inicial média e espumosa. A espuma é branca, de longevidade duradoura e há moderada formação de colarinho. Seu corpo é claro e de coloração dourada.
O aroma é muito interessante; em minha opinião, a melhor característica dessa Tripel. Emanam ao olfato notas de abacaxi, flores e vinho branco - combinação esta dificilmente encontrada. Levemente amargo e ácido: assim é o sabor inicial. O final, de média duração, apresenta apenas leve amargor. Como componentes do paladar, corpo médio, textura seca, carbonatação viva e final moderadamente alcoólico (proveniente de um teor alcoólico de 9%, que se nota presente durante todo o gole, não apenas no final) encerram as características dessa saborosa cerveja

A lovely head over a hazed golden color pour.  Big blast of spice and bread in the aroma. Cloves and coriander dominate the nice mouth filling start.  Bread with hops are the underlying tones.  Nice representation of the style; though, a bit toward the high spiced end.  Nice job.
The right appearance for this nice tripel, with lot of peppery and clove notes, a good malt backbone and certain fruitiness, not exactly in style but pleasant. A dry bitter end ends it all.

Pours hazy golden yellow with a thick white head that held on, eventually leaving a solid cover and excellent lacing. Strong, complex aromas of sugary ripe fruit - peaches and pears come to mind.
