Ale forte de type triple/ Blonde/ Goût fruité et malté: effluves dagrumes, soupçon dépices, corsée/ Arôme épicé rappelant la coriandre; légères effluves de malt/ Elle titre 9% dalcool grâce à trois fermentations.  La Fin du Monde est une bière issue dune race unique de levures lui donnant une saveur dune finesse insoupçonnée. Détient une vigoureuse présence en bouche: légèrement piquante, aux saveurs équilibrées dépices sauvages, de malt et de houblon.

Yummy rich beer flavor. theres alot to this beer - very sophisticated. You can almost taste yeast... but sweet caramel flavor hints wander in... them  bam!!! a fruity after taste! Sooooooo  sophisticated  . . . .the light yellow color is deceiving. Good stuff.

light caramel unfiltered body topped off with a pillowy head.  The aroma is full of lemon and grapefruit.  Their is quite a bit of citrus on the palate, along with grapefrut and a bit of that tripel bubble gum flavor
Nice blonde beer, with a little white fluffy head.  Sweet smell.  I notice the carbonation followed by a yeasty taste and slight alcohol burn.  Very nice!
Sweet aroma with citrus and fruit.  Flavor is sweet with notes of fruit, honey, and yeast.  Nice medium body and lively carbonation.  A very good tripel.

Bottled. Wonderful!!! Color is cloudy golden, thin foamy but persistent. Aroma is complex, citrus and sweety and fruity. Notes of clove, oak, honey and green grapefruit as well. Flavor is sweety, low carbonation and alcohol notes are percepted. Mouthfeel is  sweety at all.Português: Cerveja excelente!!! Cor turva dourada, espuma fina porém persistente. Aroma complexo, Nota cítricas, adocicadas e frutadas. Perceptíveis: Cravo, carvalho, mel e uvas verdes. Sabor é doce, baixa carbonatação e notas de álcool be, acentuadas. Retrogosto doce.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2008 Bottle. Pours very cloudy deep yellow. This beer smells sweet, with nice fruitiness coming through. Taste is sweet with dark fruit and strong alcohol warmth. The mouthfeel is pretty full but with lively carbonation. I love this beer.

Had this beer on 6/2/2007.  Aroma is light with a sweet malt scent.  Color is bright gold with very active carbonation and a thick loose head.  Taste is mild and sweet.  Starting with a medium body it goes down crisp.  Finish comes on with a sweet malt flavor backed by a fruity Belgian yeast taste.  After there is a mild bitterness and a warm feel.  Overall it has a true Belgian taste in a well rounded strong brew.

Pours a golden amber with a thick frothy white head.  Aroma of apple, pear, grape, citrus and slight hint of alcohol.  Very carbonatied with a fruity spiciness up front with a sweet citrus finish.  Kind of like a stronger more carbonated wit beer.

12-ounce bottle from Total Wine. Pours a light-gold body underneath a 1-inch white head that dissipates quickly. Loose, spotted. Nose of soap, coriander, and subtle orange rind. Similar flavors with more coriander, bubblegum, biscuits, and a strong astringent alcohol burn. Slightly yeasty. Finish of subtle green apple and bananas. High carbonation and medium body. Good, not great. Im not tasting much difference from this beer and Maudite, though I like Maudite much better.

The 750 uncorks with a resounding pop, producing a hazy straw liquid adorned with a very even, pillowy head. The foam rapidly recedes to a uniform, cloudlike mat, and only sparse lace remains. Spicy and earthy aromas dominate, teeming with floral Szechuan peppercorns and clove. A less aggressive, soft fruitiness rounds out the bouquet, with bubblegum, orange pith, plantain, and grape the effect is downright perfumey; a mesmerizing musk. Passing the lips, the liquid starts crisp and sharp, then mellows into a laughing melange of tropical fruit flavors: mango, watermelon rind, cherry, and unripe pear. Lively clove and rumcake spiciness adds interest, and a relaxing vanilla note lazily reins it back.. The clipped finish features a flash of tartness and tight bitterness, with a retronasal suggestion of bawdy barnyard funk. Healthy, fluffy carbonation accentuates the bone dry, pins-and-needles mouthfeel. Finally, a lingering, gingery alcoholic glow partners with the tingly, tongue-numbing sensation of ice crystals. A study in contrast, balance, and outright fun... as seamless, smooth, and surprising as live jazz. La Fin du Monde proves a truly outstanding ale that rivals or exceeds Belgiums best.

I like this beer. Hazy orange pore with exuberant head characteristic of a Tripel. Hints of fruit, with strong yeast. A great beer to have in the winter around the fireplace. Spicy orangey flavour makes this a nice festive beer.

341ml bottle.
Pours a hazy orangy yellow that produces a fine white head that sticks around a good while. Leaves some solid abstract lacing. Possibly the first beer Ive had where the head actually shields the whole surface of the beer for the entire drinking experience. Aroma is feintly fruity, I can pick out apricot and plum maybe. Hints of yeast are present as well. Smooth and light with carbonation that massages the tongue. Flavours of similar fruits and spicy notes. A bit of alcohol presence with a more tame and easy finish. Ends hoppy with a reprise of the first fruity flavours. Second Unibroue Ive tried. Enjoyed this more than Trois Pistole. Pretty good ol beer.

Consistent with most (all?) other high-quality Unibroue offerings - higher alcohol, very balanced, nothing in-your-face and more dependant on fruit than most other brewers of similar styles.

Pours a pale brown, almost orange color with a very mild head.  Aroma is sweet, with subtle fruity notes on the nose and stronger yeasty notes of mild clove and melon/banana.  Very pleasant and not surprising for a 3x fermented quasi-Belgian brew.  Flavor is skewed to the malty end of the spectrum (which is good!) and only mild bitterness on the finish.  pleasing on the palate and a good sipping beer to be enjoyed late at night.  Overall another excellent brew from Unibroue.

Interesting shade of orange with moderate head on pour. The aroma is distinctly melon and cantaloupe with a touch of apple to me. All the Unibroue line has that certain fruity something in the finish as well. Its pleasant and silky with very nice masking of the alcohol. An enjoyable trippel, nothing in your face, but  still complex and full of spice mixed with your fruit. As with most all tripels, one to savor and drink slowly.

750 ml bottle from Campus Bottle Shop, pours cloudy golden, with a fluffy head, the arom is sweet and malty, the flavor is sweet, and fruity and finishes with some bitterness, very fizzy, feels nice in your mouth, i would buy again.

Pours a hazy golden with a moderate white head.  Aroma is "typical Belgian," with yeast, bananas, spices, etc.  Im not really sure that I detect the "exceptional refinement," but its certainly a fine brew, slightly sweet, with hints of coriander and orange.  Very slight bitterness at the end.  A fine beer.

Nice tripel.  The appearnce is golden in color, and the head is completely out of control...takes a steady hand to pour it.  Yeasty, citrusy aroma is appealing.  the flavor has the spiciness of a tripel, the palate has some spice, and warming alcohol presence.  Great beer from a great brewery.

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2008 Pours a opaque pale orange with thin white head. Nose is citrus and spice,  with a hint of yeast. Flavor is just as the nose with some sweetness, with a very refreshing quality. The finish is a tad bitter, and the alcohol is hidden very well.
From bottle at tasting : Pours clear light yellow, one finger of white head.  Bubbly, fruity and malty aroma.  Its good, but have had much better Tripels.

Pours cloudy gold with a lot of head. Something of a bottle bomb if served just a little too warm. (I have grown to like beer best a little below room temp.) Both the aroma and the taste of this beer reveal a lot of yeast and alcohol. A bit of the sweet (corriander?) pine/clove flavor that I have come to expect from an Abbey. Very dry finish with a bit of a bite. Sadly, everything seems a bit muted in comparison to other Abbey styles.
Bottle Eulogy Tavern in Olde City Philadelphia- Poured a nice golden coloring with sugary aromas and impressive malts/hops.

Drank this while watching Great Britain Thrash the Kiwis at Rugby League.....excellent day! I wasnt overly impressed with this beer though i got a lot of candy sugar on the nose and in the flavour but not a lot else. Poured a lovely staw colour with a huge white candyfloss head, warming and chewy on the palate but nothing really that stood it out from a standard Belgium triple

Bottle. Drank while watching the last book of Nostradamus on the History Channel, fitting for the name of this brew. Nice chazy golden color. Average sized white head has large bubbles, minimal lacing. A unique aroma; strong malt, fruity, banana notes, belgian yeast, wheat, has soome qualties of a hefeweizen or belgian wit. Flavor is soft, there must be wheat used in good proportion of grist. Slight yeast character and a very slight tartness. Some spice. Malty but with a semi dry bite in the finish. Alcohol well hidden. A very good flavor. Body is medium to full. Excellent.

Bottle - Poured a cloudy straw yellow in color with a foamy white head that hung around.  Nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma   is spicy... cinnamon and clove... with bready yeast.  Flavor is slightly sour with cinnamon, cloves and plenty of estery fruitiness... some citrus, peach... light on the hops. Medium palate.   Some alcohol in the finish, which is quite yeasty and lingering.  Not my favorite tripel, but very good.

12 oz bottle poured into trappist glass.  A nice, white, rapidly dissipating head.  Spicy odor, with an emphasis on cinnamon.  Cinnamon taste with  a citrus aftertaste.  I dont really get into tripels that often, but as far as tripels go this is a great example of one.
Golden color with a nice head.  malty and spicey alot of cinnamon and some fruitiness.  The hops come out very well.

Abbey Tripels are my favorite and La Fin Du Monde is another reason why....exquistely hoppy and yeasty...ripe fruit and spicy, a little bit of cinnamon and clove taste in the back of the throat.  Well carbonated and balanced.
Poors in a pretty big head, nice golden color, Taste was pretty complex of spices, mostly cinnamon, Overall a very nice taste of the great brewery that is Unibroue.

750ml Bottle.
Pours a golden color with a white fizzy head.  Basically, this beer is a standard run-of-the-mill tripel.  Considering I dont care much for the style, this beer was doomed from the start, but it still was lackluster even in the style.
Bottle. Golden pour with a decent head, didnt stick around long. A little spiciness. Decent beer.

Pours a hazy gold/orange with a small white head.  The aroma is of sweet citrus with a little bit of spice in the background.  It tastes a bit like a wheat beer with some malty egg and cloves in the background.

Fairly shitty hay aroma with traces of banana. Milky golden color with a thick head. Vinous, yeasty, and quite sour taste of clove and lemon. Weak celery finish. It tastes like a phenolic witbier with unfermented yeast. I wasnt even sure it was yeast because it was hard to recognize the strain. It might be a good candidate for aging, but off the shelf it wasnt great.

Very fruity, like sweet peaches.  Very carbonated, a little spiced.  Alcohol pretty well hidden.  My only problem was the carbonation.  It was almost frothy, and I dont really care for that.  Otherwise, tasty.

1pt 9.4oz bottle.  Aroma is fruity with yeast.  Notes of orange, peach, plum, grapefruit, pineapple, medicine.  Large white head that mostly diminished and left little lace.  Hazy blond orange hue.  Flavor is lovely sweet and then tranforms to a yeasty earthy and spicy.  Very good brew.  Palate is medium/light bodied and watery soft with a little alcohol burn.  Was very impressed with this brew.

75 cl. bottle with a 07-07-06 best by date. 
Pours a cloudy straw hue with a decent two finger head. Smells spicy, peppery, yeasty. A tart, spicy citrusy taste is accompanied by a crisp, zesty carbonation. Finishes with a yeasty alcohol taste on the breath. 
A most excellent brew. Sept 2004
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Bottle. Pours a hazy gold, with a small, but lasting head. The taste is mostly yeast, a slight apple taste, spices, and a bit of alcohol. Very fizzy and alive. Good drink.

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2007 I am lucky enough to consider this one of my table beers. I just love La Fin du Monde and consider it the flagship beer of the Unibroue brewery. It rivals many Belgian beers of similar style. Its got a sublime mouthfeel. The yeast is that distinct one that can seem sweet to some. At times when I drink it the beer seems too sticky-sweet but other times not, so it might depend on factors like food, etc. Its complex and fun to drink, although can sit heavy in the belly. That doesnt detract from points though, because that is just the nature of a beer like this. There is a lot of banana and all those tropical-like smells and flavors. But what more needs to be said about this much-loved beer? It deserves accolades and must be one of the best of its type brewed in the New World.
nice tripel.  good mouth feel, nice color, little bit of fruit, yeast, malt, and no heavy finish.  very flavorful and drinkable.  dont notice the alcohol...until the 750 is almost gone.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2007 An awesome tripel!  Pours almost-clear light yellow with a head that keeps going... has a nice beer yeast aroma.  The beer is thick, mildly malty with a very complex flavour.  You cant taste the high alcohol content... Ide buy this one anytime!

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2009 Bottle. Pours burnt orange with thick white head. Looks kind of like an orange soda. Yeasty aroma with a hint of spice, and a smooth but sour taste, reminding me of grapefruit. Not an every day beer, but a good experience nevertheless.

Pours a darker golden color with a white head.  Aroma was light with lemon, grass, yeast, and not much alcohol for being 9%.  Light on the palate.  Flavor is of lemon, slight bubble gum, yeast, spices, and grass.  Has only a slight hint of some alcohol warming.  Very good.
truly the end of the world, great start middle and end!  A great head and very lacy with a fruity finish.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2013 Bouteille de 750ml bouchon de liège et bouteille de 341ml avec capsule métallique. Bière dorée avec une mousse blanche. Le nez est très épicé par les levures. La bouche est piquante, épicée, longue et agréable. Un classique.
75cl bottle: Hazy yellow with the finest lasting head & good lacings. Smooth wheat & yeast taste. Soft & medium carbonation. Alcohol well hidden... So drinkable...
UPDATED: OCT 28, 2007 12 ounce bottle purchased at Total Wine Fort Lauderdale, FL $2.29 Very good.
Very spritzy as evident from the tall white head.  Sweet, citrusy, yeasty flavors.  Deliciously refreshing.
Tall soapy white head with excellent lacing.  Aroam of yeast, spices, and malt. Excellent blend of spice, yeast, malt and vanilla.  Mild carbonation.  A slight hot edge;

Sweet smelling...teenage perfume. Looks like an effervescent Budweiser...taste is good, a little like pears and bananas...too fuckin sweet for me to drink more than 2 of them in a row...Not a session brew...I hand it to this Canadian Company for making an affordable "Belgian Style"...but thats just it...its an imitation, and like all imitations it suffers from the indisputable fact that imitations are weaker, less cool etc etc etc...Drink a goddam Duval

Bottle.  hugeormous, creamy, long- lasting, off-white head into cloudy dark orange body.  decent lacing was noticed on the glass.  yeast (bubble gum), light spices, and honey were all present in the aroma.  Flavor is initially bitter sweet then the bitter subsides and leaves the sweet.  fizzy carbonation, light bodied, with long duration on finish.

Good Tripel!  easy to drink and alcohol was hidden well.

Tasting from 355ml bottle in tulip glass.

A little bland compared to other unibroue biers. Toasty flavour with a slight bitter sweet aftertaste that merges to spice.
Great beer, much better than a lot of belgians in my opinion, at least for the price.

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2007 First bottle of a 4 pack from Johns Grocery (Iowa City, IA). Have had before, but didnt rate. A nice hazy high carbonated pour. Pretty substantial head, but that was expected. This tripel really has a nice spice flavor. Clearly there, but definately not overpowering. Settles in as the glass becomes half empty. Fruity and pleasant, perhaps even citrusy. Head diminished with time, but doesnt dissappear. A high quality tripel that Id go back to. A nice example of the category, but not a front runner in my book. Id buy it again.
75cl corked bottle.  Poured out a hazy yellow colour with a nice white head.  Aroma spice and fruit, nice tripel.  Flavour was earthy spice.  Well done tripel.

Another beer that i dont see what all the fuss is over.  Its got exactly the color and head that one could only dream for in an abbey tripel and a very pleasant fruit filled aroma.  I understand that unibroue uses old belgian techiques and belgian yeast strains to boot, but is it too much to ask that their beers have individual taste profiles.  All i taste is lemons, vanilla, and cloves.  With some of unibroues other beers these flavors go extrodinarily well but for how the malt backbone is on this particular brew, its rather offensive.
This is part of a beer club. Had only one bottle but was decent for the price. Poured great and had a nice finish. Would do again.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a murky golden yellow with a huge fizzy white head that quickly diminishes to a thin film and collar.

The aroma is bready malts, yeast and a little fruit and spices (clove).

The flavor is earthy, bready malts with a bit of a fruity twang.  It has a grassy bitter finish with some fruity sour notes.  The mouthfeel is medium bodied with very sharp and strong carbonation.

Overall, an OK Belgian - a bit over-priced though.

Hmmm Im not sure what it was that I didnt like about this.  Maybe I was expecting something else when I bought it like a darker, fruitier Abbey(ala Ommegang Abbey).  I may have just poured it wrong....maybe it was the fact that it was in a pint glass as opposed to a trappist glass.  Either way it wasnt that good to me, but I must say it was well constructed and complex and had a good aroma.  Ill give it another try some other time when I have a Tulip.  Try it yourself if you can afford it and you have the right glass.

This beer pours a cloudy yellow with little to no head at all.  Maybe it is a bad bottle?  I expected way more head. The is a very effervescent beer with a good citrusy smell!  The flavors really hit you good too,  Lots of apricot and yeast with a hint of lemon and honey maybe?  This is one exceptional beer!  Not sure why I waited so long to try this beer.  I will be having more of these for sure!  Cheers!

UPDATED: OCT 19, 2007 Bottle. 341mL. Pours cloudy yellow, with nice lacing and a dense head. Striking aroma is of yeast, dried apples, and apricots. Flavour is sweet and fruity, with lots of apples. Some yeast. Where did all 9% go? A little tart. Medium heavy body, no hops. Incredible.

Bottle poured into a Trappist glass.  Pours yellow with a huge white frothy head.  The head sticks around for the whole beer, but leaves no lacing.  Looking at the glass the beer is hazy with alot of carbonation bubbles floating to the top.  The aroma is citrusy, orange along with a barnyard yeasty aroma.  Taking a drink the first flavor I get is a ever so slight sourness followed by a citrus flavor, mainly orange, after that is a barnyard yeasty flavor followed by a slight bitterness.  There is also a apple and pear flavor hidden in there as well.  The body is light to medium with a dry and creamy texture and fizzy carbonation.
bottle. Hazy orange with ample white head. Aroma of tangerines, yeast. Taste of honey, citrus fruits, amlt. Refreshing, decent length. Nice.

12 oz. Bottle:  Pours a nice pale yellow-orange color which is slightly murky.  Big, fizzy white head dissipated quickly.  Initial aroma is of bananas, spice and yeast.  Some citrus notes present as it warms.  The taste on this is amazing, especially since Im not a big fan of Tripels.  A strong christmas spice flavor hits right off the bat along with a bold yeast foundation.  Has a mild fruit essence to round it out.  Damn good.

UPDATED: NOV 25, 2010 750 ml bottle. pours hazy yellow with an apple ciderish look to it. big fluffy white head. aromas are mainly of yeast with some maltyness. big yeasty flavours with a good amount of sweetness. the 9% abv is undetectable. this is a high quality brew and is esspecially flavourful just cooler then room temp. the hops remind me of tropical fruit and hit you upside the head with wonderfulness. really nice to sit an sip. a classic example of the style. buy some before i get the rest.
From the bottle. What an excellent beer. Rich malt with nice, but not cloyingly sweet finish. Carbonation dances on the tongue. Love this stuff.

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2011 Sept. 22, 2007; 12 oz. bottle.  Not my favorite style, but a lovely brew nonetheless.  Remarkable aroma,; flavor of citrus fruit one would associate with the better wheat beers.  Cant even imagine where they hid the 9% ABV.  Despite the heft, Id probably favor this in the warmer months. 838317

Re-rate on July 26, 2011; 500ml bottle.  Over the course of four years, this has become a favorite style.  Have bumped the better-than-average palate up a point.

12 oz. bottle.  pours a deep golden color with a tremendous head which disappears over time.  very spicey and full of apricot on the nose.  again, spicey on the palate with a bite on the tip and sides of the tongue in the aftertaste.  tingles on the tongue.  excellent abbey tripel.  very tasty.

pours orange gold with a pitted white head.  aroma of citrus and yeast.  taste is a fantastic blend of fruity yeast (orange, pear) and light, sweet malt.  no alcohol flavor comes through but the high abv does add a nice warmth and edge.  great prickly carbonation gives a nice crisp mouth feel, and it finishes dry.  leaves you wanting more.  excellent.
Bottle. Pours a golden yellow with a nicely formed head. Very floral/fruity aroma with a corresponding flavor, except a little maltier. More carbonated than the usual beer.

12 oz. bottle. Another outstanding effort from Unibroue. Beautiful golden color. Highly carbonated; open and pour carefully. Exceptionally fruity nose, carrying through to the taste buds. Gains complexity as it warms a bit. Leans a bit to the sweet side as far as Tripels go, more like Karmaliet than Westmalle.
Highly recommended to fans of the style.
Bottle, poured out hazy cloudy gold, with lots of head. Incredible carbonation through. Fruity malty taste. Good but Maudite is better for me.

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2007 Appearance   750 ml bottle poured cloudy gold with a white head.

Smell:  Fruity, yeasty, malt aroma

Mouth feel: this ale is great well balanced nice carbonation 

Taste: slightly sweet start to a light hoppy bitter finish 

Drinkability: a great  Tripel  I have imbibed in quite a few of these and enjoyed them every time

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2008 Bottle conditioned and courtesy of the LCBO. Golden, cloudy body, with a good head. Fruity, and mulled wine scent. Taste of cloves and cinnamon, with a warming finish. An excellent beer, and one on the best bottles available in Ontario.

Bottle from Brouage, France. Cloudy gold colour with a decent white head and good carbonation. Aroma of sweet malt and yeast. Flavour also started sweet, with some citrus fruit and a good, hoppy dry finish. Enjoyable.

This seperatiste offering is rich and sophisticated yet different, without making a huge fuss about it.  Plain in style, modern, bearing little resemblance to traditional strong beers...great for running alongside a train, playing softball, getting liquored with your mates at Biftek St. Laurant...

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2013 This is a dark gold ale with a fizzy head that settles quickly.  There is an aroma of yeast, malt, and a little fruit.  The sweet, mildly spicy flavor shifts to a little bitterness, sourness, and astringency.  There are touches of pineapple and lemon.  It is not as arresting as the best tripels, but it is good enough. The 9% alcohol is kept under wraps.  I picture having this in a cafe on a sunny afternoon - and getting drunker than I had planned.

This is a side by side review of a 750 ml bottle and ratings a 12 ounce bottle to compare differences between the two. 

Interesting start already. The 12 ounce bottle almost began to foam over the top of the bottle. The 750 ml smoked quite a bit instead. 

Holy head. Maybe this 12 ounce is over carbonated. But the head poured massive, even though I did my best to pour gently. Head is very white with small bubbles compared to the 750 which poured just a little head with much larger bubbles. Color is a cloudy gold, but the 750 bottle seems to be just a touch darker. 

Nose on the 12 ounce seems a bit more pronounced with a higher tone towards sweet, though there is a strong yeast presence as well. The 750 ml seems more muted, though I think matured might be a better term for it. I think I actually just got a whiff of strawberry?? Yeah. I think so. Strawberry and strawberry stems, and wet ones at that. I can see the same base for that smell on the 12 ounce, but it just hasnt "developed" to that point yet I think. 

Taste. The real test. The 12 ounce is smooth and yeasty with a touch of sweetness. Damn that is good. The 750 is muted. I am wondering if this is a bad bottle. Between the two, the 12 ounce seems to have a stronger flavor. The first thing that comes to mind is a 16 year old driving his first car (12 ounce bottle) and a 30 year old driving the love of his life to the place he is going to propose to her (750 ml bottle). Yeah. The 12 ounce is the hyper active kid, and the 750 is the more mature of the two. 

Mouthfeel on the 12 ounce is thick with carbonation and the 750 seems to be just a touch thinner. 

Drinkability. I think they are both on the same level. 

Overall this was an interesting expirement. I do however have to wonder if my 12 ounce bottle was overcarbonated and if that would effect this kind of "test". As the 750 bottle warmed, I have to say the flavors became more pronounced and overshadowed the 12 ounce bottle. Bottom line though - still a damn good beer.
YERM.  Spot on, damn near perfect tripel.  Definitely will be going after this one again, especially since my precious Golden Monkey isnt quite so common down here in Charlotte.
Nice light golden pour. Good thick head. Some fruit aromas are evident. The taste is subdued with a good balance. Nice sweetness.

What can I say? This is a good beer. Poured with nice head and lacing. Flavor was...subdued sweet. Sweet, but not overly so, lots of spices...with a hint of cloves. Mouthfeel was carbonated, but smooth (if that makes sense)...felt like little bubbles exploding in my mouth. Pretty darned good.

ok then theres this one...Home Run!!  well ok its just a triple, but an excellent one.Poured a cloudy yellow with a nice soapy head, subtle citrus and yeasty scents joined together to create the savory aroma. Real nice as it warms abit.The potent alcohol level is hidden very well with the great flavors that make this belgian like beer one of my favorites.( I have a few favorites)It was absolutley delightful. Have one today

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2008 Date: 08/10/1996
Mode: Bottle
Source: total beverage, DC

Appearance: slightly cloudy yelow, good head of tiny bubbles, good carbonation, 
Aroma: sweet and sour malt aroma with a hint of spicy hops, 
Flavor: deceptivaly light with slight sweetness and well balanced hop flavor and just a slight bitter aftertaste
-------- />
Date: 07/09/2008
Mode: bottle
Source: brick store

Appearance: cloudy yellow, fine white head, streaks of drippy lace, 
Aroma: sweet malt aroma, lots of spicyness, touch of bubblegum in the sweetness, light musty character, 
Flavor: dry malt flavor, lots of spicyness, touch of estery sweetness comes in to balance the spicy phoenolics, light balancing bitterness rises out of the spicyness, touch of black pepper

Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 12/20
Rating: 3.1/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: *4
355 ml bottle.  nice golden pour with white head.  strong alcohol, fruity smell.  sweet taste with hints of alcohol.
Excellent.  Powerful.  Yellow-orange color, off-white head, persistent w/nice lacing.  Fruity, spicy and delicious.   Yeasty.
Warning: This beer will cause extremely excruciating hangovers if not consumed wisely, you dont notice the alcohol under all that yeasty, citrus splashed goodness (its a bit heavy though).

Bottle. Yeasty aroma with hints of apple, melon and apricot going into a flavor with notes of citrus rind, white pepper and booze. long warming finish with alcohol present leading to dry and a lingering bitterness, but not in the way of other flavors. Fizzy body with good mouth feel. Very hazy golden with big bubbled lasting head A nice an authentic tripel, although a bit heavy for the style and leaning into strong ale territory.

750 mL bottle. One of my favorite beers. Lustrous white head that slowly gives way and allows the beautiful, slightly murky copper pour take over. Big, bold aroma of fruit and yeast accented by spice. Sits long and easy on the palate and goes down with a bit of booze. Whoever called the apple-wine note is exactly right. Very interesting beer. I love it.
I love this beer.  Hoppy.  A fruity/citrusy sorta hoppyness to it.  Its great.  The flavor is big.  Very nice indeed.  Smooth for a 9% beer.

citrusy hoppy in the spicey peppry sense. the very typical triple type flavors that we have come to expect. there is more than a touch of alcohol present. there is an nectarine and apple type winey taste that does not offend and neither impress. light malty semi caramel back note that balances it out. a finish that is dry and lingers. ok

Pours a light golden yellow with a thick white head. Aroma is yeasty and fairly boozy. Spices hit the nose next, nutmeg, clove, and corriander being the most obvious as well as a slight citrus aroma as well. Taste honestly is more of the same lots of yeast, alcohol, and spice. I have found that triples just dont do it for me. All seem unbalanced with heavy alcohol and yeast. This wasnt a terrible beer but nothing at all spectacular, just like every other triple Ive ever had. Sorry Triple fans.

Outstanding beer with a very unique flavor. Beautiful dark golden appearance with a persistent head. Almost a fruity aroma- very pleasant. Upon tasting, this beer provides a very appetizing and full flavor and sits well on the palate. Very rarely is a beer this widely available and yet still provides such a quality drinking experience.

after my beer tour of belgian this one had a lot to live up to... i was afraid it would be one  of those over sweetened tripels, but it balanced hoppiness nicely with fruit and caramel and a prickly texture... on par with decent belgian tripels

Pale orange in colour. Head quickly dissolves. Yeast peach and apricot on the nose. Tatse is spice(clove), alcohol and stonefruit. Quite dry finish. Very full mouthfeel. Overall impression: nice very! would drink again!

750 ml bottle.  Pours a large, thick head with a tan, pale, and cloudy appearance.  The smell is disappointlingly weak but there is a pleasant spicy smell.  The taste is very smooth, yeasty, and has hints of clove and orange.  FInish is a little too dry.  Because it tastes best going down, I will drink this again to complement food or cheese, but probably not drink a bottle standing alone.

12 oz bottle. Pours a cloudy pale yellow with a huge white head. Mouthfeel was bubbly. A fairly well carbinated brew. Taste was of yeast, banannas, cloves. A bit bread like. Almost like a hefe, only tart. Couldnt pick up on the alcohol even though its 9% abv.
Pours like champagne with a similar nose. Hazy Golden with a large but quickly dissapating white head.  Fruity upon first taste.  Alcohol very evident at finish.  Moderate carbonation.  Nice beer.

Bottle from BierKoning. Has an orange colour with healthy head and much carbonation. A sweet, citrusy and spicy nose. Fruity tastes of citrus, peach, orange -- and bitter too. Strongly carbonated with pop-pop mouthfeel. A long finish with first hints of its strong alcohol content. Ends with a blast. Superb.
Pours light copper.  The malt is big on both the palate and the aroma.  Very sweet in that nature.

12 oz. Bottle:
Aroma:  Yeasty and malty with undertones of spicy citrus.
Appearance: Hazy orange straw with a rocky head that lingers nicely with only minor lacing.
Flavor: Makes me feel like a monk.  Yeasty, bready, lightly bitter and dry.  There is a sweetness to it as well which makes for a wonderful balance.
Palate: The sweetness really comes out here first, yielding to a lingering dryness that stays with your mouth for a pleasant finish.
Overall:  Well done.  If you like your brews to remind of you living with monks on top of a mountain close to touching God then this is certainly close to being at "The End of the World".  A fine beer from Unibroue.

Poured a colden copper hue with silky, bubbling head.  Tasted sweet and dry and hid the alcohol quite nicely at 9%. Well-crafted multi-dimensional beer. Would make a great present for a special occasion (like the end of the world).

A hazy yellow orange color. Aroma is fruity apricots, oranges, tangerines, and peach, as well as yeast and spice. Flavor is those fruits, some clove, some spice, some alcohol, some mildewy flavors. Drinkable, fruity, and v ery carbonated.
Grand from start to finish, and a nice kick to it to boot. Great flavor and solid finish, changes character from the start of a sip to the finale. A really fine experience.
Bottle... golden yellow with a white head. Sweet mouthfeel with a slightly bitter finish. Nice beer.

Bottle. The cork pops out with a sound just like a pop-gun. Immediately, a wonderful spicy yeasty aroma fills my nostrils. Upon closer examination, hints of citrus, coriander, banana, and clove shine through. The aroma brings a wide smile to my face. The appearance is cloudy gold, with a full frothy just off-white head. The flavor is very peppery, with all the fruity and spicy notes of the aroma, this one is totally solid throughout. It finishes dry, with a very slight tart note. The mouthfeel is medium full, delicately carbonated, and the alcohol is nowhere to be found. Wonderful.

A very nice Abbey Trippel.  Very blonde, with an attractive appearance and nice head.  Fruity, strong, and smooth all at once in the mouth, and the finish is nice, with no aftertaste.  A reason to try others from Unibroue...

Bottle, pours a hazy amber with a large foamy off-white head. An orange citrus hop aroma with some sweet yeast. A fizzy mouthfeel with a tartish finish. The subtle flavours bring citrus and yeast. OK, but I dont pick it as high as some - maybe I need to give it a go in a better environment.

Rating 1800!! Bottle (750ml). I chose this Canadian classic for my 1800th rating because, well for one thing its a great beer, and also because I recently realized that Id never rated it -- I was quite surprised as Ive had it so many times that I just assumed I had rated it! Time to correct that with this milestone: Pours a lovely hazy yellow-gold with a large lasting foamy white head. Yeasty aroma with pepper and other spices along with some citrus and sweetness -- very nice. Sweet and spicy flavour of yeast, citrus, pepper, caramel malt, spices and much more -- complex and very flavourful. Some alcohol in the spicy, lightly bitter finish but for 9% it hides the alcohol very well. Medium to full bodied, nice carbonation. Even though I initially forgot to rate this beer, I never fully forget it, and when I see some in the dépanneur in Quebec I always buy some as I believe its one of the finest Tripels in the world -- a truly fantastic beer.

Orange golden with a weak head and nice lace. The aroma has notes of yeast and coriander and the mouthfeel is full. The flavour is very sweet and you arent in doubt - its a strong beer. It has notes of ripe fruit, and its fairly bitter and slightly acidic in the long finish.

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2008 Bottle as shown. Pours a cloudy orange/golden color with a small white head the diminshes quickly. The aroma is a spicy fruit of banana and light hops.  The taste is a mouthfull of fruit and honey with a sweet finish, another great brew from Unibroue.
UPDATED: AUG 3, 2007 Visually this is one stunning beer.  Aroma is generally is fruit and spices.  Corriander, malt, and citrus on the mouthfeel. vanilla on the finish.

Drank this one on a very hot and steamy Tokyo Afternoon in a dark bar in the suburb of Shimokitazawa.   Was surprised to note the high Alc. content on reading the label as it slipped down quite easily. Couldnt really tell what the colour was like as  the bar was dimly lit but got a strong fruity-malt flavor from this.   Had a second bottle of this and liked it just as much.  Keen to try more from the Unibroue outfit,  this really is an impressive brew.
Cloudy yellow gold color with ample white head.  Spicy wheat aroma with notable oranges.  Citrus flavor in the wheat body with a dry hop finish.

750 ml bottle into a goblet.  Pours a light gold with thick but rapidly diminishing white head.  Aroma is dominated by tropical fruits and light spice.  Phenolic, spicy taste with some hop bitterness.  Finishes very dry and refreshing.

Bottle, pours a cloudy, pale orange-yellow with white head.  Aroma is a little sour with oranges and wheat.  Nice, light citrus flavor with some maltiness.  Body is light, but is not watery.  Slight hop finish at the end.

A semi-opaque orange ginger-ale colored body topped with a small thin white head, minimal lacing. Aroma is that of spicy wheat and fruits. The alcohol is prominent in the taste, but doesnt overpower the fruit-sweet malts. The body is thick and sweet with a big pepper/cloves aftertaste that creeps up on you.

(Bottle) Pours an orange color with very little head. Aroma of sugar, yeast, and some light spice. Good palate, with a robust malty backbone. Some fruit and alcohol warming as well. The only thing I didnt like about this beer is the slight cidery aftertaste, which is probably due to the blend of flavors. Otherwise, a great beer.

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2008 Pours brilliant yellow-orange with white, frothy head which quickly dissipates.  Aroma of spice, straw and orange.  Big, silky malt flavor.  Finishes dry with melon and maybe some coriander.

Pours an orangy yellow color with a moderate sized foamy head. Smells like a hefeweizen (german wheat and plsner malt) With lots of yeast. Mouthfeel is honey like with a little bit of sting on the end. Tastes like honey and fruit and malt. Pretty good.

Bottle. Looks weak due to this pale milky orange - amber color. Aroma however is quite nice - at first I got what I thought was a  chocolaty orange aroma but really it is more of oranges and plums with a lot of spices like ginger. Flavor is much the same which is a good thing. Sweet fruits such as oranges offset by more darker fruits such as plums and all mixed well with the spices. No mention of the alcohol anywhere so it really is amazingly good, The appearance is the weakest element.

Once every few months, I treat myself to this fantastic beer.  This is such a refined beer that my wife and I drink it out of wine glasses, just as it was served to us at the brewery in Montreal.    My very favorite!

The problem with many of Unibroue beers is that they just dont have the robustness to support the  alcohol content. This one has lovely appley and yeasty aromas. Some good spice, but not to the extent in Trois Pistoles and Maudite. However, it is marred by medicinal aftertaste. Its too thin and watery to be at 9% alcohol.
UPDATED: JAN 2, 2008 as much as i enjoyed the trois pistoles i actually liked this one a little better.  its not as thick and dark but its still a very good beer.

Pours a beautiful golden-orange typical of abbey tripels with a nice white head.  Aroma is the typical mix of sugar, spice, and banana notes.  The taste is predominantly fruity, with banana notes, as well as sweetness added to the overall wonderful experience of this beer.  One of my favorite tripels, great job Unibroue.
Bottle.  Pours hazy golden orange.  Aroma is of yeast, alcohol and a touch banana.  Taste is sweet without a lingering finish.
Pours a golden mixed hue. Sweet aroma of an old pub.  Cloves, coriander and bubble gum are well balanced on a solid alcohol driven base.  A very contemplative beer.

UPDATED: DEC 5, 2008 Rerate from a bottle stolen from a friend of my sisters.  Not going to alter my rating a bit as my previous rating was pretty much the same.  
Bottle,  poured a clear orange and gold,  with a  thick white head.  Aroma of yeast, spice, fruit, and banana.  Flavor was much of the same, with some alcohol and sweetness.  Very enjoyable.

Sweet!!! Is how Id describe La Fin.  The fermentation off-flavors are well balanced with the alcohol but its sweet I fond it hard to finish the whole bottle, not what the belgians would call digestable
classic triple in every way.  appearance and flavor are equal to that of a top belgian triple.  definitely the best non-belgian triple i have had, by far

Nice hazy, light orange color with great thick white head.  Spicy, yeasty aroma; alchohol is prominent.  Coriander, cloves and honey on the palate with lingering, slightly metallic, alcohol finish.  Nicely carbonated.  Very enjoyable.

pours clear gold with thick that slowly dissipates.  aroma is spicy with good amounts of banana, pear, and alcohol.  taste is spicy and tangy with good amounts of fruit.  sweetness is there but not to prominent.  finish is tangy spicy  bitter.  decent stuff.

pours clear gold with thick that slowly dissipates.  aroma is spicy with good amounts of banana, pear, and alcohol.  taste is spicy and tangy with good amounts of fruit.  sweetness is there but not to prominent.  finish is tangy spicy  bitter.  decent stuff.

Hazy golden-blond color, with booming, faomy white head.  Yeasty, bread notes (almost like a freash baked pizza?!) on the nose as well as bananas and some citrus scents.  Rounded, full-bodied with yeasty flavors, liight citrus notes; grassy with a spicey clovieness.  A very nice beer indeed.

Cloudy orange-gold color with a large white head and some lacing.  Aroma is very yeasty, with strong citrus and spice notes.  Taste is like a sweet citrus explosion.  Corriander, cloves, brown sugar, and yeast are all very prominent.  Very effervescent on the tongue.  Only downfall is the sweetness, which is excessive in my opinion.  Syrupy body makes for a heavy drink.  Very similar to the Chimay Blanche.

Ey! Be careful when opennign it! This yeast had a lot of sugar/maltose to eat when it was bottled. After messing my table with the foam that came out of the bottle right after opening it I had a really nice experience. Really nice toated color, big bubble foam yeasty smell and taste. I liked it very much. If something bad were to say, I guess it would be the excess of yeast flavour.

(Bottle, Monks Café, Stockholm) Pale orange colour with huge, white head leaving lots of lacing. Fruity nose with fresh notes of apricots, oranges, pineapple, spicy hops and a hint of yeast. Fruity taste with tropical fruit (pineapple, mango), yeast, spicy hops and a warming alcohol bite in the finish.  A bit sweet, but tasty, warming and nice.

A lovely Belgian Blonde, oh wait this beer is from Canada. Those Canadians have hit the nail on the head with this clean, smooth beer. It pours a cloudy gold with a beautiful off-white head that billowed up in the glass. The head settles quickly into a ring that does its best to cling to the glass. I have had this beer several times, and sometimes it laces beautifully, other times there is barely any. But, at the end of this glass you are left with a clean beer that displays light maltiness to round out the flavor.
Apples, pears, subdued spices, yeast in the nose. Smoothe taste, minimal sour. Heavy on the light fruits. Juicey apples, some yeast, some banana. Finishes with bitter and sour.

Bottle. Cloudy, medium yellow/gold appearance with an interesting and unusual hint of pink or red. Spice-first nose shows predominantly citrus peel (orange and lemon) and cardamon, plus amazing further complexity with layers of lemongrass, nutmeg, mint, carrot and cardboard. Lively palate with alcoholic thickness reminds us this is a 9% alc./vol. beer. Spicy citrus peel/cardamon flavour is both interesting and refreshing while some malt kicks in for balance. Bitter burst of alcohol arrives at the end, and a slight aftertaste of steel. A complex beer that invites conversation among friends.

Sweet aroma with noticeable alcohol presence. Pours with a huge meringue head that settles down to a ring. Apricot color. Flavor consists of overripe banana, cloves, yeast, dates. Lightly carbonated with lingering bitter, floral finish. Great sipping beer with pleasant alcohol warmth.
pours a cloudy pale orange amber with a medium thin head. an aroma and taste of pear apples and tart lemon, with a nice yeast and grassy maltiness to it

Bottle.  Excellent fragrance - citrus & hops.  Color was nothing special:  light + cloudy.  Soda like carbonation.  Tasted of citrus, vanilla & hops - real good.  Will try again [@ Porter House, White Plains NY]

UPDATED: MAY 21, 2009 old rating 4/3/4/2/8 - 2.1

pours a cloudy orange-yellow with a large white head that goes away quickly, and some lacing.

smell is of bread yeast, citrus, some fruit, lawn clippings, spice and white pepper.

taste is dry, fizzy, yeast, some fruits, spice, and a touch of citrus, ends dry and a little bitter.

Light yellow, small head.  Somewhat tangy, just short of citrusy.  it goes down very smooth.  it wont be a revelation if youve had some belgian strong ales but it will be something youll buy again at some point.

OoooOOooOO. This is nice. I tried it at Opals last weekend and was really impressed. I liked the citrus/malt mix, and picked up on apricot, nectarine, and caramel. Went and bought a four pack at Grapevine. Nice job. You sold me.

Pours golden yellow with a big billowy head into the wrong type of glassware.  Smell is light and yeasty.  The taste is sweet and relatively mild.  Good drinkable brew.  Quite nice overall.  Thanks Liz.

Poured a cloudy golden color with some sediment evident.  Head was ample and fluffy, leaving behind thick, sheetlike lacing.  The aroma was a gentle blend of buttery caramel, sugar and soft fruits like pear and banana.  Not much spice noted.  The flavor was more sweet than spice.  Bready and sugary with a bit of tartness coming through from the fruit right before the hops came through and gave it a nice clean finish.  Alcohol wasnt noted at all.  Incredibly drinkable, not as assertive as St. Bernardus, but very nice.
Pours a cloudy gold, a good amount of carbonation.  Alcohol comes through very slightly.  Flavor is complex, slightly sweet.

12oz bottle, served in a tulip. Pours with a huge, gigantic, enormous, larger than life fluffy white head. Takes about 15 minutes to finally get all of the beer in the glass, then another 5 or so for the head to settle enough to drink. Golden body with a very lively carbonation display. Sheets of white lacing cling to the sides of the glass. Aromas of funky yeasts, candied sugars, peaches, pears, spices.  Flavors of peaches, sugars, sweet malts, spices, and some sour notes. Palate is slightly sticky but not overdone. Light to medium bodied on the tongue, finishes slightly dry, sweet and silky smooth. the alcohol is very well hidden, and as a result makes this beer dangerously drinkable. Excellent.
Bottle at Rudyards. Golden color with good amount of bubbles and carbonation. Big head. Nose of peach and pear. Taste is similar, but with some breadyness. Good beer.
Dark amber color, nice cream-colored head, tastes of clove and fig.  Sweet but not too sweet.
holy carbonation. very fruity. cloudy amber. well hidden alcohol. i am very happy with this. corked beers are always fun.

750 mL bottle.  Golden amber with champagne bubbles and a fluffy white head.  Aroma of pear, honey, and spices.  Sticky sweet and lively palate.  Tastes of pear, apple, clove, and honey with a smooth finish.

bottle: pours a hazy gold colour with a large foamy lively head. aroma is sweet and yeasty with fruity apricot and sugar. mouthfeel is very lively and crisp. the flavour is is sweet with notes of yeast, and some fruit and breadiness also. overall very good and hard to believe it is 9%.

Sampled at Mondial de la Biere. Last beer of the fest. Had that familiar belgian yeast flavor. Its not bad, but I was getting a bit bored with it after tasting their other offerings. A good solid beer though, nice carbonation, light bitterness. Id have it again.

A Mes rate: 
Bottle at my Local. Cloudy golden colour with a decent white head. Sweet peachy milk in the nose. Flavour is similar with way too much sugar. Sticky and just sickly sweet. Only got through half the glass before I gave up. Could quite easily make me ill.

Translucent amber with a thick head with good lacing. Yeasty, fruity aroma. There is a peach/apricot element to the aroma and taste intertwined with grain and sweet lemon. Pleasant mouthfeel. A good Belgian style triple.

Great beer!  Hints of fruit and wheat.  I can barely taste the 9% alcohol.  Good head with lots of armoa.  Goes down smooth with adequate aftertaste.  Perfect for a hot day.  Ive never heard of a refreshing 9% beer, until now.

750ml bottle - Pale orange in color with a nice head that gradually falls to a thin,  lasting film on top of this magnificent brew.  The aroma is of oranges and pear, and a slight alcohol note, but not as atrong as I would have expected from a 9% ABV beer.  The first sip begins a crescendo of complex, fruity symphonies, followed by notes of spicy clove and coriander, and some caramel sweet maltiness that I find very enjoyable.  A  miniscule amount of hop bitterness in the dry finish, but not very strong.  Surprisingly light on alcohol flavor; its there, but not nearly to the degree that is found in some beers that I have tried that are lower in alcohol.  Remarkably easy to drink, but with such a high alcohol content, watch out!  With such complex flavors in every quaff, I am sure I have found a new favorite beer.  This will always be in my refrigerator.  I really need to come up with a clone recipe for this!  Merci, Unibroue!  Jaime La Fin du Monde!
Robe blonde voilée surmontée dune mousse blanche mince. Arômes de levures, de blé et de bananes. Saveurs de bananes, de levures, dalcool et de citron. Texture crémeuse.

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2008 Bottled 33cl. It pours a hazy dark orange beer with a average whitish head. Yeasty, slightly peppery fruity aroma. Peaches and oranges in the nose. Malty and tart. Nothing really special or overwhelming about the nose. It reminds me slightly of "Don de dieu",  but with less peach elements. Some leathery aromas emerge, but just very faintly. The fruitiness (oranges) dominates clearly. A whiff of coriander. A very mild fruity taste. Again, some coriander, nice malt flavor with some almonds. The spiciness wasn t that present to my surprise... Some cloves. Very enjoyable caramel flavors! There are some Pumpernickel elements, I agree. A fruity and very yeasty beer. Dry, alcoholic finish. I didnt enjoy this Unibroue too much. The maudite is clearly a beer I enjoyed much more...  Slightly inferior to "don de dieu". Additional comment: (rerate): A good beer. Enjoyable, but nothing special. All the typical Unibroue elements showing up. Unfortunately some vitamin tablet-characteristic appearing.

hazy yellow colour. aroma is fruity, apple, pear and some lemon. Taste is unique like all unibroue beers. Is it the yeast? Don´t know.. but body in this beer is unique, specially for a 9% alcohol.. you don´t notice. Very good beer.

As my first rating, I felt I owed it to what is the greatest beer Ive ever had.  The aroma was very fruity, notes of citrus.  The flavor hits you immediately, a nice crescendo of malty, spicy hops.  For a 9% beer, the alcohol flavor is not noticeable at all.  The head pours a nice thick white, my only complaint would be the lack of lacing, blends back very rapidly.  In a class of champions, La Fin Du Monde stands as the Champion amongst champions.

Jungle Jims Second Spring Beer Fest
5/12/2007:  Unibroue La Fin Du Monde has a hazy yellow color with a large, fluffy white head.  The aroma and flavor contain pale malts, fruit (apple, citrus), and some spicy notes.  This beer also tastes stong, but the alcohol stays well-hidden.  This beer is medium-light in body with a generous level of carbonation and thus a lively mouthfeel.  Unibroue makes some fantastic beers and this is just one of them from their respectable repertoire!

Sampled from a 750 ml corked and caged bottle (9% ABV).

Bottle. Fluffy white but relatively high and lasting head. Hazy yellow body with a good deal of carbonation. Acidic aroma of grapefruit with a touch of spices. Pretty powerful grapefruit like flavour with spicy notes and a hint of the alcohol. Well balanced though.  Long and hoppy aftertaste.

Pours a nice gold with a thick, fluffy white head. Good head retention. Big time carbonation. Massive citrus on the nose. Taste of orange, apple, plum, and slight spice. Very good finish. Good beer, but just a little bit too much carbonation.
Hazy dark golden color iwth a thick off white head.  Aroma of bananas, pears and apples.  Taste of pepper and citrus with some malt.  Another slam dunk by Unibroue.

The beer pours a slighly hazy amber with a good thick head that leaves lacing down the side of the glass. The aroma is nice, tart though a bit metallic. the flavor is sweet throughout with a bit of a tingle on the finish. The esters in the beer are very noticable, and enjoyable.

Pours a hazy apple juice gold, with a nice frothy white head. The nose is heavy yeast, pear, apple and spice (coriander?). The mouthfeel is medium-bodied and lively while remaining quite smooth. The flavor is fruity sweet, tasting of pears and yeast with a lightly peppery alcohol finish. This beer has nice blend of flavors that only intensify in their complexity as it warms. Quite tasty.

Rated 10/8/06:  Was able to pick up a four pack instead of the bombers which are typically offered. Sampled this on a few separate nights and had a couple tonight before, during, and after dinner. Im a fan of Unibroues darker Belgian Styles but this is an excellent Tripel and quite possibly my new favorite of their brews. Strong malty aroma with a nice earthiness and spicy accents. Great pour, orange-yellow dark in the middle and lighter around the edges with a monster of a head. This beer couldnt be smoother and a pleasant finish with a slight alcohol burn is perfect for me. Hearty flavor huge malt presence with some spicy goodness. Slight citrus tops off a marvelous brew. Overall this is near the top on my list.
Cloudy yellow with a good white head.  Fruity orangish aroma.  Fruity orangish taste.  Smooth but not refreshing. Fades well.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2009 Rerate: 3-29-09.

Clear straw yellow, effervescent, frothy crackling head. Distinctive tripel aroma, banana, clove, general fruity esters. Light spritzy texture, alcoholic zing, slightly bitter finish. I havent had a beer like this in a while, or any tripel for that matter. A little nostalgic for me. Tasty but seems somewhat simple now. The main thing holding this back is the alcohol content, the carbonation, and the bitterness, not to say it isnt meant to be like this.

Orig. rating: 5-18-07.

Quite cloudy hazy yellow body, large white head. Incredibly aromatic - peach, apple crisp. Theres something about tripels that always hits the spot for me, and this is no exception. Typical fruity tripel flavor. Very nice. Some spicy/bitter in the finish.

9 4 8 4 16

Bottle @ Københavnske Øldage 2007 in Copenhagen. Clear light yellow amber color with a small frothy fair lacing mostly diminishing white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy yeasty, fruit, spices. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and light bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Bottled (Thanks heemer77). Hazy yellow colour, mediumsized lasting white head. Aroma is fruit, some yeast, hops and spices. Flavour is slight alcohol, yeast, caramel malts and some slight hints of hops. Overall quite acidic, but yet it is very wellbalanced and pleasant. Aftertaste has some fudgeish/toffeeish hints.

Bottle. Pours a hazy golden orange with a large long lasting white head that leaves good lacing. Aroma of citrus, banana, clove, and yeast spice. Taste is the same as aroma. Medium mouthfeel with a good amount of carbonation and mild bitterness. A very good Tripel.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2008 341ml Bottle. Pours a really nice hazy-orange colour, with a massive head that refuses to leave (and provides a strong think lacing on the glass)........waiting waiting waiting........slightly sweet aroma of various fruits and yeast, surprisingly little hint of alcohol considering the content. The flavour hits pretty hard, not as much yeast as the aroma made it seem, definite burn that lets you know it is in fact 9% alcohol, the various fruit flavours make it pretty complex and difficult to pick apart, but theres still some good malty sweetness evident. Finishes strong, very strong actually, with a similar burn to that of brandy or cognac. Pretty enjoyable up until the harsh alcohol burn, but I guess some people like that. Actually as it warms it gets sweeter which is definitely a plus. Im putting away the rest of my 6-pack to let the bottles age, just to see what will happen. After ONE year: Already a big difference! Much more complex fruitiness, some more delicious elements such as peach. Darker in colour too, I poured it at first without the yeast, so it looked like Duvel, then the sediment came, looking browner than I remember, but the yeasty flavour is increased, and tasty. It seems to be coming along well.

Bottle at Old Post Office Winery in Pullman, Wa.  Huge head.  Orange/rust color.  Great flavor, almost felt like i was chewing it.  Citrus tones, sweet but packed a zip to it.  Taste is delicate, evolves in your mouth.

Bottle, courtesy Sunskates. Thanks bro. Hazy yellow gold with a coarse layer of white that head that refuses to go away. Heavily over-ripe fruit aroma--the dumpster behind a fruit stand on a hot day. Warm, vulgar, but kind of appealing at the same time. Deeper in there is tart pie apple, cinnamon, rough cognac. For all the riot to the nose, the flavor is fairly delicate. Clove, cinnamon, apple, peach, given some bite by the bright carbonation. Light body for the abv, with just a bit of heat around the edges. This is a beer that wants to be loved or hated. I want to love it, but Im not sure I feel good being around such sketchy characters. This beer would steal a £20 off your table when you werent looking.

Bottled (BB 09/2008)
Orange color, small off-white head. Fruity yeasty aroma - there is at least mango, banana and orange, quite typical American-Belgium style nose. Very crisp carbonated mouthfeel. Orange zesty, fruity, only a bit yeasty flavor. Sweetish tripel which hides its ABV very well. Light alcohol in the aftertaste, almost watery too as fruityness fades away, but good one anyway.

Dull amber/dark gold color, slightly cloudy.  In short, an outstanding belgian tripel style beer, and one of my staple favorites.  Near perfect balance of sweet and sour.  After much research, 750ml bottle seems to taste better than the 12oz.  Best slightly chilled or cold.  My only complaint (and its a small one) is that the carbonation seems a bit excessive - quickly remedied or course by pouring out a slightly larger head after opening.  Good stuff!

I enjoyed this tripel styled ale from Canada this evening. I noted the huge foamy head that need time to settle before I could taste it.  One breath after another, I inhaled it to get a sense it was like any Belgian tripel with a sense of sour fruits, sweet malt, and lively yeast.
It tasted just like the aroma projected in a very clean and big flavor.

750 ml bottle.  Pours a medium golden amber with a course white head.  Intense spice and fruit noise with notable apricot, peach and lemon notes.  Noise carries over into the body with an explosion of tastes.  Fruits and spices coupled with a dry snappy finish highlight this remarkable tripel.

Cold 12oz bottle:  Pours a hazy bright orange color with a large persistent fluffy ivory head.  Aroma is of nice yeast, light grains, light fruits, spice and honey.  Taste is pretty much the same, but has grassy hops and a distinct lemon note to it.  Light to medium bodied and smooth with playful carbonation.  Ending is dry with notes of light grains and fruit, and a moderate alcohol burn.

Bottle.Thick white head.Light cloudy orange color.Spicy citrus honey aroma.Clove and soft bitter fruit flavor.Smooth.Chewy.The alcohol content isnt apparent in the taste but it is apparent shortly thereafter.This is very good.I could enjoy a few of these.Just not all at once.

This is one of the tasteiest beer ive drinked, even though at first I thought the taste would eventualy get on my nerve, it wasnt the case. As the beer warms up the beer gets sweeter and gets even better. I even was a little tipsy in the end, a great beer to start a day with.

Yeasty dark bread.  Hazy golden/amber color.  Wonderful long lasting head. Hints of honey, citrus and almonds in the flavor.  Has a certain sweetness at the end.  Best if chilled, flavor seems to dissipate upon warming.  I would do this one again.

750 ml bottle. Hazy golden orange with some visible carbonation in the center if you looked hard enough and a huge white head. I was a little suprised that there was barely any lacing left on my glass. Aroma changed significantly throughout this beer it started with classic belgian style, spicy yeast, and as it warmed fruity, banana and lemon, and towards the end sweetness, candy and bubblegum. Flavor was smooth and drinkable with notes of yeast, lemon and banana. Great beer on a beautiful day, life is good.

Bottle. Hazy dull gold color.  Frothy white head , carbonation hard to see.  Citrus and honey aroma with a spicy tinge.  Banana/Orange flavor and a spicy alcohol overtone.  Both malt and hops take a back seat in this style, which is preferred.  This beer is like a belgian white on steroids.  Pleasant overall.  Bubbly light palate but not watery.  If youre looking for a powerful (alcohol) beer that goes down relatively easy La Fin Du Monde is an ideal choice.

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2008 This one was yummy. Initial aroma was a lemony sourness followed by a small hint of doughiness. As it warmed I got a big banana aroma. The aroma was fantastic and complex with nearly something different with each new smell. It poured a murky dark yellow with a huge off-white frothy head that stayed. Lacing was good. Taste was slightly sweet, acidic and bitter. This is a very well made Trpel! Medium bodied with lively carbonation. Very refreshing for such a big beer and well balanced.

This is wonderful beer. Its muddy gold appearance and grey sediment doesnt do it justice. The aroma is multi-faceted: carrot, salt, butter, soft cheese, yeast, honey, treacle tart. Something new every time you go back to your glass.  Taste is sweet, yeasty, sour, leathery, fruity. Banana, creme caramel, malt: the pleasures are endless. As I rate I still have another three centimetres to enjoy...
This is how you do a triple.  Unibroue is proving again and again that Canada DOES have something worth exporting

Delish....pours with a three finger white head.   You can hear the carbonation.  Tastes like I am drinking out of an island fruit basket.  One of the best tripels I have ever had.  Alcohol well hidden.  My first Unibroue...why did I wait so long?! Heading to the liquor store tomorrow to pick up some more.

A very yeasty smell, but the taste is some what sweet, and you could never tell that this beer is 9% alc. by the taste. The buzz yes, but not the taste. A very great tasting beer. It taste so much better then the Victory Triple Ale called Golden Monkey, which has the same acl. content as the Du Monde Highly Recommended!

4 pack- 12 oz.  Aroma is a tripel right away- sour, yeasty, good.  Hazy orange, head dissipated, but nice lacing.  A lot of carbonation.  For some reason I find that banana is the dominant flavor.  Fruity bitterness at the end, but still smooth, which is why I like this one.  So much complexity here- one of my favorite tripels.

750ml bottle. Pours a cloudy amber with a nice fluffy head. Aroma is sweet with notes of fruits, spices and some hops. The flavour is also sweet with a primarily fuity taste. nice aftertaste, you can taste the alcohol, but its not overwhelming and i think it only adds to the taste of this great beer.

341 mL bottle.  Pours hazy blonde.  Aroma is of banana, toffee, and some pear.  Flavour is quite sweet, with some fruity sour notes as well.  Warming mouthfeel due to high alcohol content and carbonation.  Pretty nice overall.

Bottle:  Cloudy light body with plenty of white head.  Sour aroma with tart apple, citrus, and pear notes.  Alcohol very present in the nose.  This beer makes sure you know its a tripple.  Actually, it beats you over the head with this fact in just about every aspect.  Very tart and sour, with lots of yeast, apple and alcohol.  What really sets this one apart for me was the mouthfeel, as silky smooth as Ive ever had, yet still manages to be crisp.  Deserves all the accolades it receives.
Big head, fruity aroma. Sweet taste reminded me of a cream soda. Very silky feel. Alcohol is well hidden. Another outstanding brew from Unibroue.
This beer would be great if the abv was a little less. The alcohol stiffles the true taste of the beer. The best part is the sediments at the bottom which adds nice texture and flavor. Disapointing.

Pours hazy gold, fluffy white head.  Aroma is tangy, tart, slightly brassy, apricot fruit notes, slight mustiness underneath.  Flavor is tangy, blue cheese, and tart fruit with a veil of mustiness that balances everything nicely.  Fairly crisp tasting.

UPDATED: APR 15, 2007 This beer pours a nice hazy yellow color with a great head.  The smell is tremendous, and the beer doesnt disappoint.  What an excellent triple!  They know how to do it at Unibroque.

This beer pours a golden yellow with a nice head, but the head almost vanishes into thin air. I liked that head. The beer is nice and cloudy. Very fruity, but the bite is not what I was expecting. I like the Trois Pisotles version better. Has a nice fruity smell, and looks like a yellow fruit basket in my glass. Bananas, lemons, and maybe some grapefruit. A delicious beer with a great ABV. This beer was nice and bubbly with a great yeast taste to warm me up at the end. Good beer.

Pours with large fuffy head that dies quickly. Smells sweet, of ripe fruits.  Tastes of banana, oranges. Maybe a bit too much carb?  Ends with a crispness.  

I must try the rest of the Unibroue lineup now if this is a good representation of their brews!

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2007 bottle from uto. After having the Don de Dieu, I couldnt wait to tuck into this one. Amber with a short lived white head and a consistent fine sediment. Very similar to the Don in aroma and taste. Amazing nose of sweet, ripened fruit nectar - cantaloupe, pineapple, mango and peach. Reminds me of Jumex - a thick, lush Mexican juice made with exotic fruits. The light rum-like alcohol edge gives it the character of a mixed drink. Full aroma, without being heavy or overly sweet. It makes for a nice alternative to the standard Belgian nose. Taste to match, but with the addition of honey and stronger hints of alcohol. Long finish of pineaple, passion fruit and warming alcohol. Full bodied and very smooth. Lip smacking good. I think I love Unibroue.
Nice white head and simple golden color.  Smells of spices and has excellent slavor and a smooth finish.  Alcohol gives a nice warming sensation.  unfiltered.  4 pack of 11 oz bottles.

Bouteille. Arome de levure et dagrumes. Belle couleur blonde-orangée, voilée. Mousse abondante, mais sefface assez rapidement en laissant une mince couronne.  Goût complexe dalcool, de malt de blé, de levure, dagrumes et dépices. Effervescence forte, mais se marie bien avec les saveurs en bouche. Corps épais. Arrière-goût malté et épicé avec un léger goût alcoolisé.

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2007 Typical fruity qualities of a Belgian triple, predominantly banana and orange.  Slightly too  much carbonation, detracts from flavor of beer.  Does not quite compare to the Tripel Karmeliet, but a fine brew nonetheless. 
::::::::::Dec 24::::::::::
Had this one after Boulevards Tripel and was impressed with how refined and clear it tasted after the latter.

UPDATED: APR 21, 2009 341 mL bottle.  Another beer that used to terrify me doesnt seem all that frightening any more.  Translucent orange with huge head that quickly dissipates into something more manageable.  Aroma is spicy, with fresh fruit and bread.  Taste is full, with just a hint of alcohol.  It is honey sweet, with a bit of banana/cloves, white pepper, and alcohol.  Tangy citrus and bitter hops on the finish.  Nice.

Very fruity. Very carbonated. White head was big, but diminished quickly. Unfiltered. This beer was very complex, almost too much for me. For the style of brew, this beer was awesome. Ill have to have another.

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a Duvel tulip glass, cloudy yellow golden with a huge white head. (Perhaps an aggressive pour.) Aroma was of sweet citrus fruit, yeast and spice. The taste was very sweet with notes of lemon, orangle peel and other citrus fruits. There were notes of cinnamon, clove and perhaps some banana. Creamy mouthfeel. Little alcohol up front, but it did become more apparent as it warmed. This one reminded me of a hefeweizen like Paulaner, only spicier and sweeter. This one really hit the spot and its not even from Belgium. Heresy? Well see if it holds up on the re-rate.
bottle . . pours cloudy amber with a strong white head . . aroma is spices/ oranges/ wheat/ bananas . . taste is apricot, bananas, alcohol, sweet, alcohol . . grassy . . not bad!  has some complexity

A nice tripel but not quite in the same class as the Tripel Karmeliet.  To my palate, not quite as bold as their Maudite or Trois Pistoles beers, but a pleasant and unique flavor.  Would like to try on tap-- only had from bottle.

Bottled cork & wire: A hazy light golden beer, with an initially enormous bubbly and frothy white head that fades to a single finger. Aroma has evident crystal malt, fruity notes of apples, musty yeast, sweet honey and an herbal hint. Has a very bubbly mouthfeel. Flavor is sweet upfront, with lots of honey, apples, green grapes. Later flavors develop spicyness (white pepper). Subtle banana notes are also there. The finish is lightly herbal, warming and spicy. This stuff is definitly spicy and warming, yet the alcohol is well hidden in the flavor. A decent Tripel.
Pours golden-orange and hazy.  Aroma is spicy and fresh.  Flavor is peachy and maby some corriander.  Nice tripel.

Poured into tuliip glass. Enormous head took several minutes to die down. Aroma is sweet fruit and huge musty yeast. Taste is banana, cloves, pineapple, white pepper and alcohol. Very sweet. The comparison to cake batter is not unwarranted. Mouthfeel is smooth and carbonation is just right. Very drinkable, although I think two would do it for me in a session due to the ABV. Very interesting, very pleasant beer.
Pale orange color with a small head. Aroma is fruity. Taste is sweet, malt and yeasty. Notes of pepper and hops.

This had a good head.Murky from all the active fermentation.Straw color.Aroma was of fresh cut grass with orange peel infused.Flavor was of fermented orange and biting yeasty,wheat.Not really the type of beer I favor ,but it is well balanced and well-made.Finishes bitter.palate was about average.Not my kind of beer,but it is somewhat complex and interesting.Someone should like it.
excellent attention to detail.  very malty, chocolaty peanut butter taste, light sweet and full of fullfillingness.  great copper color

poured a hazed goldy orange with a nice fluffy head.  very big beer in terms of feel, fruits and spices.  Lots going on and I like it and want more.  ABV is hiding in this one.  Lots of peeps recomend this and now I know why
My least favorite of the Unibroue line but still good.  A nice gold color but a little musty.  Leaves a nice citrus finish.
Wow, pours a hazy golden, somewhat lemon colored, forming a large white foam head.  Aroma of lemons, yeast, and wet forrest.  Flavor was of biscuity ale.
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text: Bottle. Pours a hazy orange with a big white head. A sweet malty aroma with some fruit and spice as well.  Some yeast and citrus flavors and then it quickly becomes dry with a sweet finish. Very carbonated. B

(33 cl bottle from Systembolaget, ordering section) Hazy orange color, small white head. Spicy yeasty fruity choriander scent. Spritzy sweet yeasty taste, acidic. Sweet aftertaste. Spritzy mouthfeel, low bitterness. Also apricot aroma.

Nice....Very nice. bottle, high carbonation, yellowy orange color. Big belgium taste for a beer brewed in Canada. Orange juice flavor typical of the style, big boozyness lost in all the great taste. Pick it up if it is near you.

Light golden with a big white head. Citrusy, spicy, yeasty aroma. Sweet and spicy taste, not as much of the fruityness I expected. Distinct notes of honey and cloves. Wonderful flavor really, but short alcoholic finish detracts.

(Bottle, thanks Gnoff) Pours hazy orange. Very spicy and citric aroma with lemon, Seville oranges, sourish apples and alot of yeast. Full spicy flavour with coriander and citrus fruits tones. Medium sweet. Spicy, numbing, lingering aftertaste. Rather clean, medium body. A very nice tripel.

Bottle (33 cl). Pours clody deep golden, almost orange. Spicy aroma with notes of hay and honey, and a yeasty touch, of course. Well carbonated. The finish is too sweet, unbalanced and alcoholic for my taste.
golden/orange color. very large frothy head.  malty aroma with nice levels of spice and fruitiness.  very carbonated mouthfeel. yeasty& spicy flavor. well disguised 9%. very good overall
Bottle.  Sweet malty aroma.  Big frothy white head.  Flavor is rich maltiness with sweet honey accents and spiciness.  Golden color with murky opaque quality.  Creamy palate with good carbonation.

A pale amber orange coloured beer with a thick white head. A spicy, citrusy nose, with a bready malt aroma, and a hint of caramel. A fizzy mouthfeel is followed by a dry taste, citrusy, then bready and malty with a spiciness, like aniseed and clove, and even a hint of chilli (!?!). Alcoholic and a little soapy in the end, leading to a dry and spicy finish. (Bottle - purchased from The Beers of Europe, Setchey, Norfolk for £2.19 a bottle).

341 ml bottle - pours an opaque honey with some lightness at the edges and bottom and a huuuuuuuge white head.  One of the biggest heads Ive seen on a beer, even when poured at a trickle.  Aroma of yeast/bread, some citrus and spice, and the flavour continues this but is more pronounced, especially with the spiciness.  Beautiful.  Delicate carbonation, a nice round mouthfeel, and a long finish all contribute to an excellent beer.  Bravo!  One of the very few beacons of hope available in the Ontario beer market.

750ml bottle poured in a trappist glass.  Pours a light golden with a fluffy white head.  A lot of bubbles rising to the top.  Smell is great with yeast and fruits.  Malty with a warmness from the alcohol, which you can detect more than other Triples Ive had.  This is good but the flavor is lacking complexity and kick to put it over the edge.

A good tripel by our neighbors in Canada, eh? Aroma of yeast and fruit. Pour was a hazy orange. Taste was tart and fruity with yeast backgrounds and heavy carbonation. Very refreshing, if not ordinary
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: This is probably my favorite Unibroue, if not my favorite beer. Pours a hazy golden color with a prominent head. Aroma is complex, tangy, citrusy. Flavor is like the aroma - with a dose of spiciness and sweetness. Mouthfeel is incredibly refreshing, carbonated, yet smooth. I buy this one fairly frequently, and its well worth the money.

UPDATED: APR 8, 2007 Hazy dark copper with large off-white head and lacing all over the place. Huge aroma, citrus, yeast, vanilla, spices; coriander, cinnamon, cloves, great complexity. Taste leaned to the sweet side overall but it was very rounded & balanced, with many things going on. Medium/thick mouthfeel, medium carbonation.

Poured into a brandy snifter, leaving a glorious frothy white head that stuck to edge of the glass as it disipated. Dark cloudy amber colour. Clove and corriander coming through stong on the nose, along with some light citrus. Drinks so easy, you wouldnt believe it had an abv of 9. Typical unibroue yeasty taste, which rocks my socks off. Get your hands on this shiz. Its a drink worthy enough for the metal gods.
very deep flavor. a darn good tripel. darker golden color. flavor is pleasant and easy to drink.
UPDATED: AUG 8, 2007 #200. One of my favorites. Great Belgian tripel. Deep golden color, spicy, sweet, peppery, yeasty,wonderful flavor. Brilliant.

By far one of my favorite beers. Many times I have had it straight from the bottle but a great pleasure when you pour it. It has such a rich color and great head. Goes down amazingly smooth with a nice aftertaste. A truly great brew.

To my mind more akin to a fortified wheat, this powerful brew is packed with the goodness of heavy yeasts, cilantro and a healthy dose of bubbles. Faint straw in color and a head that doesnt linger, but with all the sweetness of wheat. A rather strange combination, but most tasty nonetheless.
Bottled. Cloudy golden pour with big yeasty aroma and fruits. Big white head. Taste was of big carbonation and fruity malt. A well done brew.
Hazy yellow pour. Aroma is banana, slight citrus. Flavor is banana, slight citrus while being bitter/tart. Finish is wet.
Excellent beer, if was made the test-blind one would swear to be about a Belgian. It only lacked a little of floral taste.

750mL bottle.  This brew is a slightly hazy gold with a small, white, big-bubbled head that vanishes almost instantly.  The aroma is banana bubble gum, chardonnay or blanc de noir, and vanilla.  There is a sour twang in the nose from the yeast and light grass from the hops.  It is slick and medium-bodied and fizzy like champagne.  There is the warmth of alcohol at the end of the flavor.  As just about all the Unibroue offerings, the flavor has a great balance between sweet, sour and bitter.  The flavor starts like the aroma and gets spicy like cardamom or something.
