It then develops a musty noble grape character.  It has a medium-length aftertaste of alcohol.  This is quite unique.  It certainly has wine-like qualities.

12 oz. bottle. Powerful, hefeweizen-esque, yeasty aroma includes lemon, orange, cinnamon, and paprika notes. Pours a hazy, sparkling orange / dark gold with a large amount of uneven near-white head and nice lacing. Tart flavor features citrus and some hops bitterness. Not as flavorful as it is aromatic, which is disappointing, but La Fin Du Monde is pleasant nonetheless. Alcohol well masked. Fascinating yeasty aftertaste. Medium body. Very lively in the palate (perhaps a bit overcarbonated). Easy to drink, especially for a beer with such a high alcohol content. This is a nice and high quality beer, but it is by no means mind blowing.

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2008 Complexa e bem balanceada, tanto no aroma, quanto no paladar. Álcool presente, porém muito bem inserido, de forma moderada, sem tornar-se desgradável. Coloração dourada, turva. Retrogosto marcante. Notas cítricas, de floral, de madeira e um leve adocicado, possivelmente caramelo. Creme legal. Carbonatação um pouco excessiva. Excelente cerveja.

12oz poured hazy grapefruity color with moderately sustained shimmering white head. Mild aroma of citrus rinds, corn, begian yeast(?) Smooth with sweet, fruity, full flavor of oranges, corriandor. Slight hop finish, but very sweet and thick. High gravity but rather shallow complexity.

12oz. Bottle:  Aroma is heavily sweet.  Smells of orange, spices, citrus fruit, and yeast.  Poured golden/orange with a huge, foamy, off-white head that lasted throughout.  Very good lacing.  Very cloudy.  Tons of  particles.  Flavor is heavily sweet.  Tastes of citrus fruits, oranges, peaches, yeast, coriander and cloves.  Medium body.  A little thick.  Lively carbonation.  Long finish tastes sugary and of spices.  Overall, tasty but I prefer a bitter brew.

12 oz. Bottle.  Cloudy yellow.  Flat, especially for a Unibroue.  Perhaps I should have bought the 750 ml bottle.  Sweet fruity aroma mainly cider and champagne.  Nice sweet yeasty and malty taste with notes of cider and champgne.  Some spice there as well.  Smooth, mid to heavy body with strong alcohol effevescent/fizz/sensation and taste at the end.
Cloudy yellow with tons of white foam.  Very yeasty/wheaty aroma.   A bit of sweet, sour, bitter, and salty flavors, light breadyness and a lot of citrus.  Crisp, with clean sweet finish.

Bottle (750) pour a slightly hazy golden color with foamy white head. Smell of coriander and orange.Very effervesent. The mouth is made of harmoniously blend :sweetness, alcool, and citrus. Soft bitteness in the end. Ive enjoy it with kenogami and parmesan cheese
La fin du monde pours a cloudy golden color with alot of off-white head. I also did not care for the smell, but enjoyed the taste.

Although this beer had a beautiful murky golden color, it had an oddly peculier aroma that put me off before the first gulp.  The flavor was quite nice, wheat / fruit, full-bodied, but the aftertaste was somewhat, to quite, disappointing.  I was left with a odd taste in my mouth that reminded me of the smell.  Hum, go figure: maybe I did it to myself.  A decent beer, but dont fly all the way to Canada to drink it.  Fly there for sure, but try some of the other Unibroue better beers first.  Long live Canada, Cheers.

UPDATED: APR 28, 2007 Naturally cloudy golden colour with  a large head.  Mildy carbonated with hints of citrus in the aroma and flavour.  Alcohol is masked well except for the aftertaste.  Overall, a very enjoyable beer, unique in flavour.
UPDATED: JUN 30, 2007 Golden with big white head / Full bodied / Flavors of sour yeast, banana, orange, and coriander /.  Body and hop holds up well to alcohol kick.  Near perfect.

12 oz bottle from sampler pack.  First glance says white beer, but aroma and first sip quickly dispel that.  Light and cloudy amber with large white head, more body than a white and a solid smooth taste.  I can see why this is so popular.  Citrus and apple, lovely beer.  I still like em a bit darker, but this is very very nice.
750ml corked bottle-pours a foamy, diminishing white head and hazy yellow head with effervescence.  Aroma is sweet, medium malt.  Taste is sweet medium malt, lots of effervescence on the tongue.

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2009 Golden and hazy with a white frothy head.  A complex fruity aroma, consisting mainly of orange. Taste is beautiful and complex. Although the alcohol is noticeable, it is completely balanced with syurpy, buttery esters.  Powerful, balanced, and filled with flavor.

Pours a hazy golden amber, topped by a huge frothy white head of foam. Good head retention  perhaps too good? Die down a bit and let me at this beer, dammit! Excellent lacing. Once the foam dies back a bit, I smell a mildly yeasty and fruity and bready aroma.

Very nice flavors of sweet wheat, a little lemon, a little Red Delicious apple, and some subtle coriander. A mild peppery spice in the finish might be the only trace of hops. Light to medium body, lots of carbonation. Smooth and drinkable  the alcohol is hidden.

Drank in a tulip glass. 750ml bottle dated: 2006-07-21.  Orange hazy poor with a thin off white head.  Aromas of spruce, tangerine, coriander, passion fruit,  hoppy, woody and a hint of caramel.  Perfect carbonation, sweet balanced feel, good bitterness and you can definitely feel the alcohol.  Flavors are very hoppy, coriander, elderberry flowers and peppery. I have tasted many  of these and i have to say that this beer ages incredibly well... buy it new... and AGE IT a good 5 years... Perfect dry floral finish...

UPDATED: APR 16, 2007 BB 10-09.  Pours with a massive, white head which settles to a decent, creamy/fluffy, lasting head with very little lacing; body is a hazy, golden color with orange hints.  Simple but solid nose; orange, corriander, yeast, floral, pepper, and a hint of clove.  Taste is very similar; orange peel, pear, yeast with lighter notes of pepper, banana, and some other undescribable spices.  Somewhat sweet with only enough bitterness to balance.  Palate is medium-full, round, quite lively, and somewhat dry towards the end; much more substantial feel than most tripels.  Finishes fairly dry, with yeast, corriander, and clove.  Very solid all the way around, nothing spectacular but nothing bad to say.  One of the better tripels Ive had to date.
pours a hazy yellow golden, mild citrusy nose with a smooth body with corriander and peppery presence, subdued hoppiness, a loing lasting taste that leaves you relaxed and wanting a nap.
Pours light yellow, cloudy, with a bubbly, large head. Tastes strongly of citrus, vanilla, and banana. Some strong spice qualities, and a good thick mouth feel. Tasty beer.

Bottle:  foamy head dissipates into powder-like barrier that persists long into the beer.  Aroma is malt with a winter mulling spice.  Mouthfeel is intense in the back of the throat.  It has a creamy, substantive feel.  The taste is incredible, with that same spice as in the aroma with each sip, hitting the roof of mouth, back sides of tongue and back of mouth. Taste lingers nicely, dry, slightly roasty.  A very good beer.

Was part of a "Beers around the World" pack.  A cloudy brew that looks like an unfiltered wheat.  Sweet to the taste, almost like a semi-dry white wine.  When I opened the bottle, the foam didnt stop till I poured it into a glass.

I Love this beer. Its one of the only beers I know that I can actually still taste it every time I think about it. From the pungent aroma to the wonderful fruity taste. If you enjoy good beer youll love this!
Bottle.  Pours a golden color, with a huge white head that takes forever to come down.  Medium body and pretty carbonated.  Unfilitered and unbelievably great.  Get it.

750. Pours a hazy gold with a massive white head. Medium body and explosive carbonation. Belgian yeast aroma with some fruit behind it. Taste of peaches, oranges caramel, wheat??? A bit of coriander in the dry finish.

12oz. white fluffy head and hazy light amber color.  tart fruit aroma and even some sour hops.  yeast and malts dominate the aroma.  taste is full for the style, with a pleasant, non-offensive spicy hop finish.  also some riper fruit on the palate.  very well rounded beer.

This is the best Belgian-style beer Ive ever had that isnt from Belgium.  Ive had a number of the Unibroue beers, and I believe this is the best beer they brew.  It is a light and effervescent tripel that pairs equally well with pizza or a more elegant meal.

It pours a straw-color with excellent tightly packed head (think Duvel).  The beer is hazy, and smells lightly yeasty, like you would expect a tripel to smell.

Taste is also of yeastiness, although the flavor is not tremendously complicated like other tripels Ive had.  There is not a lot of spiciness.  However, the taste is simple, pleasant, and the mouthfeel is very evervescent and refreshing.  I really like this beer!
Pours a hazy straw color with a large head. Aroma is Belgian yeast and sweet malt. Taste bananas, cloves, pepper, pears and sweet malts. Slightly alcoholic finish.

This was a very pressurized bottle with plenty of carbonation in the drink. Pours absolutely beautifully, leaving a thick white head with a strong orange-coloured body. The aroma is the typical Unibroue smell with spices and ripe fruits like plums and grapes. The first sip had great flavour of spices and a plenty of other notes. I did not fully appreciate the drink until I took a rather large drink of it and noticed that it was amazingly smooth and malty; this MADE the beer. 

Overall, it is a very well made beer, reading the other reviews for this I have no clue why people can not tolerate the alcohol taste and in some instances they call it "cheek and throat burning". Perhaps these people are very sensitive to alcohol, but I did not find this a problem at all, I would have never guessed this beer was 9% ABV in the first place, more like 6-7.5%. Infact, Id go as far as to say its drinkable enough for almost any occasion despite of the "gourmet" label that Unibroue give this. Its beers like these that make want to never buy mainstream or cheaper brews ever again.

bottle from friends house - always a favor since coming back from Quebec City - aroma is sweet and fruity, light semi orange head, flavor is a delightfully sweet, fruity and lighter then you would think, and ends a little spicy - just delicious!
Staple drinking in these parts. Malty. Nice finish. Drink a bottle by yourself on a cold Saturday night.

Maybe one that doesnt get some of the attention it deserves for being one of the better tripels this side of the pond.  Opaque orange-yellow with a fading white fizzy head.  Aroma mostly citrus and spice, with clove, orange and lemon predominate.  Slight yeast character first on the tongue fades to oranges and light stone fruits.  Finishes exceptionally dry and spicy, with the smallest hint of bitterness.  Highly effervescent and crisp.

Pours hazy yellow with a white head.  Aroma blend of fruit and spice.  There was 9% alcohol in this brew?  Couldnt taste anything but a spicy citrus flavor that finished smooth.  Usually I expect a bit of hoppiness from this type of beer, but there was none to be found.  A great summer brew.
A hazy yellow pour with visible debris. Nice taste, with a sweet citrus flavor.

Outstanding vision pours into the glass. Thick white head topping a hazy golden beer. Great retention and lacing. Aromas or citrus and bananas loft and linger even when the glass is away from your nose. Flavors of cloves, citrus, yeast and crisp sweetness. I could hardly sense the 9.0% alcohol in this beer. Outstanding!

Ive had a few Unibroues in the last few days and already I can identify this as distinctly "Unibroue."  This isnt to say anything about the assassin-like precision of my palate but more to say that Unibroues seem to be so one-dimensional in their own particular way.  Always with the noticeable alcohol, metallic coating and a generally synthetic quality to its flavors.  This tripel is greyish gold in color with a very nice creamy white head.  Orange, dry spiciness, alcohol, and some sour character...very typical.

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2008 A really nice beer, one of the more enjoyable I have had recently. It pours a nice cloudy, orangeish yellow with a respectable white head. The aroma is slightly yeasty with a fruit I cant identify. Has a nice spicy, malty flavor with a healthy amount  of carbonation. The alcohol does come through here in a really good way which adds to the flavor. Feels good in the mouth and stays that way for a while.
This will come to be one of my favorite beers.

Pours like a tripel should, cloudy orange/yellow with a very strong tall white head. This beer has the usual massive fruity estery unibroue nose. Very sharp and crisp spice nose with hints of apple, coriander, and a peppery dryness to it. Sweet up front on the palate, lots of fruitiness, apple, citrus, and some pineapple. Fades to a powerful spicy finish that is so alive with carbonation and spice it reminds me of poprocks candy.

Bottle. Yellow-orange colour with a very nice head. Aroma of roasted malt, spices, caramel and some wheat. Flavour is caramellic, malty with spices(coriander among others), yeasty, bit alcoholic, some nuttiness. A great great brew!

Aroma of coriander, yeast, perhaps citrus. Hazy gold color with a minimal white head. Flavor of coriander and other spice; relatively dry. Substantial mouthfeel. Alternates between a hint of sweetness, definite spice and some hop bitterness. Hints of light stone fruit throughout. Very, very nice. In the end it is dry.

Quite a nice yeasty nose with hints of coriander and quite an aroma of alcohol (that doesnt fade in the mouth). Its got a nice flavor, a complex mix of some spices and a citrus note.  I didnt find it too sweet, but I only sampled one 12 oz bottle quite slowly. I can imagine how more than one glass could be a bit overwhelming. I think the yeasty flavor does take the edge of the alcohol which could otherwise be quite strong and perhaps overpowering.  Its a pretty good beer and, given how relatively easy it is to find in the States vis-a-vis many other craft beers, its definitely woth a try.

I dont know if its a yeasty flavor that I found a bit overpowering, I would say I think it was more of a wheat straw type flavor.  This does have a lot of other things going for it including a citrusy profile.  I like it, but would go with Chimay White or Trois (if sticking to Unibroue).

Pours a very hazy orange with a one finger head that settles very quickly to a thin spotty cap leaving behind almost no lace.

Smell; lots of coriander and citric lemon, with a bunch of spices and yeast. Theres a bit of a bready dough quality, in there as well.

Taste; very fruity with oranges and lemons, and theres some other fruits that I cant quite place. The spices and sweetness are almost to overwhelming for me. Some alcohol makes its presence felt in the aftertaste pretty strongly. Mouthfeel is medium bodied, and with the sweetness and abundance of spices this is a bit hard for me to drink.
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text: Pours golden with a white frothy head. Citris and yeasty flavor. Nice Aroma. Robust ,but not too heavy
Cloudy copper with a ricky frothy head.  Smells of sour dough bread amd green apples and citrus zest  Nice marriage of sweet malt and spicy hops.

It is a very intense beer. The head didnt last much. It has a beautiful golden color. Esters,  alcohol, fruity... A nice balance between bitterness and sweetness. Some yeasty aftertaste.
A nice beer.

Not really a triple as i would have expected, more of a strong belgiun wit bier, with not as much body as id like to cover the alcohol, and the pepperyness comes off the alcohol more than the hops whic is a mistake, buttery at times in both aroma and taste, sugar coated almonds with buttery pepper is a good way to put it.

i love this stuff!
just like a true belgian ale. lots of yeast in the aroma, but lots of fruit in the flavour a truly amazing beer!

La Fin Du Monde sported a nice hazy, pumpkin color.  The head was fizzy, thin, and white.  The aroma was very wheat-like and yeasty with hints of citris.  The flavor has a bite to it.  There is citris, sour hints, yeast, and alcohol.  The palate is light but lively due to carbonation.  The finish is warm.
has a very nice fruit feel to it, a touch to much alcohol taste but over all a very nice beer

1000th rater  Cork and wire with 2005 on the wire.  Best before 12-15-08, my guess this bottle is pretty much a year old.  Was not able to retrieve my La Fin Du Monde glass so I used my slightly thinner Corsendonk tulip glass.  Pours with a small head that turns into a strong lacing.  Body is a beautiful thick murky golden.  Amazing almost no clarity for a golden beer.  Aroma for me is world class.  Strong honey and almost tea like sweetness beautifuly melded with candi sugar.  Some effervescent lemony, citrusy sweetness as well.  Very original yet true to the belgian feel.  Some earthy undertones.  Taste is similarly sweet with a strong belgian feel.  A very good translation from aroma to flavor with a little bit more of the citrus/tropical fruit aspect.  Just a small hint of bitterness in the end.  Present carbonation on the cheeks but not overwhelming.  Medium heavy body.  I feel this beer has been underappreciated b/c of its availabilty.  I wont refer to this as a true tripel but definitely a great belgian-style beer (something that guy at the 2005 GABF might even enjoy).
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: Very tasty brew mimicing Belgian style beer.  Nice brown/amber cloudy color strong brew that is well balanced. Many flavors pop out at you with this one. Good anytime of year

A cloudy amber/orange color with a small ring of a beige for a head. Sweet fruity malts, vanilla, creamy. Sweet with some young red wine tannins and some oak barrel as well. Nice feel, a spicy finish with a warming, from the belly up, alcohol kick. Another solid brew from our friends up north.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2007 12 oz. Bottle dataed 1.31.09 served in a chalice.  Pours a cloudy apricot color, with a big head that quicky collapses and slowly replenishes.  Aroma is of  lemons and yeast, which permeats my sinuses and later my lungs with each swallow.  Flavor follows closely with the aroma profile.  Mouthfeel is first dominated by the carbonation, agressive and tingly with the evident, but not unpleasant alcohol.  Medium-bodied and dry, with neither hop nor malt character dominating.   No lacing. This lacks some of the visual characteristics and complexity of a Duvel, but is quite satisfactory.

Bottle. Pours a cloudy orange hue with a nice off-white head on top. Aroma is full of fruit with spice, malt, and yeast in there as well. Flavor is quite complex with many different fruits hitting the palate. Another great beer from Unibroue!

UPDATED: JUN 14, 2007 Bottle, poured into Red Wine glass.  Orangey-yellowy cloudy pour.  Aroma is yeasty and sweet flower.  Taste is yeast and big body.  Nicely carbonated and a perfect finish.  Fantastic beer.

Light banana with coriander and yeast. Cloudy yellow yep looks the part. Some stone fruit along with bread, sweet malt and some spice. Barely a hint of alcohol I think this is nicely blended. Quite thick and pleasing to drink

Bottle at the Electro Lounge. Tulip glass. Good abbey tripel. Very tight carbonation, nice white head. good brew, pretty tasty reminds me of a larger version of Don du Diel. More fruity, more yeast, good dry finish. I liked it quite a bit.

Head goes fast down. Colour light it is. Cloudy look has this. Has that great tripel smell going for it. It tastes pretty great though. It tastes all spicy and whatnot. Taste of alcohol is not even there and for a niner beer that is something to say. Little sting on the tongue there is, but nothing to complain aboot. Thick beer is this, indeed. Not so much fruity as it is just a little bit on the sweet side. Good stuff. I have another bottle in my fridge. Drink that stuff soon, if you get what I am saying.
Bottle.  Nice light pour with a white head.  A nice sweet smell and taste.  A bit heavier for a medium body, which is very welcomed.  A  nice lingering bubbly finish that is nicely satisfying.

In the aroma I detected moderate yeasty dough, clove, and alcohol.  In appearance it is cloudy with a golden orange body hue.  Initial flavor is sweet and yeasty.  Finish duration is average to long.  Medium body, very lively carbonation.  Overall: I love this ale.  I am a big fan of belgian style ales and this one really stood out.
Nice tight white head with cloudy golden color.  Complex flavor with yeasty nose. High alcohol content sneaks up on you...in the best way.

This has a dough like, flowery taste common to the belgian style beers.  The alcohol is a bit overpowering and its not the most balanced beer...but man...is it tasty!

try some
Had from a bottle.  Somewhat flowery taste, with hints of apple and/or some other type of fruit.  Didnt realize it was so high in alcohol, till I looked at the bottle.
Nice pour, head, and color. but too flowery for my taste. Would have like deeper flavor.

750ml bottle.  Cloudy amber with a big frothy head.  Aroma of bready malt and fruit--banana, apple, lemon, with some nut and cheese essence.  Semi-sweet biscuit malts, fruit and spice/pepper flavors.  Pretty good, though doesnt really stand out from the rest of the non-Belgian Belgians.
Bottle.33cl. Appearance is a bit too hazy, but it is full flavored nice and strong and then no head.  This is mine nr. 200.

Fizzy, huge frothy head.  Nice orangish hue.  Aroma is yeasty and citrus.  Flavor is pretty awesome.  Relatively complex, sweet, orange, yeasty, with a slight alcohol finish.  I had this a long time ago and didnt like it, but really a great beer now that I think of it.

Bottle 75cl, 2005. Abbey Tripel all the way and what a tripel this is. Amazing how well it hides the alcohol, this beer is just so smooth. The fermentation just poured out when I opened the bottle, similar to a champagne bottle. Hue was orange like and cloudiness was very hazy with particles being medium and density being average. Because of the triple fermentation, the head was huge and extremely frothy. Head longevity was mostly lasting with some excellent lacing. The sniff was quit impressive, maybe caused by the triple fermentation again. God blend of moderated hoppy and yeasty notes. Some of them being flowers, perfume, grass, lemon, orange, cheese and leather. Other notes were spicy, apple, coriander. Palate was slightly misleading, as it hides the alcohol so well. Tempted to say medium bodied but mend as a positive ting. Texture was silky smooth with a fizzy carbonation. Initial flavor was light sweet with some acidity and bitterness blending nicely in there. Finish is sweet and very refreshing with an average duration that left me with a feeling for more and more and more.Brilliant experience.

A damn good beer, but more along the style of a Saison or Belgian golden ale than a Triple. Poured to a hazy golden orange, with good carbonation and a thick white head that lingered , then dissipated to little lacing. Aroma was very pleasant spices (clove and coriander) with a hint of apples. Taste was more of the spices, and a hint of cookie dough. Mouthfeel was tingly, as a result of the spices, and the finish was smooth and a little warming, due to the 9% abv. Left a lingering spicy aftertaste.

Fresh fruity aroma with hints of orange peel and lime, pours with a deep bronze hue and a large frothy lingering head, a hoppy fruity taste, hints of apples and a distinctive citrusy bite, nice medium palate, leaves a warm fruity aftertaste.  This truly is "liquid gold".
Bottle: Pours a cloudy gold color with a big head long lasting head.  Aroma of yeast, banana, citrus, and coriander.  Tastes are same as aroma.  Excellent body and nice sweet and sour finish.

Unibroue La Fin Du Monde
12 oz bottle
Slow pour in a tulip glass
Best before 04/08, ended 12/06

Poured a murky amber with a huge white mostly to fully lasting frothy pillow head.

Smelt of moderate bananas, sweet dough, white pepper.


Taste was upfront strong bittersweet raw sweet bread dough with peaches and oranges followed by a pungent sweaty raw dough on an average length finish.  Palate was creamy, softly carbonated, medium bodied and light astringency.

Overall, it is unfathomable that this beer is 9% alcohol.  The balance is exquisite.  Only wish there was more complexity.

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2007 Bottle. Pours hazy golden. Huge, bubbly head. Nose is sweet and sour, fermented apples almost. Very light opening on the tongue, but very carbonated. Middle is a complex yeasty sourness. Finish is clean with strong alcohol tones. Very warming. Very good.

Bottle.  Pours a cloudy yellow-orange, with a huge white head, some lacing.   Aroma is spices, herbs, yeast, and citrus.   Flavor is sweet, banana, yeast, alcohol, orange.   Palate is medium bodied, sticky, highly carbonated.   A strong tripel.

This beer has a yeasty-alcohol type smell. The appearance has a cloudy orange-yellow color to it. I noticed its very bubbly with a long lasting head.
The flavor is quite sweet with an alcohol catch and a dry aftertaste. As with many Unibrowe beers it gives you a little bit of carbonated tongue burn. This beer is right up there with 
Maudite and Trois Pistoles. I just wish Unibrowe would tone down on their alcohol content of these beers because I really like the taste.

Pours a translucent orange-gold color with moderately thick head.  Strong belgian aroma of coriander with alcoholic notes.  The flavor is sweet with a clean finish.  Very little alcoholic flavor.  Citrus and coriander predominate.  Im pleasantly suprised with this one.

pours a hazy orangish gold with a bubbly white head.
Aroma is fresh and spritzy citrus
Flavour was tangy sweet and tart and effervescent.

Found this one bottled in Sycamore, Illinois.  Cloudy, dark yellow pour with a thick, white head.  Bready nose with a bit of orange and corriander, sweetness balanced with sharpness of citrus.  Finishes strong.  Good!

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2007 Lots of head, smells of malt and hops, creamy head.  Pale cloudy golden appearance. Tastes heavily of malts with an aftertaste of hops.  Very smooth and rich, I highly recommend it.  An excellent tripel.

Hazy light orange/gold with a mountainous and finely textured head.  Head subsides rather quickly, leaving good lacing.

Deep, complex nose of spices, herbs, yeast, and citrus.

Lively carbonation dances on the tongue, giving lift to flavors of peach jam and overripe banana.  Subtle acid twang on the back end also helps keep the brew from being too heavy.  Actuallly, the body seems quite light for the ABV.  Finish is long, complex, and mouthwatering.

A brew thats both engrossingly complex and light on its feet, with very little of the rotten/oxidative notes that ruined the Trois Pistoles for me.
not very impressed with this brew or any of the unibroue brews.  very dissappointed especially with the price

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2006 Semi-opaque deep yellow in color. Medium head. Orange and honey aroma with a complimentary taste. Strong yeast flavor - it is bottle fermented. The flavor was not strong enought to mask the high alcohol (9%) which took away from this brew a little. Not the best that Unibroue puts out.
Give me another year and I will rate this beer higher.  My first impression was that this is a Belgian Ale.  Hazy gold with a white head.  Sweet wheat perhaps a hint of cloves.  A good strong brew.

Bottle. Poured a cloudy, yellow-orange with a huge white head that laced a little. Had a light, white wine-like aroma. Sweet wine like flavor with a lot of carbonation on the tongue. There was also some honey and light fruit flavors apparent.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2007 Re-rate. Pours a hazy pale yellow with a thick profuse creamy white head. The aroma is yeasty, dry, spicy, sweet, slight Belgian nose. The flavor is also yeast and dry, some spice, tart apple, mild Belgian flavor. The palate was extremely lively and warming from the alc. The finish was warm alcohol/

Cloudy golden with big head. Spicy/floral belgium yeast aroma. Light spicy belgian yeast taste, but surprisingly refreshing. Good sweetness with a sharp finish. Rated with the assistance of Sir Jonathan Nolley.

This was a treat, thanks to BEN for treating me at mollys, pours a light golden yellow with big foamy head.... smooth as anything.... alcohol is very well hidden.... nice balance too...overall very enjoyable.
355 ml Bottle. Cloudy golden color with full foamy white head. Aroma and taste of yeast and citrus. The alcohol is very well hidden. Very little after taste.

Pours light golden and hazy and forms a nice head. Thoroughly carbonated! The aroma is really nice and fruity, but the taste reveals too much alcohol. A tripel should have a hint of this heavenly liquid but its just too much here. Reminds me of drinking household alcohol on the Roskilde Festival back in the crazy days in 97 (which I swear Ill never do again!!!!!). Could have been a nice one, but the alcohol sets it way back.
a whole ton of head with a vegetal, yeasty aroma.  Thick and sweet, with the yeasty character really coming through. very nice, though not something Id want everyday.

0.341L  bottle at home. This is my first triple from other side of Atlantic. Nice hazy golden color with huge white head. Malty and yeasty aroma, similar taste with spicy bitterness at the end. Well balanced and good beer. Reminds me of some Belgian triples.

Exploding with white head, this product is hazy pee colored. Aroma is yeasty spicy, almost to the point of burning.. Taste is the same, but more subdued until the finish.  Nice. Medium body, but a little much in the fizz department.  $3/12ozs.

11/8/06.  Poured out of 12 oz. bottle, purchased at Liquorama in Upland, CA 7/25/06.  Rated blind.  Pours a cloudy golden-tan color with a generous, densely beady white head.  Lacing is good while it lasts-- uniform and falling in slow sheets-- but the head doesnt retain particularly well.  Aroma is bright, sweet, and yeasty with all kinds of fruity esters and a spiced character-- candied orange peel and coriander-- with a boldness that climbs out of the glass.  A little bit of alcohol beneath it, and perhaps too sweet.  But still quite lovely.  Flavor carries the fruity sweetness and coriander/alcohol bite a bit too far, losing much of the softness and subtlety that were so warming in the aroma.  Candied orange-pineapple and some slight doughiness with the coriander laying like a soggy blanket on top of everything.  Pretty incredible array of fruity and spicy yeast characteristics/fermentation byproducts on display here, but the elegance is somehow lost on me.  Fluffy and creamy mouthfeel, very airy with effervescence to lift up the medium body and carry the yeast flavors to all parts of the mouth.  The finish is a lengthy mess of alcohol flavors, glowing in my throat like Im wasted even though Ive only had a few sips and its my first beer of the night.  Really a big detraction from the otherwise fine mouthfeel.  Slightly numbing from the alcohol prominence.  A solid but unspectacular offering, one that I cant drink but maybe a glass of at any one sitting (and on rare occasions).  And I guess its worth saying that I guessed what it was after the first couple of sips.  That Unibroue house character and booziness is unmistakable, and I wouldnt say this is one of their best beers.

341ml bottle - pours cloudy gold with a very thick rocky white head. Looks fantastic. Sweet, bready, aroma is followed through in the taste with the addition of a number of spices, blended very nicely. Theres a good hit of orange in there that I really love. Yeasty and thick. Finishes with a bit of sourness and bitterness that is completely pleasant and warming. Amazing beer. A staple beer.

I was not expecting this from a pale ale. Definitely has the signature taste that is evident in Trois Pistoles. Quite homogenous and sweet. Not as good as the Trois Pistoles to me, but this triple fermented ale is something that I could brag about to friends. The finish is very strong and smooth. Taste is of taragon and other spices. The blend of spices and the sweetness of the beer make it quite something. Not something that I can alway stomach. I need to be in the mood for this beer, and when I am, I really enjoy it.

Sweet, musty fruits aroma, very inviting to the nose.  Pours a beautiful cloudy pale golden color with thick, generous head of two fingers and leaves nice lacing on the glass.   The flavor masks the alcohol level very well.  Tastes of sweetened ripe harvest fruit, nutmeg and golden toasted bread.   Not much of an aftertaste but a remnant of nutmeg flavor remains as it warms up. The yeasts used in the production of this beverage were very present throughout its sampling.  The palate leaves an equally intricate sensation in your mouth.  A masterpiece of brewmanship.

Thanks Dennis!  Pours a bubbly gold, with a huge white head.  Smells of tangerines, and other fruity goodness.  Good malty taste, a bit bitter, but overall well balanced. Havent had many tripels, but this one makes me want to try more.

Pours a hazy gold with an orange hue and a frothy white head.  Smells of apples and other fruit, there is also a presence of bread.  The taste is full of sugar bread and dark malts with fruit.  The finish is a little bitter and tingles, but overall goes down smooth.  It sure does warm you up!

UPDATED: NOV 22, 2006 Aroma was very nice - a bit sourish, with floral and wood tones. It poured a light amber with a massive head which dissipated quickly, but left lots of lace. Flavour pleasant, but not terribly impressive - weakish, a lot of citrus and not a lot of other fruit. A very present taste of alchohol - the 9% ABV hit me like a brick wall about 10 minutes into sipping down about half the bottle. A lingering honey aftertaste - odd! The mouthfeel was unremarkable - good carbonation, at times a bit excessive. To sum, its definitely a quality drink, but better to save it for when youre in the mood for a lighter, more refreshing beer (and a brutal buzz).

Served at NYC Brewtopiafest.  I cant say enough about how nice the Unibroue reps were at this thing and how overall they have a great collection of interest, different and tasty beers.  pours a hazy-golden body with a small white head that dissipates quickly.  aroma is fruity, spicy and kind of smells like herbal tea. tastes of raw, fresh vegetables, florals, yeast, peppers, lemon and apples. well-carbonated yet smooth body.  its soft, sweet citrus yet tantalizingly acidic. wow.

Drank this with some freshly smoked aged white cheddar; courtesy of Nathan.  Thank you Chef.  Yeast and citrus dominate the nose.  Fuzzy in the mouth and full of fruit and round flavors.  It is good - but not one I want to have often.

UPDATED: NOV 1, 2006 Pours out cloudy bronzish yellow. Citrus and yeast in the nose.  Some intereting malt character going on here. Fruit, spice, and alcohol. Lots of alcohol flavor, maybe a little bit too much really. Still an enjoyable brew, and an interesting choice for a quiet evening.

Pours deep gold (almost orange) with white head - very cloudy. The aroma is heavy of yeast and bread dough - hints of spice (nutmeg). The flavor starts tingly from the carbonation and full of yeast and some malt. The middle of the flavor shows some fruit and spice, more doughy malts, and some grassy hop flavor. The beer finishes full-bodied with more flavors of yeasty bread and some alcohol - long finish with sweet aftertaste. The mouthfeel is light and highly carbonated.
Bottle; Yeasty, spicy nose with a hint of caramelly sweetness; hazy gold with a huge, long-lasting white head; sweet fruity, flavor with some cloves; alcohol seems well covered.
Bottle, light foamy head with a cloudy golden color.  Nice aroma of grapefruit and floral tones.  Sweet flavor with warmth of alcohol.  Nothing stellar.

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2006 12 ounce bottle served in a Duvel glass.  Gusher.  Pretty clear golden color with a fizzy white head.  Aroma of alcohol, herbs and spice, sugar.  The flavor is pretty alcoholic with a long burn.  Sweet lemony flavor.  Maybe too sweet.  High carbonation.  Not something I will seek out again.
strong brew, yeast  and alcohol flavour intimidate many tasters but enjoyed it aged .
UPDATED: APR 8, 2008 Complex fruit and spice aroma and flavor. Alcohol well hidden. Massive head. Cloudy golden color. Lots of complex flavors!

Grassy hop notes float on a bed of sea air and honey. Beautiful brew all the way around from the pillowy white head to the sun drenched gold hue and the wonderful nose and mouthfeel. Notes of white fruit and candy with a bit of almond blossom and lemon zest. Wonderful clean spicy finish.

Bottled(330ml). -Just another great Unibroue. Honey coloured, foamy white head, perfumy pistaccio ice cream nose. Yeasty and fruity(orange, peach)  aroma with nice peppery(coriander) notes. Tastes like mild version of Tripel Karmeliet.

750. Pours a deep tannish orange cloud, kind of butterscotch colored, actually. Towering bubbly white head that fades to mousse but never really leaves. God, its gorgeous. Swirling, surging, rising carb. Big green apple tart nose. Some fun wild funk on the attack, more on the finish. Not overly funky by any means, though. Plenty of spice throughout the palate, even a tinge of pepper at the edges. Clean herbal hop finish, no linger. Great stuff, and one of the first worldly brews a friend ever gave me--10 years ago now. Shes lost her husband this year, and its sad to drink this beer and think about when he was still around, now that hes gone. Great beer given in good spirits is always a happy memory, though. Nice job by Unibroue.

341ml Bottle: Pours cloudy orange with a very generous foamy white head; incredible lacing and head retention straight through to the bitter end.  Aroma is highly complex; plenty of citrus with a lean on the lemon alongside spices I would peg as coriander, allspice, nutmeg, ginger, cardamom.. best described, I suppose, as "Moroccan spices".  Its all present in the flavour, intense and busy with an incredible earthen tone alongside the hops that hit the back fo your tongue.  Not hard at all to drink, but beware that sneaky 9% that lulls you in when you least expect it.  Good one, worth the hype.

Bottle:Murky, hazy gold color with a nice white head.  The aromas is reminiscient of when you leave your apple slices in your lunch box over a hot weekend.  I also notice sweet spices and bananas.  The flavor is sweet and yeasty.  Bananas and baked beans with brown sugar are also present.  The aftertaste is nice and is what calls you back for another sip, even if you dont prefer the style like myself.

Quite a good beer.  Definitely a bit of a treasure to drink, though it is rather simple to locate.  Very strong yeasty taste, which I enjoy, and heavy but balanced carbonation.  Not enough of the bitter taste Id like to enjoy with this, but its still pretty darn good.  I cant drink too much or Ill be very drunk.

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2006 Bottle. Gushes out of the bottle all over my counter,  pouring hazy gold with lots of small floating particles and a big airy white head. 

Deeply yeasty nose, somewhat sour and rank, some lemon, some banana. The flavor follows, dominated by bready yeasts and an incessant sour chalkiness that seems untrue to style. The bitterness is pretty laid back on the long end, and so the beer ends up missing some of the snap you get from e.g. Westmalle. I absolutely love Abbey Tripels and I know that Im way off the left-hand tail in my rating of this one, but this one simply is not a beer that Ive enjoyed, any of the times that Ive tasted it.
Love the color of this beer.  Nice yeasty and alcholic finish.  A little bit too tangy on the finish
yellow-orange color, big head.  First noticeable feature was citrus, both in the smell and taste.  Great beer if you like the style!

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2016 750 ml bottle.  Pours a hazy yellow body with a medium frothy white head. Aroma is citrus, banana, malt, spices  and yeast. Taste is spicy and citrusy, rather sweet, but balanced by hops, pleasant   yeast flavor, alcohol seems less then 9%. Full body. One of my favourite Unibroue.

I tend to underestimate this beer, as this is my everyday go to, but every time I have made a tripel blind tasting, it won against the big names of this style. I guess Im just spoiled to get this one for cheap and to enjoy it very often!

My first trippel and purchased due to rave reviews from friends.  Initial pour had lots of white head, yellow-irange in color.  Aroma of citrus at first, but with another smell I was able to pick out some bananas.  Active palate, with plenty of carbonation.  Had a yeasty, citrusy taste.  Finish was bitter and alcoholic.  At first I wasnt that big a fan, but as I sipped more, I enjoyed it and detected some peppery taste.  I particularly enjoyed the last of the 750 ml bottle.  A good beer and Im glad I tried it.

Those pesky Canadians and there DAMN GOOD BEER!!  Unibroue has quickly become one of my favorite breweries (mid-2006), and they seem to be flawless.  This trippel had a nice spice to the flavor, and an awesome color when poured (a yellow-orange hazy color).  Lively palate, and high alcohol content, but all perfectly balanced.  A MUST TRY!

This beer was pretty good.  On the pour, large, tall white head, lots of small bubbles.  Had a very translucent yellow-orange color.  Very fragrant and aromatic.  Frothy and smooth texture going down the hatch.  Pleasant on the palate and refrshing.  The aftertaste was pretty sweet though, very common with your Beligian tripels.  I could do with a less sweet taste, but overall I really enjoyed it.  And not to mention the 9% kick, wow!
Nice tripel, lemony and yeasty with a hint of clove and funkyness.  Not my absolute favorite tripel, but a very tasty tipple.
Light cloudy yellow.  Smell of yeast, alcghol, malt and lemon.  Taste of yeast, lemon, tart apples, hops, gasoline and hot dog juice.  A tart, citrus bitterness at the end.

aroma was of alcohol and many yeasty flavors such as banana and clove.  very blond beer with big white bubbly head.  flavor was dry and peppery. not too bad.  ver active palate.  Not my favorite tripel but good.

Pours honey colored, with a fizzy, white head.  Very little retention and no lacing.  Aromas of alcohol, yeast and banana, much like a hefe; some hop bouquet.  Full body, very fizzy; good balanced flavors of hops, malt and yeast.  Finish could be a bit more clean.

Yellow-orangeish upon pour from bottle.  Lots of thick white head and excellent lacing.  Quite the taste palate with overtones of fresh and fermented fruits and nuts.  Not sure which ones, but definitely some.  Heavy in alcohol and flavor.  Sounds like a good way to end the world to me!

12 oz bottle:  pours a hazy yellow gold with a nice sized white head.  Lots of distinctly unibroue yeast aromas with a little grapefruit and apple citrus.  Earthiness, bread, orange peel, green apples, corriander and yeast are all over my tongue bouncing off with lots of carbonation.  The fruity tartness fades to a hint of alcohol in the finish.  Very nicely done.
Lively carbonation on the tongue. Pale yellow/brown.  Light body with excellent tartness and fruit.  Not at all heavy for the % alcohol within.  Refreshing and very tasty.
Great beer with plenty of fruity flavor.  Poured a nice apple cider brown, with a little bit of white foam head.  Good drinking til the last sip.

sampled from 750.  Pours a nice hazy light orange with a medium head  and medium to high carbonation.  Aroma: is very earthy and yeasty, light amount of tart citrus.  Taste is tart citrus, earthy yeast, some notes of bread, with a very clean finish.  The body/texture is slightly watery but this is a dangerously drinkable tripel, well made.
Kick start at the front end with a more gentle finish. I like it. Smells of yeast and citrus. This is a little bit more bashful a triple than Im used to.

pours clear light yellow with a large white head. Aroma is light bread, lightly hoppy and heavy leather and earth/cheese.  Flavor is a great balance that follows through to the finish as it diminishes with hints of citrius throughout.  Medium bodied watery, and creamy.  This would be a much better choice and of the same style as Delirium Tremens

Cloudy golden with medium off-white head. Aroma is sweet orange, some pepper, . Taste is medium sweet, orange, yeasty, pepper, bready, light alcohol, finish is pleasant alcohol warming. Medium-full body that holds the alcohol well.
Bottle at home. Unclear light yellow - white head. Sediment at the bottom. Soft creamy, fruity, yeast, orange, lime,  sweet, light sulphur, light licorice. High carbonation.

Clean and fruity tasting.  Lots of belgian type flavor.  Nice beer.
Hides the alcohol very well.

This beer pours a light cloudy yellow with a touch of pale green. When held to the light, it changes color to a darker copper. the head pours quite tall and consists of thin and even white bubbles. There is a nice stream of bubbles rising from the bottom of the tulip glass that sustain this head. There is no lace as the head just slips down the side of the glass. 

Smells of intense pineapple, dry red apple, bitter yeast, a wheat and oat malt and a bit of watermelon. 

Tastes of smooth green grapes with a little sour and dry sting. There are also notes of melon, oats, and smooth creamy yeast. 

The mouth feel is light bodied with an intense small bubble carbonation. 

The flavor of this beer is very prominent, but mellow enough with a light enough carbonation to make this very enjoyable.

The first time I tried this beer, I really didnt like it (750 ml bottle), but have found that the standard "regular" bottle seems to taste much better - just my imagination, or a result of the bottle-conditioning? Anyway - the beer is wonderful. A pale orange colour with an enormous head that fades to some rocky terrain, sticking around for the duration. The powerful alcohol percentage is well-hidden in the complex array of tastes that seem to start on one side of the tongue and finish on the other. Balanced spices, and a hint of citrus and banana really make this something to sit back and enjoy. Highly recommended, but stick to the 341 ml bottles over the 750 large-size. Just not quite the same.

Pours hazy light orange with a thick, fizzy, off white head. Aroma is yeast, berries, and spice. Flavor is basically the same as the aroma with a good hint of the alcohol on the finish. Pretty light on the palate, but a little too much fizz. Pretty enjoyable overall, and fairly unique, but just too much carbonation.

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2007 Close to Chimay this didnt bowl me over but I liked it more with each sip. A little bit like wine in taste, the beer flavor came in more strongly when it warmed. It tassted better at just under room temp then cold. I wont buy it again for a while but will happily drink the others in the pack.

Either I just dont like belgian beers or I keep getting abused bottles.  Happened to me with Orval also.  The aroma is STRONG and not really pleasant: alcohol, vomit, cat-pee.  The flavor, however, was not offensive, it was clean, fruity and champagne-like.  With apples and pears and bit of hops.

A strong beer with a lot of yeast taste. I reminded me of Belgian beers. I dont like this type of beer. Too sweet and too much taste of yeast.
I got a 12 oz bottle. The head was fine and lasted until I finisthed the beer.

UPDATED: SEP 9, 2006 12 oz bottle pours a murky pale amber with a very large white head that dissipates quickly.  Smells slightly sweet, and slightly skunky.  The taste is amazingly unique.  It starts with a strong hop for a few seconds with a strong fast hint of alcohol and instantly drops to nothing. No aftertaste at all.  I couldnt believe it.  At around 9% alcohol, this beer keeps the belly nice and warm.  Id love to try any other beer that tastes close to this.

BCA (Nov 08). Sweet malts and strong alcohol dont help the spicy yeast and citrus flavours. But the initial floral honey flavours to the malt are pretty good, unfortunately these fade into obscurity after the onslaught of sweet alcohol.
Slightly hazy golden color with a thick white head.  Aroma of yeast and citrus.  Nice malty flavor with some spice notes.  Excellent.
Pale color with a lot of carbonation. Almost sparkling like a wine ! Metallic and citrus notes with some bitterness.

Bottle. Nice fruity smell, has a nice sweet (but not too sweet) taste at first, but soon disipates to give a dry, but nice aftertaste. The best thing is that you do not experience that punch in the mouth of alcohol, dispite the 9% al. content, the overall flavor does a fine job of covering it up. Very decent.

Milky light orange color with a nice foamy head, lots of tiny bubbles. Aroma of citrus and bubble gum. Malty with some spice. Smooth feel and the alcohol isnt overpowering considering it is 9%. Not a bad beer.
Bottle.  Citrus aroma with raspberry hue.  Heavy foam pour with non lacy head.  Carbonated, but not fizzy.  Smooth finish.  A class act all the way.
A tad bit overrated, dont you say? Aroma is sweet and spicy with lemon, pepper, phenol, and some hops. Flavor is the same. A bit overatenuated. Too much coriander. Dry mouthfeel.

12 oz bottle.  Delicious.  Wheaty appearance with orange tones.  Creamy thick, white head that laced nicely.  Spicey, malty taste.  Fruit and honey nose.  Nice feel in the mouth.  Very nicely balanced beer.  Unibroue is 2 for 2.

Unibroue knows what its doing, and their self-description of robust is dead on.  Complex flavor with a grapefruit tinge, spicy flavor, nice tangy finish, beautiful aroma of crisp fruit.  And of course, gorgeous ABU.

(06.10.06) One pint, 9.4 oz brown bottle purchased from DiCarlos, Mundelein, IL. 9% ABV. Belgium-style triple that poured cloudy orange with medium white head.  Good carbonation. Medium-to-full bodied ale that starts semi-dry with malt/fruit (pineapple and peach)/spicy (coriander?) flavors. Some tanginess and sharpness in the mouth. Finished with light malt fade. Rich complex flavors. A beautiful flavorful beer.

Creamy is the best way to describe this.  Its very sweet and pours smooth.  A nice aftertaste, but I could use more of a bitter bite.  All in all, this is a fine beer with a great diversity of flavors.  Contrary to the opinnion of other users, this beer doesnt taste like a white wine- this is primarily due to the fact that it is a beer.

Might as well just drink white wine instead, not too far off,  or mix with a preferred ale if you like this sor of thing. Not for me. Sour and acidic notes finish particulary bad and linger in your mouth. Cracked the bottle cap and half the beer fizzed out but didnt taste like way too much carbonation.

12oz bottle.  Aroma:  Spiciness jumps out first.  Mostly clove but some pepperiness too.  Lots of citrus, and some slight banana.  Lots of the Unibroue house yeast character, mostly earthiness in this one.  Appearance:    Golden yellow and slightly hazed.  Head is full, white, and rocky.  Flavor:  Mix of orange and lemon.  Nice spiciness.  Malt plays a supporting role here, but does it well.  Alcohol ties it all together.  Very tasty.  Palate:  Medium bodied with a nice creamy texture.  Lively carbonation.  Slight alcohol warming in back of mouth.  Overall:  A great beer and one of my favorites from Unibroue.

i really enjoyed the small sample I had of this beer, it was rich with the expected taste of malts and light hops. The flavor was crisp ith a noticeable arrangement of spice and yeas. A strong Alcohol content and mild fruits.

Citrusy, yeasty, bready aroma with hints of spiciness underneath (clove, nutmeg).  Huge citrusy (lemon, orange), yeasty, and spicy flavors, vague hint of pineapple and green apple underneath.  One of my "go-to" beers, and one that I often reccommend to people.

Bottle. A friend from Canada brought it in Switzerland while I was studying there.
Murky golden color. Aromas of citric fruit and spices. Tastes of orange , yeast, mild pepper and other spices. Pretty good beer , I would love to retry it after so many years.

Pours a glowing orange with a THICK white head.  Every bottle Ive opened has started spilling - beware.  Aroma is of fruits, spice, and yeast.  Similar to a Belgian White.  Flavor is sweet, with yeast, a syrupy fruit flavor, and spice.

Hazy yellow coloured with some carbonation and a small diminishing white head. Very fruity malty and yeasty sweet aroma. Full palate, some sprankling. Finish is sweet bitter, alcoholic (very little burning) and rather heavy. Overall a very nice beer; I really like this one.

An orange beer with sediment floating around underneath an off-white head. The aroma is very sweet with strong fruity notes, like peaches, oranges, and grapes, but also with notes of yeast and a dusty hop note. The flavor is sweet, though more mellow than the aroma, with notes of fruit, again peaches, but now the alcohol mixes in together with lighter notes of over ripe apricot, wood, and sirup. The end is somewhat dry and spicy (coriander and cloves) but still with a lot of fruit, before the alcohol starts burning down the throat and in the cheeks.

Enjoyable citrus and clove flavor and with a subtle squeeze of an orange rind, it bites the palate wonderfully!  It pours like a basic American lager until the first scent crosses your nose.  One of my favs from Unibroue.  This would be my choice "si La Fin du Monde va arriver quelque jour (en mille ans ou plus....jespair!)".
Bottle. Good head but short duration. Color is hazy golden. Aroma is nice and yeasty with lots of fruit. Taste is sweet, yeasty and fruity with some alcohol as well.

Pours opaque yellow with a white head . Aroma is sour fruits (bananas, garpefruit) with cloves and a slight cedar. Flavor is amazing rich like the scent with fruits exspecially banana and a great spicy hoppy yeast and clove finish. Taste lingers in your mouth as a slight alchohol burn slides down your throat. Only complaint was it was overly carbonized

UPDATED: MAY 4, 2007 Great head, cloudy golden color. A gift from Secret Santa.--thanks bunches. Very sweet (the gift and the taste).  Citrus overtones and almond undertones, with a syrupy finish.  Better cold.
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text: Poured a cloudy color of stewed peaches with a majestic, off white peachy colored frothy head, mostly lasting.  Heavily yeasty aroma - dough, horse blanket, and soapy notes.  Moderately malty of biscuits.  Orange, corriander, fresh cut green peppers.  As  great as this looked and smelled, I was expecting quite a lot more than I got.  Really humdrum flavor and disappointing body.  Lightly sweet, some acid and sourness.  Surprisingly short and unremarkable finish, overly carbonated with a light to medium body.  Im sad this wasnt better.
Wonderful beer... You can feel the alcohol as it goes down,  high malt aroma and taste beatutiful white lacing that remains throught the glass

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2007 This beer pours a hazy burnt orange and yellow.  The head is about 1/2in thick and snow white.  The lacing is decent, but it doesnt stay long.  Citrus, corriander, clove, and a little banana apper in the nose.  The mouthfeel is great and almost grainy, with a little alcohol warming effect, some banana, and maybe a little earthiness.  This has a nice lingering aftertaste.

Re-rate:  Okay so its not better than Westmalle, like I had it rated before.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: Pours a golden color.  Fruity with belguim yeasts and spices.  Honestly a little to much spice for my taste.  Very sweet well made ale, but not my thing.

Pours a beautiful golden yellow with pieces of yeast floating. Head is thick and frothy. Beer smells of intense citrus, banana and spices (coriander, nutmeg, clove). Taste is quite similar to the smell. I tell people it feels like a "bouquet of flavor" in your mouth. Nice balance between malt and hops, sweet and bitter. Alcohol is definitely noticeable but welcomed. If the world were to end tomorrow, this is the last beer I definitely would choose to drink.

350 mL bottle.  Poured into Trappist.  First pour contained the most head Ive ever poured from a brew... settled (eventually) with a foggy light gold hue.  Complex taste with fruit tones, medium body, and pleasant tone.  Leaves you wanting more.  Very enjoyable for an after dinner treat and to share with family/friends and good times.

Bottle. 750ml. Slow poured a hazy amber with a slight white head that quickly dissappeared.Aromas of fruits and malts and hint of banana .The taste was smooth and balanced.The malt and citrusy fruit came through with zest.This is a very well made brew which I will enjoy agin.

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2007 Bottle(0,33) Yellow hazy colour, with a nice creamy foam. Aroma of yeast,fruty,citric,banana,Vine-and a bit of alc-bitternes in the end..
Sweet maltynes,banana, round bread mouth feeling,medium finish,with a malty sweet round finish.Full body.
750ml.  Amber color, with a thick, long lasting, white head.  Spices and fruits make up this aroma, along with its flavors.
Great hazy amber pour and super fluffy, thick head.  Quite yeasty and just a touch of alcohol on the nose over the cloves and biscuit.  Superb.

Pours hazy orange with stunning cotton white head. Aroma is very fruity with a mixture of banana, apples and mostly oranges. The taste is based very much on dried fruits, a little vinious and quite great actually!

I love to pour this beer hard and see the cotton white head form.  I know it wont last long but it is a beautiful contrast to the cantaloupe color of the beer.  The fruity aroma of apple-bananas spice and a little hay is only interrupted by the  unibroue yeast, this scent permeates through every one of there stronger ales (since I have not sampled anything less than 7%abv).  The flavor is what I expect from a begian triple, dried fruits a little alcohol and some yeast.  This is has to be one of the best bangs for your buck in the area and a must for anyone looking to try this style for the first time.

Pear ,banana ,and some spices in the aroma(but definetely no corriander, I dont know where everyone else was getting that) huge head ,cloudy body, heavy banana pear malt taste,lots of sweetness so there must be plenty of unfermentable sugar in here,wonderful smooth aftertaste,its everything I love about Belgian beer

UPDATED: SEP 14, 2014 Hazed orange pour with a high frothy white head. Aroma is brown sugar and biscuits. Flavor is light brown sugar and caramel malt with a tart dry finish. Medium body with a touch of papery bitter finish. Carbonation is aggressive/lively. pretty nice beer 7-4-8-3-15

La Fin Du Monde is a great name for a beer, so I have to give some points for that. The pour is golden brown with a monster head. The aroma is of some light citrus and spices. The taste is full bodied for sure, but is dominated by coriander--which I just dont like in my beer. Herbal taste in the finish that sticks with you.

UPDATED: JUL 17, 2006 hazy golden brownish with a huge thick, fluffy white head.  Has a nice sweetness to it,  flavors of fresh fruit, clove, banana, yeasty, with a somewhat bitter and sour  aftertaste.  Nice thick mouthfeel.  Finish is decently dry.  a well balanced brew.
Bottled, 330 ml. Hazy, solid head. Fruity aroma. Sweet, very sweet and rich taste. Mouthfeel is sticky. Alcohol is present but the beer is still very drinkable. Liked it a lot.

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2009 Corked and capped, 750ml bottle. Poured a rich, wheat-golden with thick white head. Very cloudy. A yeasty, full flavour with hints of bread and butter. Enough alcohol on the finish to warm you up a little. For 9%, extremely easy to drink. Highly recommended, definitely the highlight of the night.
Edit: Well more than half a year on, every time I try it, I never expect it to be as good as I remember. It always is.

Pours a hazy golden-brown into the glass with a huge head that diminishes.  From the look only, it reminds me of a hefe-dark.  The nose has some sour citrus, yeast, wheat, and possibly some clove (?).  Flavors follow accordingly, with a drying biscuity-clove finish.  The tartness, backed with such crisp carbonation, lends the mouthfeel to be lighter than the style suggests.  Not bad at all...  I may be picking up an ever-so-slight alcohol note to the very end of the finish, but not medicinal.  Great job!  Great beer!
Heavy hoppy aroma. Huge creamy white head. Excellent lasing. Cloudy orange body. Heavy bitter initial flavor. Palate medium to full.

Bottle. This is my third Unibrou and I was beginnig to think that this is a really crappy brewery, but this one is quite good but not as good as you canadian/american  think. Creamy white excellent fully lasting head. Yellow colour. Very powerfull applehoppy aroma. But its much much too alcoholic. It doesnt taste that well. Very nice oily palate though.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2006 Aroma: Fruit, wonderful yeast, wild raspberry, wheat, candisugar, coriander, aniseed, peach/passion/mango, perhaps all of them, sweet malt, wonderful sourishness, mineral.

Appearance: like multivitaminejuice, orange yellow, turbid, milklike fog, white fizzing head that quickly declines.

Flavor: sweet, molasseslike and fruity, stabilizing maltiness, lovely afterbitterness with a onionlike acridness to it.

Palate: rough, very fresh and very mellow, I would have given it 5 if it wasnt so sharp.

The beer gets heavier shortly.

(Specs on Smith)
Cloudy, with a thick off-white head.
Lots of lacing.
Strong taste, slightly spicy.

Bottle best before 10-04-08.  Hazy dirty dark golden/yellow, tiny bits of sediment everywhere, with decent head from somewhat vigorous pour. Fades to film. Highly carnonated, quick swirl brings back decent amount of head. Aroma is very yeasty, with plenty of fruit. Rotten banana, orange peel, pear, with a certain peach/apricot/mango character to it. Corriander and faint alcohol in the background. Flavor much the same. Big yeasty banana up front, zesty orange peel and corriander taking over through the middle and some more banana in the finish. Banana really comes through as it warms. Even for all the unibroue catbonation, has a great mellow/smooth mouthfeel. Highly sessionable beer though. Not a huge tripel fan, but hard to beat when well done.
Pours a cloudy yellow, no head. Very aromatic. Tastes of lemon, bananas, and bitter hops. Touch of honey as well. Excellent beer.
Cloudy gold, with a white head. Aromas are yeast, spice, and citrus. Flavors are much the same, yeast, spice, and alcohol.

UPDATED: AUG 21, 2010 Pours cloudy light orange with a large white fine foamy head.  Sweet candied malt and dusty yeast aroma.   Chewy sparkly lively palate.  Some sweet cereal flavor, candied malt, yeast, light summer fruit.... touch of pepper, an excellent triple.  8.4.8.5.17 . . . . . .

[in need of rerate]

Smells likes champagne nitrate and fruit. Nice and powerful.

Tastes very much like it smells, only more subdued. Powerful honey malt upfront leads into the strong, violent fruit that zips and zaps and leaves you wanting more as it disolves into cloves and spice.

Truly an exceptional beer.

Bottle. Pours cloudy yellow with retentive white head. The aroma is much like lemon cookies. The flavor is somewhat sweet bread with some lemon and noble hops. Just a hint of honey, as well. Some alcohol is evident in the aftertaste. The mouthfeel is rather fizzy.

Hazy golden color with thin white head. Aroma seems citrusy, banana and yeast. Taste is aided by high carbonation. I first taste bitter hops, some sourness, spice then candy sugar sweetness. Fruity flavors (banana mostly) linger. The flavors mix well resulting in an enjoyable experience.
UPDATED: NOV 27, 2006 A pretty nice beer. Golden color with a huge fluffy head that stays around for a while. Aroma of malts and spice.  Flavor is of sugary spices and malts.

head is not totally white,but slightly creamy-colored
beautyfull,a bit hazy orange-golden color
carbonation fits  very well to the beer,in mouth,altough i had to put my glass very quickly under the bottle, for preventing loosing some of that beautyfull "juice"!! 
I think,that i should have poured it a bit colder in my glass,and leth warm it a bit up after!!!
smells yeasty,spicy,some orange and banana smell, on the bottle,there was only written"épices" (spices),but i think there is coriander in it.
tasts yeasty,spicy,fruity,sweet-sourish,a bit of hops too!
aftertaste yeasty,spicy,fruity,bitter-sweet,a bit of hops, some warm alcohol,but not too much, just giving a nice warm feeling in the throat.
by the way,normally,here in switzerland,we have rather warm weather,on that time of year,but now, we had a very cold and rainy mai and a cold beginning of june,so this beer is great to give some warmth to a cold evening and for give hope for beather weather!!
a very good beer,the spices dont hide the fruityness,well balanced!!
A beer to share with friends,on evenings,when discussing about life and so on!!

Hazy yellow with thick head. Loads of retention with webby lacing. Sweet fruity nose... bananas and yeast with slight alcohol hints. Similar taste with a light spicy character to it. Smooth crisp taste with sharp but somewhat sweet alcohol flavor and warming. This is a great beer.

Beautiful golden pour with a very thick white head.  Aroma gives off hints of oranges, bananas and other fruits as well as an obvious alcohol smell.  Taste is a spicy mixture of the above and does not completely hide the alcohol.  Finish is mildly bitter.  An excellent Tripel from Unibroue.

12oz bottle, <!-- i -->best before 01-31-09<!-- /i -->.  Opened this POS up and foam got on my keyboard, my clothes, and on my desk.  I am pissed off.  The beer hasnt been hardly moved for over a month and a half.  It will lose three points on the "overall" for that stupidity--nothing needs to be that carbonated.  If there were any volatiles I missed them due to me trying to clean up my keyboard.   Pours a cloudy golden with a huge piece of crap white head, quickly fading.  Aroma of Belgian yeasts, bananas, nondescript sweet fruits, pepper, and alcohol.  Taste is much of the same.  There is some hotness from the alcohol, which fits with the 9% ABV.  Slightly bitter finish.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied, very light carbonation (since all was lost from the mountain of foam).   Would have been a pretty good beer except for the fact that I lost four ounces of it from the carbonation.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: This beer pours a golden color with a thick white head thats persistent.  The aroma is sweet and fruity.  This is a medium bodied beer that reminds me a lot of a german hef with a fruity taste, but with that spicy unibroue flavor.  An excellent beer!

A nice Canadian version of a Belgian style beer. The alcohol taste was strong on this one, but the flavor beneath revealed a nice sweetness with a touch of orange. The beer was a cloudy lemon color. The head was appreciable, and the bottom of the bottle poured with small solids into the glass (orange rinde?). A very likeable beer with great flavor.

Simply an excellent beer.  Pours cloudy gold with a fat white head.  Aroma is full of yeast and spice, with some lighter fruits.  Perfect balance of malt, yeast, and spcie in the taste, with some hops for a nice bite in the end.  One of the best.

Very Nice 750ml bottle representing  the province of Quebec, Canada. A true and complex tripel from Unibroue. Nice gold-yellow unfiltered colour with big and rich foamy head. Hints of spices and a blend of different yeasts gives a lasting taste (although it does not completely hide the alcohol). A bit stronger than the "Don de Dieu." My type of beer.

Cloudy blonde with a fine lacy white head.  Great banana and toast aromas with a bready yeast and coriander spice.  Nice hoppy bite and corbonation give way to a full, bready palate.  Smooth, with a hint of alcohol on the finish.  Nice and fruity up front before the drying malts kick in.  Very good.

Golden body with a small white head. Very nice aroma, yeast is pronounced, banana and other sweet fruits, very typical of the style.  Excellent body, a good example of the style.  Yeast, banana, some other fruits.  Spicy ending.
Hazy orange color with a creamy white head. Aroma of sweet malt, some banana and spice. Flavor of sweet banana and lots of spice.

Bottle.
A sweet and strong aroma overwhelms my senses.
Pours a very giving head that stays around awhile. Slightly recedes and a cloudy mixture until the last sip.
Spicey taste and well balanced. Nice blend of malt and yeast. Very drinkable. No notice of the high alcohol in the tone of the ale.
Very good. Will be drinking again.
Cheers!
This blonde ale poured with a lacy off-white head. There is a full complex flavor that starts off sweet, with a more bitter hoppy finish.
Orange/Yellow.   Very highly carbonated.  many complex flavors:  spcicy bitterness, citrus fruit, yeast, and hops.  Aftertaste is bitter.

Yeasty with a banana/bubblegum aroma nad a hint of spiced caramel apples.  Cloudy, yellow-gold in color with small particles floating around and a huge, rocky head that is loud.  Sweet fruity flavor with earthy banana, some caramel apple and a light touch of spice.  The finish is dry with some vinous notes.  Very drinkable, medium-light body with lots of carbonation.  Alcohol is well hidden.  Thanks to brigadier for the bottle.

Very well done Unibroue! I have always meant to try this ale, but never got around to it for whatever reason. Now, here it is! I this this brew is what an abbey tripel should try to be! It had an excellent aroma of citrus, the colour was a darker hazy yellow/amber. The flavour was citrus to hoppy. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

i was surprised to see their flagship beer is 9% abv.  what a cool company.  a great beer as well, complex, very identifiable cotton candy aroma with candy malts and that whole belgian yeast thing.  i figure ill have this again someday and rate it for real.
This to me is an exceptional strong ale.  a little fruity, a little spicy, and a little yeasty.  very cloudy white ale with a bubbly head.

UPDATED: MAY 16, 2006 Bottle. Hazy orange golden color with a massive white head and maximum lacing on my Tulip glass. Smells of ripe oranges and pinaples with some spicy (cloves, pepper, ginger) yeasty undertones. Tastes of spices, raisins, citrus, yeast, sourdough and a sweet caramel aftertaste. A very complex flavor that brings out diffrent savory tastes with every gulp, a highly fermented finish but a very well hidden 9% abv.A full body and the warmth of the brew is felt almost to late at the pit of the stomach. A bit stenchy and metalic at the first pour but at the end i was thinking it was one of my favorites, very smooth, its an essential.
Bottle, 330 ml. Hazy yellow colour, white head. Hints of tropic fruits in the aroma. Slightly sweet & spicy taste. Well hidden ABV. I had expected more from this beer...
Bottle . Dark orange colour with a white head. Fruity aroma with yeast and alcohol.. The flavour has many elements of yeast, fruitiness  and alcohol. But it´s a good mix.

bottle. Poured a nice yellow, slightly cloudy, but not to much. Small white head that disappears. Lots of fruity flavors. I tasted what might have been raisin, but I wasnt really sure. There was also a decent amount of spice to this beer.

Bottled, 33cl. Orange-golden with some sediments and a small white head. The nose has lots of citrus, mostly grape-fruit, and yeast. The flavor has candi-sugar, citrus, alcohol and bitterness. Finish is bitter and has some alcohol. This is one of the beers I would very much like to have available in Norway. (060422)

UPDATED: JUN 19, 2006 Bottle:  Nice pour, although head is a bit ridiculous...  Dirty straw color.  Aromas are of apple, bread, some hops.  Sweet apple flavor that yields to a hoppy, malty body with a little bit of alcoholic warmth.  Nice.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: bottle -  poured hazy golden yellow with a vigarous carbonation.  very light hoppy aroma and taste but the finish was very sweet almost cider like

Lemon grass, banana peel aroma.  Tall head with an extremely hazy body from the tons of floating yeast sediment.  Slight metallic flavor up front which grows, but then blends into the rose petal flowery flavor thats the majority of the body.  The high alcohol content is well-hidden and drops well into the light hoppy character.  Decent, but nothing really stands out in this one.

This is a big beer.  Lots of yeast, clove spiciness and banana.  Nice golden haze.  Head goes bye-bye really quickly.  Good lacing, while it lasts.  As with most Unibroue beers, there is almost too much carbonation.  There is a bit of a sour finish.  I prefer the Allagash Tripel Reserve.
Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus. Beautiful pour, very smooth, unibroue never lets me down. good smell great taste fat head pours golden in color. very drinkable. unbelievable smoothness for 9%.

Small bottle. Creamy sustaining head. High carbonation. Nose of orange, pepper and yeast. Sweet and sour with a long finish along with alcohol warmth.  Fairly round body, yet easily drinkable. On the other hand, my opinion is small Unibroue bottles do not compare favorably to their bigger counterpart in terms of complexity and I fell the body is also thinner, as if the smaller ones were more carbonated. Still a very good brew.
Perfect blend of strength and flavor.  Each variety from Unibroue has a similar taste with subtle differences.  La Fin du Monde is beautiful in appearance, pour, and flavor.
Old notes but good memories. This is so typical of the yeast that dominates Unibroue brews. ALWAYS full of outragious flavor,complex with fruit and spices. There brews are almost always a good bet.

Lightly hazy golden color with a fizzy head that disappears quickly.  Aroma is very spicy and peppery with some white grape and banana hints.  Taste delivers everything on the aroma - banana, white grape, clove spiciness and pepper aspects along with smooth malt flavor and light Belgium yeast.  The mouthfeel is lighter than most tripels and has very sharp carbonation.  It detracts a bit from the flavor, but not much.  Finish is a bit on the sour side that lingers along with the spices.  Further down the banana and clove aspects come to the front much like the Don de Dieu - the finish also mellows from the sourness to an earthly Belgium yeast feel.  A very nice beer from a consistant brewery.
Fruity, with the clear aroma of a Belgian ale.  Massive head that fill more that 50% of the glass.  Sharp and tangy with a smooth finish that belies the alcohol content.
user_location: Peoples Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text: OUTSTANDING beer.  Very efferevescent, like a complex cider.  I taste apples, grapefruit, some sourness, and some pronounced maltiness.  Has a decent amount of fizz to it as well.  Very nice, tingling mouthfeel.  You can barely taste the 9% abv.
Triple fermentation.  Dark golden pur with a light skunky smell. Malty taste with a strong alcohol finish. 7%
UPDATED: JUN 8, 2006 Pour this beer slowly!  Even a moderately slow pour will result in precious drops being wasted.  Thick head that lingers for 10 minutes.  Pours orange-brown.  Great beer
Pours out a hazy light brown color with a large beige head. Flavor is wonderful with malty and citrus notes.  Aroma is yeasty and a bot malty.  Super good brew

Big soapy head, hazy "goldenrod" color, active carbonation.  Aroma: First hint, this may be a bad bottle, slight skunage, but notes followed by yeast esters and pwnage, slight alcohol.  First taste confirms that this bottle was starting to turn (no doubt from poor storage at the place of purchase as it was covered in dust and sitting in UV light...) but this was not a ruined beer, as it still poured on strong malt body with yeasty bananas, slight clove spice, and lasting sweetness.  Good long finish, feels great all around, I would like one of these in its prime.
glass.it has sunny haze look to it and a yeast bitternesss aroma a smooth touch of the lips and a bubbly dance on the toung leaveing a little of a  bitter after taste. not bad i would say.
Bottle. Hazy golden colour with a white head. Spicy, yeasty aroma. Malty and spicy flavor with some hints of yeast. Long warming spicy aftertaste.
grass, banana, pale, amber, hazy, tan foam, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium sourness, light body, thin feel, fizzy, astringent,

Ive tried this on three separate occasions, and I cant do it.

La Fin du Monde tastes like old socks, and smells equally appealing. Its only merit is that its nice to look at. I am not impressed.

12oz bottle.  Hazy, golden banana hue.  Large white head.  Banana, clove and ginger nose.  Yeasty and bready head aroma.  Floral and perfumy.  Smooth full and slick.  Alcohol burn is slight.  Initial is smooth with caramel and cola notes.  Then into a grainy and citrus and dry perfumy middle.  The finish is cloying and sweet.  Tongue tingling.

I love this beer so much.  Its got such a great mouthfeel to it.  Every sip has this fantastic sweetness in it thats not too sweet, but just right.  I like this beer as well or maybe better than some of its genuine Belgian counterparts.  A bit of alcohol in the taste, but its 9%, so that can be expected somewhat.  Goes well with cheese.
Take your time with this one.  Good color from the start, with a frothy almost meringue like head.  Lots of alcohol flavor on the front, but its impact subsides.

Outstanding beer.  Looks totally amazing with a thick pillowy head that lasts.  Tastes like Okanagen fruits (peach skins really stand out to me) with some yeastiness.  Boozy.  Its good to have ales being brewed in Canada that are completely comparable to the Belgians.

12 oz bottle poured a light golden color with a moderate fizzy head. Nice fruity aroma with a touch of citrus.  Yeasty flavor with notes of honey and citrus.  Crisp, slightly bitter finish with a nice effervescent mouth feel.  My favorite Unibroue so far, reminds me somewhat of RR Deification.

Hazy golden triple, white head.  This is a standard triplel . Fruity esters, vanilla sweetness, pepperish dryness.  Its robust and slightly sticky.  Nothing here really lacks compared to other tripels, and nothing really stands out.  This is similar to other tripels I have had.  Not my favorite style, but I enjoy it from time to time.

I dont like most tripels all that much, and this is no exception.  The fruity and spicy flavors are OK, but I dont go for the thick, syrupy palate with the strong sweetness and alcohol burn.  This beer is a very typical tripel.  Also has some strong prickly carbonation.  Flavor fades out a bit near the end and in the finish.

Pours like gold with a white head.  Nose is fruity and floral with hints of spice.  Flavor follows the nose with amazingly complex fruity flavors balanced by a nice alcohol burn. Very full mouthfeel. A very good triple and about the best youll find that isnt brewed in Belgium.
