Pours a hazy gold.  Some malt, some yeast in the nose. Same in the flavor, but some fruits are present. Nice smooth palate, but not a lot of lace. Nice tripel.

Pours with a slightly hazy golden body topped by a thick rocky white head with good lacing.  Slightly sweet and fruity (banana) aroma with a yeasty accent and lemony and spicy notes.  Slightly sweet and fruity (banana) flavor with notes of clove and lemon and a touch of yeasty bread.  The finish is slighlty sweet and spicy from clove.  Medium to full bodied and slighlty tingly yet smooth and refreshing.

It's La Fin du Monde as we know it, but I don't feel fine. Color is (I'm sorry) piss yellow. Thin bone white head. Too yeasty and spicy for me. But for what it's worth, it tastes better slightly warm than cold.

Hazy yellow hue with a thin head and no lace. Aroma of hay fields, herbs, banana, earthy yeast, allspice, tropical fruits, and cotton candy. Smacks down your taste buds with massive sweetness, alcohol, and earthy tones. Follows with an acidic tone which just will not let go. Messy taste, this beer has no idea where it wants to go or be. Some potential, but in the end fails to produce the results I expected.

Tasty stuff, but does not call forth apocalyptic visions, at least in this guy. Indeed yellow: lemon yellow, but fairly clear, which prevents it from coming off like a wheat beer. Lotsa head, from start to finish, as is common with Unibroue beers. Interesting aroma on this one: lemon, banana, bready/yeasty flavors, grain dust, and pineapple. Flavor is less multifarious, but still pretty interesting. Not as sweet as I would have thought, a good amount of warming alcohol, noble hoppiness. A faint nuttiness is all I got from the malts; this is mostly about the yeast and various citrusy/mildy sour flavors produced thereby.

La fin du monde...oui, parce que c'est wicked terrible.  Maybe i just don't like this style of beer, but i did not like this one (neither did the two other Ratebeerians who split this with me).  wicked yello (it's so ungodly yellow that i have intentionally left off the 'w' to illustrate the pure toxic yellowness of it) with an odd, unpleasant fruity taste.  i had a near impossible time trying to distinguish what this tasted like because my face contorted in an awful way by the overwhelming awfulness of it.

UPDATED: APR 10, 2005 Another excellent Unibroue offering. Pours a deep cloudy gold with a creamy white head. Aroma of spice and malt. Very smooth and slightly fruity flavor ...  sweet and silky on the palate. Great beer.

750 ml corked & caged brown bottle. Poured out a very pale straw yellow color. Had an enormous, but short lived, creamy white head on it. The head faded to a creamy white lacing on top of the beer itself. Aromas of lemon, lactic wheat, and belgian yeast. That sweet, funky yeast. No discernable hop aroma whatsoever. Tasted fresh, crisp and subdued. No alcohol taste at all here, despite it's rather high ABV rating. Lemon notes in the beginning, with a sweet maltiness in the middle. It has a crisp finish to it also. Not cloying at all. A very drinkable beer from Unibroue. It makes a great lawnmower beer, although rather high in alcohol.

75 cL bottle, wine glass, 48 degrees.  Short lived, fizzy, white head sits atop a hazy, medium-yellow body, which shows lively carbonation.  Heavy dough and cobweb yeast; citric and flower hops; grain and light bread malt; hints of banana and apple; no indication of alcohol in the aroma.  Moderately sweet throughout with a light bitterness to the finish.  Pleasantly acidic throughout with only a tinge of alcohol at the end.  Aroma is translated quite well to the flavor.  Medium-light body has fizzy carbonation and is somewhat drying, but watery otherwise.  The bottom line is: tasty, refreshing, well hidden alcohol...I dig it!

This beer is very good, however, I don't think it lives up to its ratings.  Perhaps it was my bottle, or perhaps it was just me, but I just felt like it left a little lacking - nothing made it stand out very much.  Fairly strong bite, complex hoppy notes to the flavour, it is definitely more potent than the Hoegaarden I tried next.  Medium bitterness, lightly sweet, it is pleasing to the senses, but not overwhelming.

This didn't drink to 9%.  Big white head on a clear, slightly off-amber body.  There is something grape underneath this, and the perfuming aroma develops as it warms.  Very good palate, frothing and drinkable, and a nice yeasty, unalcoholic, fruity, spicy, sweet, complex set of flavors.  A nice, classic Unibroue interpretation.
Very nice! Sweet yeasty aroma. Dark golden opaque colour. Very yeasty flavour, some malt. But I have to tell you, I couldn't really notice the 9% alcoholic content.

Pours a hazy golden orange, lively carbonation that settles quickly and hangs around for the whole glass. Aroma has yeast, pear, citrus, celery. The first sip hits hard. There's some yeast flavor, a bit of malt, soft and sugary sweet, alcohol in the finish. You can feel this beer warming you up- not a great choice for a warm summer night. But on the other hand I love tripels, so maybe the rating is a little biased. I'm impressed, especially considering that the first time I had this over a year ago (before I starting drinking real beers) I thought this beer more closely resembled smoked ham than anything else. My tastes have changed I guess.
this is my first rated beer and i'm not a snob so forgive me.  it reminds me of southern bbq.  the taste and smell.  if you enjoy that kind of thing then this is the beer for you

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2003 Aroma is pears and apricots. Appearance is murky yellow. Flavor is spicy with some citrus fruit. Overall a decently flavorful belgian blond similiar to alot of Unibroue's beers. Not bad.
UPDATED: NOV 10, 2003 It always amazes me how these Tripels can be so much smoother and more drinkable than the Dubbels. Unibroue hit the mark with this one. Much better this time around.

Crazy light pale blonde colour with a brilliantly white thick head. The colour is unusually light for a tripel, but would look good for a belgie white. Aroma of wheat, yeast, corn and bananas. Once again, more of a white style than a tripel. Good thick mouthful, and pretty sharp initially...yeast, sugars and spices make up the taste. The palate is pretty drying, some of the hop characteristics come out in the aftertaste, but thats about it. Basically, a big let-down, and yet another by Unibroue. I had a 750 mL bottle purchased at Southtown Beverage in Rochester, New York.
UPDATED: JAN 4, 2004 A good one ! A pale and cloudy yellow colour, a nice fruity aroma and a good yeasty/malty taste. Maybe just a bit too sweet. Perfect for cold evenings.

I untwisted the wire and the cork was gone! Pours cloudy pale gold with a frothy off white head into my Duvel glass. Lively carbonation.  Aroma is spicy and yeasty. Temperature is  56 degrees F. Flavor is sweet, spicy (orange, coriander, and clove), lightly bitter with some alcohol presence. Finish is somewhat acidic and kinda dry. Long mouth watering aftertaste. The 9% ABV makes it's self known. I like it !!!
One of the best beers i've ever had.  Just one question, where are they hiding this alcohol?! I certainly can't taste it, but after 3 beers, i can sure feel it!  Way to go Unibroue.
Cloudy yellow color with a big white head. Aroma of yeast and malt. Flavor is sweet, spicy, acidic and dry.
Esters from high gravity fermentation combined with alcohol, fruit and candy in the nose.  A very smooth drinking beer despite the high alcohol.

Robust german wheat appearance--brown gold with incredible lacing-tiny, fine bubbles composing a luscious cream head. The aroma was of delicious, but nto overdone yeast and a woody atmosphere.  Good creamy initial touch on the lips, but that was also the downfall. This brew was too smooth and the flavors flattened after the initial taste. SOme yeast and wood and alcohol more noticeable towards the end, but still well integrated. The flavor was not quite as robust as advertised, but this was an easy drinking, tasteful Tripel all the same.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2005 Very cloudy with not alot of head. Decent finish with a spicy flavor. Very alcoholic first few sips but halfway through you warm up to the sweet tastes and forget about the alcohol which may not be a good thing.

Cloudy light honey color. Pours nice with diminishing white head. Nose is malt and citrus. Sweet, but fruit sweet, with light spice and alcohol warmness. Light carbonation and very yeasty with a share of malt. After you swallow its as if it was never there, the finish is so light leaving only slight spice and mild hops. Warms the belly though. Very good.

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2003 The glass rapidly fills with a big white head. The beer is golden, pale enough. It smells fruits, malt and spices. In mouth, the alcohol is on the frontline, more than for the Fringante who proposed 10% ABV. Lemon, coriander and other sweet components stick to this alcohol and malt and leave a warming astringent feeling.

It does fit the style quite well. The sweetness and alcohol shine through. As with alot of unibroue products sometimes you get a good bottle sometimes you don't. On a good bottle pours a large white quickly deminishing head. Lots of particles. Easy enough to drink despite the prevailent alcohol. Better than most beers you'll find at the corner store.

UPDATED: NOV 19, 2007 November 2007. Hazy golden yellow body with a big billowy white head. Aroma is yeasty and alcoholic, light underlying notes of dry lemony citrus and muted wisps of peppery spice in both the flavour and the aroma. Alcohol is a touch prominent when you first start but mellows wonderfully as the glass goes on. Has the basic characteristics of a Belgian tripel - dry alcohol balanced by sweet pale malt with moderate hop bitterness and light spicy notes. Smooth medium palate is fairly effervescent, pleasantly so. Fairly drinkable, though the dry alcohol occasionally snaps you back to attention. 8/4/8/4/16

July 2003. Bottle. Can kind of smell the alcohol in the aroma, and taste it a tiny bit at first. The alcohol sticks out more as it warms. Goes down easy enough for me to polish off a six pack in a night, and strong enough for me to regret that fact in the morning. just a hint of bitter, and some spices especially in the aftertaste.. 8/4/8/4/16
UPDATED: JUL 9, 2003 Yellowish color, with a small head that left no lacing.  Somewhat carbonated, with a sweet citrus, sour taste to it.

Cloudy yellow gold color. Tall white head. Fruity aroma. Starts with a crisp dry malty flavor and endis in a ripe fruity flavor with hints of candy sugar.  Has a slight sour apple flavor, and a slight touch of bananna. Another delicious offering from Unibroue.

Lots of foamy head.  Beer is orange-yellow or light golden in color.  Head contains very large bubbles that linger.  The aroma and flavor is of straw and grass.  Alcohol is well hidden, but i'm not a fan of the blondes.  Sampled at 72 degrees Fahrenheit.

Cloudy gold color with a big white head. Lots of yeast. Fruity esters: banana and some citrus. Similar flavor. Clean finish. Well-hidden 9%. The end of the world isn't a big Belgian blonde from Quebec, but it isnt too far off though.
Hazy golden body with a fluffy white head. Yeasty, and apple aromas. Light sweet and crisp feel, with flavors of yeast, bananas and apple sourness

Big, pure white head with some scattered laceing. Hazey pale blonde color. Sulfury, yeasty nose, some breadiness also. Light/medium body. Big carbonation, spritsey. Soft malt flavors, fruity, some bubble gum notes with some coriander flavors too. Tart, dry finish. 9% alc. is well hidden. A nice big blonde ale, the end of the world? NAAAAAA, but i do like nice big blondes!

Color a pale, cloudy yellow color with yeast floating around, nice white frothy head leaving clingy, patchy lace. Smells of lemon and tropical fruit, banana, with a hint of spice and sweet bitterness. Taste is more of the same, citrusy and tropically smooth and clean with a spicy lemon dry finish thats warming from the alcohol. Feel is medium body sweet and fruity flavors that dry out, nice, crisp and clean finish with warming qualities from alcohol. Pretty drinkable but is a sipper, 9%, it'll sneak up on you for sure

UPDATED: APR 21, 2006 Citric aroma.
Pale cloudy yellow, champagne bubbles, white soap head.
Citrus, yeast and some low key belgian funk. Also some ethanol and phenolic notes. Deceivingly light body makes you go to the end of the world...eh...bottle fast.

Light gold color. Small head. Aroma is yeasty, fruity and citrusy. A medium bodied Belgian tripel. Fruity, bright, yeasty and spicy, all the things an Abbey Triple should be. Complex flavors are intermingling here. Apples, oranges and peaches mix with coriander, cloves and allspice (?) to make a very pleasant tasting beer. Add its extremely fine champagne like carbonation and this beer is a real winner. Very smooth. The 9% alcohol is hidden fairly well. It does peak out occasionally, as every once in a while there is a touch of alcohol bite and it is a real belly warmer. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and dry. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.
a subtle fruity aroma...mainly bananas. Nice golden color with a white head.  Smooth fruity taste with a malty finish.
Golden color, thin white head. Had a light aroma of whiskey and 7UP and a champagne-like aroma. Very well hidden alcohol. Overall a nice drink.

Pours cloudy gold with a white head that disappears quickly. Looks a lot like a hefeweizen, actually. Smells of roasted grain and a little malt, plus some alcohol. Mellow at first, with a salty hop flavor, then a sweet grainy flavor. It seems a bit sloppy in the carbonation, as well. Has a dry, long aftertaste.
Light yellow in color, somewhat cloudy.  Yeasty aroma.  Flavor is yeasty almost like a weiss or wit mixed a sweet fruit flavor of bananas and apples.  Dry finish.  Good Beer
Pale yellow color, very frothy head and effervescent carbonation.  Nice, light taste despite the 9% alcohol.  An excellent beer.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2009 Murky bright yellow color with a large foamy white head. Looks like a wit.  Aroma of Dawn dish soap and orange and lemon peel.  Nice spicy flavors at first, turning to a more alcoholic and soapy feel mixed with a pleasent wheat taste.  Leaves the mouth very spicy and jumpy.
Not bad but just didn't really do it for this hophead. A somewhat spicy belgian ale I guess. Afterwards I used a Stone IPA to bring my tastebuds back in line...

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2004 Appearance is cloudy and opaque.   Scents of spice, cirtus, orange and corriander.  Spicy taste, orange and corriander come through. Very light body and taste considering the alcohol content.
Lots of bubbles with a medium-thick white head.  Sweet, yeasty nose.  Dark straw yellow in appearance, with cloves, yeasty, and a spice metallic character to the body.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2004 Deep yellow colour, cloudy with lots of creamy white head and great lacing. Aroma is yeasty and spicy, with cloves, nutmeg, maybe cinnamon. Full bodied with sweet citrus and spicy flavours. Finishes with a subtle alcohol bitterness.

Good, highly drinkable Belgian style triple fermented ale.  Bottle conditioned in 750 ml container.  Attractive golden-amber slightly hazy color with average, quickly diminishing head and fair lacing.  Very complex aroma with wheat, honey, apple, flowers, lemon, coriander, clove and lots of yeast.  Initial sweet and acidic malt and yeast flavors, nicely balanced with hops.  Flavors became more complex as the ale warmed up bringing a bit more citrus to the ever-present yeast.  Not outstanding, but definitely worth the special club price.  I look forward to trying the other bottle in a few months to see how it ages.
Complex nose, caramel malt flavors and plenty of spiced falvors as well. Finishes with a strong alcohol flavor (but not in a bad way)
UPDATED: JUN 21, 2003 What a nose! Great texture and the yeast was especially present. The wheaty flavor was a bit much for me, but definately something that I wouldnt mind having again.
Wheaty, alcoholic nose.  A whiff of peaches and some cinnamon.  Nice and solid, but not outstanding.  Citrusy, not a definitive malt presence.  Alcohol is very evident when cold.
alcohol was apparent in the flavor, sharp to the tongue, cloudy, rather malty and yeasty, a good belgian tripel
UPDATED: MAY 13, 2003 Light yellow in color. Yeasty aroma with very small head.Taste of citrus with a little bit of bitterness on the finish. Overall a decent belgium tripel.
Cloudy yellow with a standing head.  Yeasty aroma.  Sweet and creamy, almost wheaty flavor with citric borders.  Quite good.

See my review for Don De Dieu for everything except color as La Fin Du Monde is a bright lemon color.  Not that they are bad beers just to similar to tell apart.  In fact they taste like Blanche de Chambly as my wife reminded me.

This lovely treat reminded me of New Belgium's Trippel. Similar wheat/citrus aroma and flavorful body. I did find La Fin to be a bit more complex, but maybe that was only because it was a touch heavier. Just a bit of a light, slowly disapating head.
A light golden ale with smooth frothy head. Body lighter than expected but stil carries a nice flavor profile of fruit and spice.

Bright golden. Ever-so-slightly hazy. Surprisingly thin head for Unibroue. Light yeast esters in the nose--banana, cloves, maybe a touch of pepper. Very fine, smooth carbonation. Medium to full bodied. Silky mouthfeel. A sharp tart bite up front. Mellows quickly and beautifully. More bananas in the middle with some slight malt sweetness. Definite wheat notes. Lightly bitter finish with a pronounced note of cloves. Refreshing and deliciously complex.
This is some good stuff.  Loads of citrus, has an incredible finish.  Nice mix of spices.

A nice tripel and a decent beer to make my 100th beer rated on RateBeer.  (Wish it were Westvleteren instead but it will do).  Yeasty, loaded with that citrusy hoppy aroma but a nice balance of sweetness and malt in the finish.  Spicy and flowery in taste.  A good beer and one on my repurchase list.

Hazy gold body, huge frothy white head.  Aroma of lemon and citrus.  Flavor of alcohol and spice, some notes of citrus fruit, maybe orange.  Smooth palate with a dry, mellow finish.  Another great brew from Unibroue.

Sweet, honey like aroma, musky. Light wheat/yeast profile with citrus. Vapory. Low hops. Sour cherry aroma after pouring sediment. Nice white foamy lacing head atop slightly cloudy butterscotch-orange liquid. Medium effervescence - light on the tongue. Medium silky watery body. Lightly sweet but it sticks with you in the finish and after. Citrus,wheat,yeast and small pleasant bitterness. Fruity sweet in the back of the throat. A little alcohol. A little more bitterness after pouring sediment.  Nice beer.
Bright golden color with a nice white head. Aroma of clove and coriander. Flavor was very good with a good complex mix of clove, coriander, malt and a little bitterness. A very good brew.

Very cloudy, caramel-orange color. Well-defined citrus flavor (oranges?) Spices and yeast flavors abound. Not for the faint of heart, although the alcohol content does not overwhelm you. Overall, a pretty good Tripel.
I think this is one of the best Triple's made, it is a great beer.  Very drinkable...

Fruit highlighted nose of oranges and a little spicy too. Rich gold colr and a huge rocky spongy head. Apricot-like maltiness, like french-vanilla ice cream. Full body and a creamy texture. Alcohol is pretty well hidden, but there is a pleasant throat-warming effect.

This beer has a brilliant glow, intoxicating aroma, and refreshing zest.  I'd drink this beer under any conditions but it really hits the spot after a cold day on the slopes of Monte Sainte Anne.  Don't drink the bottom or the 4th fermentation will occur in your stomach!

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2003 " If I remember correctly, this beer had a hint of a malted bourbon flavor.The bottle contains lots of settlement, making it a pale cloudy beer. This beer will kick your butt it is strong. I think “La Fin Du Monde” means the “End Of The World” "
One of my fav style of beer, La Fin Du Monde does not dissapoint. Wonderful aroma, fruity orange flavor, and a beautiful mouthfeel. I love Unibroue beers so much!

acidic, yeasty nose. Murky orange, medium fluffy head. Fizzy carbonation. Alcohol, vanilla, yeast and banana in taste. Slightly peppery. Fullmouth - smooth - suprisingly if you see how fizzy it is. Yummie
THIS is what a Belgian style is all about. Might just be one of the best beers made in North America.  They should be awfully proud of the yeasts they accumulated to produce this gem.

this is my first tripel ... very interesting ... almost yellow in color, very cloudy ... head dissapated quickly, probably due to the heavy carbonation ... flavor is sweet but almost a little sour ... alcohol is present in the flavor but isnt over powering at all ... clean finish ...
Shared big 750ml bottle. Good solid tripel. Just lacking a tas in the flavor catergory. Like mine a little sweeter.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2003 Another first impression Whoa! This brew foamed up 1/4 brew, 3/4 foam as I poured it into my glass. Its head was a very white color. The bubbles in the head ranged from small to large. Again, this is another very carbonated brew. This brew also had a very mild aroma. It too was hard for me to distinguish from other smells. It has a very light orange color with yeast particles floating in it. Its flavor contains a variety of different tastes. The carbonation once again rolls off the tongue. It is adding to my buzz tonight. I liked the flavor and taste of the brew. It agrees with me very much. All in all an excellent brew!  This brew is very potent and it added to my buzz for the evening. Hotstuff gave it a 4.55 rating and said she could drink it for the evening, but would be very drunk and that we would have a great time!
Pale yellow in color with a large, white head. Citrus (esp. grapefruit) aroma, slightly spicey. Flavor is citrusy at the front, yeasty, with a spicey finish and a touch of alcohol at the end.

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2004 Miniscule Brussels Lace feverishly dancing among yeast and spice sediment make this one of the most beatiful beers I have seen in a while.  Two-finger head poured, traces of head remained to the last sip.  Suberp!   Yeasty, clove, corriander, citrus taste.  Very complex.  Outstanding beer!

Hazy golden liquid with a moderate sturdy off white head.  Drunken oranges marching yeast to the bread factory aroma. Thick feel.  Nice background of malt with pepper and chalky yeast flavors.  A decent relax and enjoy tipple.
Decent yellow yeasty beer.  Taste and smell slighlty astringent but nice and tangy tart flavor throughout.  Good flavor.  A bit thin on the texture for my taste.  Nice alcohol kick.

This beer poured a golden straw color and formed a bubbly white head that left circular lace. A small amount of carbonation was present. It had an aroma of citrus, spice(?clove) and some yeast elements. The flavor was of spice and citrus with a warming feeling of the alcohol present. The finish was a touch astrigent

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2004 A solid brew with a pretty noticeable alcohol taste.  The rest of the beer, makes you not care about the alcohol.  Not too bitter, with a yeast-like texture.  Highly recommended------ 3/19/04.  This was the beer that got me hooked on beer and Rate Beer.  Now that I look back at my original rating, its pretty pitiful.  12 oz bottle this time.  Nose is fruity, I smell pineapples, malts, yeasts, and spices.  Don't remember the aroma being so pleasant.  Pours hazy blonde with a HUGE white head.  Very sweet and fruity start--really taste what appears to be pineapple.  Sweet candies in the middle.  Alcohol hidden well.  Nice palate.  I agree with my initial rating.  This seems much better than the first time I had it.

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2003 Sweet and malty taste with nice fizzy carbonation.  Huge head on pour, took many minutes to settle.  High alcohol content hidden very well, you wouldn't come close to thinking this was 9% abv.  Overall very nice.

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2003 I smell apple and alcohol in the aroma.  Pours a cloudy straw color, small head and minimal lacing, very small bubbles.  Great mouthfeel.  The ABV is well hidden, flavor is  a hint of apple with an alcohol finish.  Almost champagne like.

Awesome nose of hazelnut, vanilla, apple, and alchol.  Pours a light hazy honey blond.  I left the floaties in the bottle.  The average white frothy white head is mostly diminishing with no lacing.  The sweet flavor starts highly acidic and malty, and the finish is long and sweet.  The medium dry fizzy body finishes mostly astringent with a hint at the brew's gravity.  An excellent brew.
The perfect amount of sweetness.  The high alcohol content is well hidden.  Carbonation is strong.  Definately one of my top choices.

UPDATED: MAR 5, 2003 Begins with cloudy, soft gold color and snowy white (thick) head. Aroma is nice, slightly sweet, and subtle. Flavor is much like the aroma, and is really very nice. Very easy on the palatte and simply delicious. Another fine beer from Unibroue!

Mostly diminishing head. Light, hazy, golden pale color.  Fine sediment floating, probably from the pour or too much agitation.  Clove and light banana, as others have said.  Fairly smooth.  The alcohol pokes its head out just a little just so you know it's there.  I need to drink more Belgian styles so I can get a feel for the flavors in these brews.  They're a lot more delicate than the stuff I'm used to drinking.

Pretty hazy yellow color with a bright white head...very similar in appearance to a whiskey sour. The aroma and flavor had nice clove and sweet banana tones with just a hint of hops bitterness to round it out. Very pleasant beer.
a very intresting trip.  light, smooth yet solid.  I liked it a lot more then several other trips i've had, probably a better "drinking" beer.
very good triple.  It has a tang in the flavor but hides its strength well.  It has a similar nuance to other Unibroue beers that seems to come from yeast.  A Quebecois Belgian style triple perhaps.
UPDATED: JUN 20, 2003 I'm glad they finally changed the laws in Ohio so we can get treasures like this.  A wonderful belgian ale that knocks your socks off.

Hazy lemon/orange colour, with a creamy off white head, that lingers until the last drop.  Another beautiful beer from Unibroue this one has a calming grassy, yeasty smell, that has hints of orange.  Heavenly mouth feel, light on the tongue and spicy through the finish.  I generally like the belgian double style better than the blone/triple style, but this is one of my favourites of the later.

Lasting white head and lace on sides of the glass; hazy gold color.  Clove and citrus, yeasty and fruity, with a hint of alcohol in the aroma.  Malty start with a dry finish, well balanced but finishes with a hop flavor; not overwhelming, but not something I'd expect from a stronger blonde ale.  Alcohol, clove, peppery flavor, but not as complex as I'd like it.  The fruitiness in the aroma doesn't quite carry through to the flavor, at least not as much.  Explosive carbonation, something I'd expect from a Belgian style ale, but this is a little astringent and dry in the mouth.  I haven't had a bad beer from Unibroue yet, but this is not my favorite.

This lemon gold beer is cloudy and the small bubbles form a nice head that dissipates after a short time. The nose is yeasty with hints of lavender and slight citrusy hops. The body is very rich, soft and satisfying with sweet maltiness and a bready/doughy yeastiness. The finish is honeyed and faintly hints at lemon peel.
1/17/03:  bottle.  light golden- yellow color.  very active: lots of carbonation.  evident lacing.  yeasty and a bit of lemony flavor.

Sparkling gold body with a thin but persistent head. Some lacing.
Yeasty and floral nose. The left over tasties from the three yeasts used in fermentation can be smelled.
Yeasty taste overpowers the maltiness but the hop finish is nice. Strong enough to be noticed but not too strong as to overpower the yeastiness.
Carbonated like champagne. This probably helps the lightness of the beer.
Not too bad for not being monks.

hazy yellow pour with frothy head.  Too carbonated for my tastes - bubbles bouncing all over the glass for the duration of the beer.  The carbonation ruined the mouthfeel for me and combined with spicy flavor, burnt my throat all the way down.  Not malty and the aftertaste is spicy - not hop spicy but more like black pepper spicy.  Not my favorite style nor my favorite representation of the style.

big beer, big price.  if you know your geography, you'll recognize a cartographical depiction of labrador and eastern quebec on the label.  but if like most americans, you don't know poland from the pleiades, you'll wonder why there's a backlit buffalo patty so handsomely rendered.  in either case, it's significance is unexplained, and in fact is irrellevant once you find yourself personally and emotionally involved with the beer itself. a very pastel yellow pour, only slightly more vibrant than creamed corn, it wears a bright snowy crown momentarily, but too soon finds it cumbersome and casts it aside, prefering a naked straw blonde simplicity.  a huge champagne bubbly aroma is consistent with the release of volumns of carbon dioxide, (eek!--a greenhouse gas contributing to global warming!) and then notes of pear, bread dough, golden apples and vaseline intensive care lotion. taste is very much like a sparkling cider, sweet and brisk on the tongue, yet more creamy. yeasty as any weizen-- without being citrus thankfully-- and tho the hops are discreet, a light tartness across the finish suggests that they're there to leash any undue sweetness.  a brisk beverage for brunch, with a smart buzz that will unfetter the shyest tongue.
A most enjoyable light-colored beer with good somewhat fruity tones. It"s so good I"ve gone out of my way to get it.

Pours a lightly hazed golden.  Small champagne like bubbles race to the top, battling the sediment for the quickest path to join their fellows in the thick white head.  Aroma is medium fruity (banana and apple), and lightly yeaty.  Flavor is apple and banana, ending clean and dry with some yeast undertones.
Another winner from Unibroue.  Not quite as good as the Maudite.  Perhaps a little drier, while the Maudite is sweeter and fruitier.  This one has very nice lace.
Nice head and colour. Discreet aroma of lemon. It has the taste of a wheat beer with an aftertaste a little bit heavy. A good beer.

Poured a wonderfull yellow haze with a fluffy head and good lacing.  Soft on the palate, this was full of apricots and spices.  Yeasty, tangy, a little alcohol apparent.  One of the best of the triple style

Straw colored with little head.  This beer had tons of carbonation, and lots of stuff floating in amongst the bubbles.  Mouthfeel was thick, boardering on chewy, which was bit of a surprise.  Tastes were bananna and cloves, which I expected.  The presence of hop bitterness, taste, or aroma was negligible.  The ABV was very, very well masked except for a tingle on the tongue and a warming of the gut.  Overall this beer was pretty good, but could use some more assertiveness on the hop end of the spectrum.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2003 Hazy dark yellow in color, the bubbly head dissappated rather quickly to just a little foam around the edge of the glass, lots of different fruity characterists in the nose, has quite a bit of undertones similar to a Belgian Wit beer, some hints of sour veggies in the flavors, very well balanced though, I guess it"s drinkable if you are into this brewer"s beers, but I guess I just don"t care for Unibroue"s stuff

Interesting aroma, is pale yellow in appearance and quite cloudy. Has a complex flavour, spicy aftertaste that would be similar to Leffe Blond. Even though it is quite stong, you cant really taste the alcohol. Satisfying - recommended.

Oh how sweet The End of The World is - no Im not a freakin nihilist, I just like the beer. Very traditionally Belgian, and very traditional Unibroue, but the thing I found that sets this apart from others is the apparent nuttiness in the yeast. The remarkable smoothness of the yeast with the fruity esters is very appealing, almost like a hazelnut/peach combonation. Not my favorite from Unibroue but very nice.
Hazy yellow,white head.Yeasty citrus nose(orange).Flavor has both malt and yeast, with harsh unpleasant alcohol heat

Great banana - muesli aroma with squeze of lemon, but I smelled better in some other beers. Slightly hazy yellowish look got some carbonation, white head. Strong drink but alcohol was blended in great way. Yeasty, acidic plus alcohol. Nice mix. Thanks Doug!
Cloudy straw-yellow color.Yeast and citrus notes dominate. Refreshing and fun to drink. Alcohol isnt even noticeable. A very good beer,certainly worth having again.
long lasting head.  reminded me a lot of don de dieu.  i am becoming more of a friend of this brewery the more i taste of it.
A very dry Belgian Tripel, not as heavy or sweet as some of them are.  The flavor is refreshing, citrusy, and the alcohol is masked well.  Essence of apples.

This is a very drinkable belgian, but nothing about it seems to "shine" and stand out like in many other Unibroue beers.  It seems pretty mediocre to me.  Slight citrus and malt tastes and a dry finish.  I probably wont buy this again.
Not a great appearance, but a nice solid taste -- strong but still smooth and drinkable.
Once again the strong alcohol prescence takes away from the other positive characteristics of this beer.

Re-Rate 12/28/02: One sip of a Unibroue beer several years ago started a continuous love affair with this brewery, and the whole line of their beers, La Fin Du Monde was that first beer, what a stroke of luck that was for this Grizzled Old Beer Swiller.
As it pours from the bottle, a slightly hazy lemon yellow, the head creamy in texture, the size masterful, the color a brilliant white, as it evanesces it leaves a silky sheet of fine lace to cover the glass.  The aroma of finely malted grains dominates the nose, citrus crisp, lightly sweet and a pleasure to the senses. Ambrosial start with lots of malt, the top middling in its feel with a spirited acidity, masterfully hopped, and a long drawn-out aftertaste that is dry. The 9% ABV, make this a real Belly Warmer, for these cold winter days and nights, a beer I love, and I always have a few bottles on hand as they age gracefully and I wish I could say the same for my own self. Ranks #282 on my current 1000 beer master list.

A convincing almost-Belgian tripel.  I like it better than the Allagash, for example, and possibly more than the real thing.  Strong taste of yeast, but not too yeasty or bready.  Lightly hopped.  Deceptively easy to drink for a 9% ABV.
This is a nice one for a lighter belgian ale.  Similar in charactewr to Duvel, but less hops.  Weak aroma but rich flavor.  Small but enduring head.

Have heard this is similar to Trois Pistoles, but havent tried it yet. I like the Unibroue beers as well if not better than Chimay. The price difference isnt bad either. The nose is a bit citric with a slight spice undertone.

UPDATED: APR 5, 2004 Blonde color, fizzy champaigne-like head.  Huge, fruity, slightly citric nose.  Very yeasty, with a big robust mouthfeel and peppery finish.  Alcohol is fairly well hidden within the big body.  Many similarities to Trois Pistoles - aroma especially.  Mmmmm.
UPDATED: JAN 29, 2003 Has a yellow/orange color and a slight alcohol smell.  Taste is similar to Trois Pistols, but it does not have the high alcohol flavor.   I would get it again.
Another quality beer from Unibroue. Big, yeasty and belgian with a nutty and fruity smell and flavor. This is a good brewery.

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2005 Not quite as interesting as Maudite.  The cloudier the glass the better the taste.  Need to mix up the citrus flavours to really enjoy.  Malt is not that strong.  Liquid Gold?  OK!
very good beer. comes corked and ready to please. good taste..and maybe its just the fact that its from canada that i seem to taste maple..lol..
Beautiful head that takes forever to dissipate when you pour it.  Good flavor, a little more acidic than Id prefer but no biggie.  Damn good beer.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2010 I have tried to like Unibroue beers several times since the first time I rated them but I cannot get past the strong spicy/celery flavor and aroma that seems to be present in all of their beers.  Very large and frothy head, nice golden clouded color.  Flavor is initially sweet then powerful spice.  A decent Tripel.

Very interesting to say the least. I needed to back off on my pouring a few times because the mighty head nearly overflowed. This one poors a cloudy mustard yellow with a huge head that will die down quickly after a sip or two and leave a nice creamy layer. The aroma is that of a mild malt mixed in with something of a nutmeg smell. The taste is very powerful as many have pointed out with a considerable tasting of that extra yeast and alcohol. The palate however is very happy with this rogue aftertaste, its a pleasant surprise, and once again, another above average blonde. I guess i will have to take back my original statement that the only thing good to ever come out of Canada was William Shatner...i guess Unibroue deserves a place up there too. Probably the biggest downer for this beer is the overwhelmingness of the yeast left from the triple fermentation process..sort of makes one cringe from time to time but gets better with every sip. Another must try again.

nice golden clouded color.  Swete aroma and flavor to match.  Alcohol is a little too present, but is balanced nicely by the malt.  Not my favorite belgian ale, but something that would go well with a meal, not so much on its own.

A light color yellow cloudy colored beer, a light too carbonated.  A fruity tart smell of peaches, oranges, grapes, and apples. Sweet tasting of fruit plus the nich high alcohol feeling warming you up. Not my favorite Unibroue Product but a good one indeed.
Not one of my favorite products from Unibroue.  This was a light yellow- overly carbonated belgianb that was very sweet and alcoholic.  A little too sweet for my tastes
UPDATED: APR 7, 2005

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2003 (Re-Rate) I try to like this beer, hence my third re-rate. I was rather harsh the first couple of times and I am learning to appreciate La Fin du Monde. Pours a thin pearly white head with a slightly cloudy, straw body. Looks beautiful. Thick carbonation. Aroma of lemon, honey and yeast. Bold and powerful dry taste. Getting to like you! (Original) Its like openning a bottle of turpentine. With all the alcohol in this beer it is hard to taste anything else. Originator to the term: Death by 6-pack. I cant fathom why Unibroue makes this when they have so many excellent Quebec products. (Score 1.9)

ive had this several times but never in the circumstances to rate it. it is a hazy hefe light peachish color but thats where the story ends, no banana bubble gum flavas goin on heyah.  ok, maybe a tad bit of bubble gum. or juicy fruit? and even though you cant really taste the alcohol you just KNOW it is strong cuz it hits your tummy in a warm whammy. (hubby said "ew, this is strong" so i might be mistaken about being able to taste the alcohol. then again, he likes bud.)

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2003 poured clear but settled  in a schoolbus glow with big and little bubbles alike partying on top..aroma spoke in showers of spice..coriander & nutmeg surrounded in orange peel forests and blizzards of cinnimonaroma was a complete foreshadowing of the flavor except for the slight alcohol burn...a tad chalky in texture..overzelous carbination...turns to week old orange juice in the finish..average over spiced belgian

Very classic Belgian ale.  Light hazy lemon color, much like lemonade.  Oranges and light fruit, spice, and alcohol.  Dry finish.  The alcohol is really strong throughout, which some may not enjoy as it sits on the palate.  For those that like stron ales this is worth checking out.

Pours a cloudy golden yellow with a big white head. Very smooth flavor with a nice balance of hops and malts. Has a dry and somewhat spicy finish that is very nice. Unibroue brews may be the best things to have come out of Canada.

Giant white head, tons of carbonation.  Hazy pale golden hue.  Bell pepper aroma as indicated by the mighty Oakes, as well as light spice, light fruit, orange.  Alcohol is evident, malts are nice, light to medium bodied, big fruity body, and pepper and dry in the finish.  These guys are excellent, im always impressed.  The larger cork finished bottles are always better, they mellow and meld flavors nicely with age.  WOOOHOO!

Misty golden color with a gurgling, frothy head leaves a sparkling mesh of lace sliding down the glass. Yeasty citrus aroma with clues of spices. Floral(roses?). Sweet malty flavor with a touch of tropical fruit and cloves. Mild hops and talcy faintly dry finish.

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2004 Rerate Bubblegum sweetness is the most prominent flavor coming through this time around. Still damn good, tastes have just refined a bit in the last two years.  Original 4.0 Second of the Unibroue's that I have tried - even though it has 9% ABV - it hides it well.  Clean, fresh, fruity aroma, bubbly, champagne-like appearance. Good mouthfeel - wakes your tastebuds up with its crispness and spiciness.
Amber, hazy, colour. head doesnt last long. Yeasty, slightly acidic, with a touch of toffee, aroma. The flavour reminds me of a way too strong Witbier. It gave me a heartburn!

This time I left the sediment behind in the bottle so it poured an very faintly hazy medium gold. Head is still small. Aroma was similar to the first rating but included a stronger vinous aroma. Palate was a bit smoother. Less spicey/yeasty and more sweet fruity  is consistent with leaving the yeast in the bottle.  
First rated 9/20/2002 3.5 Faint hazy yellow brown under a shortish lasting off-white crusty bubbled head. Fine specks of beige sediment. Faint soapy sappy hops aroma warming to a medium strong cirtus honey and caramel malty, spicey golden syrup, especially when glass is swirled. Medium body with medium strong wheat, lemon and honey flavours do a fair job of masking the high ABV. Spices  (coriander and nutmeg?) linger in finish and aftertaste. An interesting and different brew but not smooth or well blended enough to challenge Terrible or even La Maudite.
Pours cloudy with foamy head that dissipates quickly.  Very spicy with hints of citrus and banana then fades into a blend of malt and yeast.
Nice crystal clear light blonde.  Slightly sweet, with a hint of attitude at the end to make you come back for more.  Man I love this brewery!

Not as good as I remembered it this is still a fine drink and a blessing to New World fans of Belgian style brewing, as is Unibroue in general. The beer pours with an active but short-lived head, though retaining enough to enhance the mouthfeel. Aromas of citrus and spice, dominate along with a hearty maltiness, grassy herbal notes and earthy yeast. The beer remains a milky sedimented yellow/amber - at least it does if you pour the yeast, as I did. There is a definite lemony quality to the beer, herbal? - lemon verbena , lemon grass, etc. Bready banana and honey flavors, plenty of malt, enough tartness for contrast and complexity and a fairly clean finish. Nonetheless, I dont think its Unibroues best.

Sweet spicy lemon zest aroma.Dark golden cloudy appearence with fine streams of bubbles that shoot up the sides of my tulip glass.Flavours of tangerines,pinapple,banana rum and honey.I like this beer but it seems to me like all those flavours get kind of muddled resulting in a slightly dirty finish.

This ale is a great bottle to take to a party and start conversations.  People who only drink Lite will ask "what is that?" and anyone with an open mind will be begging to try a swig.  Just the fact that its called "The End of the World" puts it high on my list.  Great citrusy flavor but not too malty.

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2011 Re-rate 12/18/11: It had been a while since Id had this, so I figured it was time for a rerate.  12oz bottle, best by 7/27/14.  Pours a slightly hazy bright golden with a pillowy froth of clingy-lacing white head.  Has a floral bready nose with some light wheaty sweetness and banana esters with a touch of cloves.  Starts with good fullness and fine carbonation with a pleasant biscuity sweetness and mild bitter balance with some orange citrus and clove spice.  Finishes smooth and bittersweet, hiding the alcohol well.  Very true to style and enjoyable.

Original rating 10/30/02: Butterscotch aroma and cloudy golden body.  Solid fruity and malty flavor masks most of the alcohol and the finish is dry and clean.  It doesnt quite have the aged oilyness in the palate many of the better Belgian ales have, but hey, its not the end of the world, so sit back and enjoy it, because its still a respectable brew.

A cloudy amber/orange color with a light, white head.  Citrus fruit and spice complement each other nicely.  The mouthfeel is a bit too sharp for me, but all in all, this quite a nice beer, with the familiar Unibroue characteristics.

Im glad the fruitiness of this beer is strongly balanced with sharper gingery and peppery accents.  Im glad, too, that theres a citric ice-tea kick at close.  Without those touches, this thing would too closely resemble a yuppie fruit drink - it still tastes suspiciously like something you could get in the Oasis juice bar in Ann Arbor.
Not a bad beer, kinda hoppy.  Also expensive for me.  not bad though.

My appreciation for this fine ale
grew appreciably when it appeaped on a
menu at the Hollywood Brown Derby at MGM 
Studios at Walt Disney World.  This fine
ale increased that dining experience immensely
and I am grateful.  Smells and pours good.  Nice head
retention with light lacing.  Very nice yeast flavor, not a trace of the 9% 
ABV.  Very nice.

UPDATED: NOV 10, 2005 Twist-off cap removal yielded a lively release.  This is one of the better looking Triples in a glass; the dense and creamy foam never relents.  Huge aroma full of ginger, peach, pepper, vanilla, mango, green olive, lemon zest, wood, and some toastines; there are also some subtle phenolic hints.  Medium-full palate with yeasty softness.  Moderately complex flavors of anise, peach, zucchini bread, honey, white grape, kiwi, and black pepper.  Perhaps this boasts more tropical fruitinesss than any other Triple I have experienced.  Finishes with tea notes and subtle hop leaf bitterness.  Readily availablity always makes this a mainstay at my home.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: I could not believe my eyes when I came across this and 2 other Unibroue beers at a local general store.  Immediately I cursed myslef for only having ten dollars and not having the internet on my cell phone to see which product was the one to get!  Ah well, this one was definately a good choice.  Light golden in appearance with a cloudy haze, this brew reminded me somewhat of Duvel.  A buttery soft, lasting head came up nicely from the yellow liquid.  Pears, apple and wet dog were all appearant in the initial nosing.  As the beer warmed, alcohol made its presence as well, though not too much.  Beautifully balanced with a palate wetting hop bite. Wonderful.  alcohol is there in the first few sips, but is soon put in its place by the complexities this beer holds onto throughout the glass.  An exquisite blegian strong ale that deserves at least a 4 rating and a must try for any serious beer taster.

Sometimes you get a new beer and you expect too much out of it. I was so hoping that this would be a GREAT beer that there was probably no way it could live up to it. To put it bluntly I was unimpressed with it. Just aan average belgian style golden ale. mild flowery aroma with a cloudy yellow apperance and a huge bubbly foamy head. Taste fruity with a hint of flower and spice. Once again just average.

UPDATED: MAY 4, 2003 This beer rocks.
A complex and excellent beer. The aroma was lightly floral and yeasty (soap). I detected aged apples, lemon and an unfamiliar, very pleasant spice in the nose. This masterpiece has a murky golden hue with a large, rocky white head. No lacing, but fully lasting. Deliscious. Very malty, but well balanced. Not sweet.  A touch sour (I dig that) with hints of citrus and alcohol. The 9% ABV is fairly well hidden. Medium body with a creamy mouthfeel. Lively carbonation. A touch acetic in the finish, but mostly just a long, very dry finish to an excellent belgian style ale. Belgian Trippel fans must try this one. Highly recommended.
Not a big fan of this one.  Similar to Duvel.  There just wasnt anything noteworthy about this beer.

Mmmm.  Possibly the best of Unibroue.  Nice, vivid nose.  Pretty cloudy golden color.  Flavor is very nice.  Very spicy and yeasty, plenty of hints of banana and citrus.  Nice texture, pleasingly full.  Very yeasty, gives a nice sensation of chewing it as it goes down.  Yum.
Careful sipping is required as the alcohol is there. Complex with a citrus aroma
UPDATED: APR 6, 2003 Great beer ! but there is better in this category.

Cloudy golden appearance.  Huge Belgian head typical of this style.  Complex aroma with some citrus qualities and some spice and just a little bit of mustiness thrown in for good measure. 9% ABV is hidden very well, Im enjoying this 750 ml bottle. Let this one warm to about 55 degrees and it is perfect! Very nice job Unibroue!
Superb creamy head, beautiful cloudy yellow colour. The aroma is fruity and fresh. A nice beer lacking maybe of a little bit of power.
Love the name.  Very wheat-y with an extra kick an sweetness.
I only had a taste of a buds, but this is a very good light belgian beer.  It was cloudy with a good mix of sweetness and spice.

Any beer from unibroue is worth trying - truely the best domestic (near domestic-canadian) Belgium copy. La fin de monde is my favorite from this brewer- reminesent of the 8% Chimay. (rumour has it , the brew master is from the Chimay family) bold, robust and alot of alcohol, anything else you need? how about 3-4 bucks for a 750ml a little cheaper than Chimay, and I cant tell the difference- the elixir of life
Not as good as La Maudite, but the beer has a real kick in the ass at 9%. Yeasty, citrus, woody, not as smooth as Maudite,

Quite yeasty on the nose with some hops evident.  Some malt up front but mostly this is dry, yeasty, and mildly peppery.  Cloudy blonde in color with a large, quickly dissipating head.  Full mouthfeel for such a light colored beer.  Not bad
Truly a classic.
Like all of Unibroue line-up, true to its Belgian heritage.  Beautiul hazy light yellow.  Some wheat and yeast in the nose.  Citrus flavors pervade.  A wonderful summer sipper.
this was good, large white head, wonderful citrus aroma.  Like a witbier on steroids, flavors everywhere, spice,corainder, lemon. Very good

First, let me say, "a bottle conditioned belgian tripel in a twist top bottle?"  Yes, it is.  Huge frothy white head, sour malt aroma.  Taste of spice and yeast.  A high quality tripel.  I do not think the alcohol is over pronouced but the again I dont drink much under 8%.  It could be that other had it to soon, this will probably age very well.
MMMM, nice and fruity, with a strong spice flavor in the finish.
very much a similar beer to don de dieu without the freaky flourescent yellow color. spicy nose and a fruity flavor.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2003 an old favourite that got me turning towards great beer.  one of unibroue's better tripel style beers with good sweet and spiciness(cardamom?  pepper?) and yeasty sloburn finish.
definitely spicy... tasted kind of like ginger ale to me, but thats just me. great aroma and quite malty... definitely lemon, orange and grapefruit flavors are present

Smells much like the Blanche de Chamblay, and looks similar in the glass; citrus with some spice in the nose and hazy yellow with a medium head in the eyes. Very lemony (and sweet) flavor with good spice and noticable alcohol, especially in the finish. Quite nice.

This beer pours up with an incredibly boisterous white head over a cloudy golden body.  The aroma has strong notes of citrus, reminiscent of a hefeweizen with a wedge of lemon in it.  There are no esthers to speak of, however.  Instead, the beer is noticeably oppy, although I have noticed it more due to the hefe aroma.  It feels smooth in the mouth, but thin.

Insanely active head. Big airy foam. It was difficult to pour it softly enough to keep it under control, but from the taste and the lack of foamy at opening, it wasnt infected. Aroma is lemon on top of apricots. Light lemony/apricot flavor that rides on a noticeable malt backbone. Has a little of the cottony mouthfeel but not enough to hurt the drinkability. Probably the best Belgian golden ale Ive tried.
I think it resembles a weaker version of maudite. Not as strong but goes down smooth.  Sweet, no aftertaste.  I think id rather have Maudite but still a great beer.
Its like Trois Pistoles + Duvel + Hoegaarden White. Basically a pale version of Trois Pistoles with witbier spices. Quite good, like a really strong witbier, but more complex.
Great Tasting ale even though you might think you are drinking champagne. with a 9% abv it doesnt have a strong alcohol taste its rather a sweet&fruity taste

A cloudy, pale gold in appearance. It had a large, frothy white head and lots of champagne-like bubbles. It reminded me somewhat of a white beer. Its taste is slightly sweet & fruity. I found it to be very enjoyable.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2003 750 ml caged and corked bottle, best before 10-24-05 date. Pours a pale cloudy yellow color with a lot of floaties, nice white frothy head that leaves a clingy lace in my glass. Has a clean bannana and spicy lemon aroma. Sweet and fruity flavors that dry out, nice crisp and clean finish, another great ale by this brewery.

An Excellent trippel.  I havent had many trippels but it is the best Ive had so far.  Very strong in alcohol- yet it is only slightly noticable in the aroma.  Many spices in the aroma including coriander, clove, pepper, and maybe cumin.  Awesome appearance!  Nice golden hazy look with a medium head. (must drink in the propper belgian glass)  Fizzy and carbonated but not overly so- which makes it more drinkable.  Reminds me somewhat of a delerium tremens but this is much much better.  Lots of belgian biscuit and aromatic malts in the flavor to balance out all the spices.  Im assuming some hallertau or saaz was used but in moderation.   Yeasty, almost breadlike taste and aroma comes through very well, but is not overbearing.  As it warmed, a little more bubblegum flavors came through in the flavor.  The beginnign flavor is sweet yet slightly acidic, but the finish leaves you wanting another sip.  One of the best belgians from one of the most diversified and distinguished Brewery of Belgian Ales

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2004 Great beer! Very carbonated almost to the point of being annoying. Cloudy blond reminescent of a hefe-weizen. Strong alcohol aroma and taste with a strong dose of spice. Almost like a mix of a wheat beer and a champagne. Great beer overall.

A very frothy head that is a mixture of small and large bubbles. Cloudy yellow color. I dont detect much aroma at all. Sparkly feel in the mouth with nice mixture of sweet, smooth,flowery-spicy. Doesnt have the alcohol burn you might expect from a 9%abv. I seem to detect just a very slight cidery note. Very tasty overall, and quite refreshing.
Very fruity and sweet, nice yellow color.This is one sweet and fruity beer, its good, but not that good. The perfume smell is almost to much at times, maybe Blondes dont have more fun.
Best example of style. The champagne of beers.
Murky yellow colour, little bit of alcohol taste to it.  Coriander, cloves and other spices present in the taste.  Tastes a bit like a belgian white beer.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2015 Bottle (BB 02-05-17). Head is initially small, frothy, white, mostly diminishing. Body is hazy medium to dark yellow, bottle conditioned. Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (toasted grain), lightly hoppy (herbs, lemon), moderately yeasty (basement), with notes of alcohol, pepper, apple, gum. Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively/soft carbonation, moderately alcoholic. A decent enough rendition...a little apple in the nose, but otherwise attractive with decent yeast and pepper notes. Good flavor balance as well, nice dryness in the finish. A little too watery with poor carbonation makes the mouthfeel less than desired, but ultimately its a fairly good tripel (whereas all too many are sugar/booze bombs).
Nice full spicy flavor.  Full bodied and I love the cloudy appearance.  Would go great with a fancy chicken dish.

August oranges fall from the sky as apples turn to luscious cider instantaneously…Shards of caramel nuts and exquisite blades of wheat caress me as they pass by…Raining white pepper…Wondrous malt/hop balance…If this is the end of the world, I feel privileged to relive it again and again…
Bottle.  Pale golden yellow appearance with a laced head.  Much like a white beer with the belgian tripel punch.  Spicy and flowerly flavor.

This is a beer that comes alive as it warms a bit. Im not a fan of suspending the yeast in this one   - pour carefully after letting it sit for a couple of days. From other experience, this beer ages very well, particularly in the larger 750 ml size. 

This bottle poured   with a fair bit of chill haze, which cleared as the beer warmed to a gorgeous gold with hints of orange. The head was large, white, and creamy, with moderate to good longevity. 

Aroma started fairly closed, with hints of bready malt and a touch of flowery perfume. As it warmed, the maltiness came out, along with big flowery hops, hints of coriander, clove, and citrus. The alcohol also becomes apparent in the nose as it warms. 

Body is quite full, with fine, strong carbonation and a mouth-coating finish.

When cold, the flavor is subdued, clean, starting moderately sweet and finishing somewhat bitter. After warming to appropriate drinking temp, the sweetness dominates, along with strong citrus and flowery notes. 

This is one of my standard almost always in the fridge beers, I love it ...

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2003 Excellent Belgian Strong Ale. Quite similar to Duvel, but a little lighter and cleaner. Pale yellow. Slightly sweet. Quite effervescent. The alcohol is hidden wonderfully. No noticable alcohol aroma, flavor, or even warming. How they hid this much alcohol in a beer this light and delicate is a mystery. An excellent beer!

This beer has a slightly hazy golden colour with a big white head.  When cold, it has a lot of carbonation but as it warms up, it feels more flat.  Its got an aroma of yeast, apricot, apple and alcohol with some lemony notes.  The flavour is a bit too sweet for me with bready notes and some bitterness trying to fight the sweetness in the finish.  Since this is a beer ive had many times and used to be one of my favourites, im a bit disapointed tonight.  I remembered this beer to be better though its still very good.

I drank this without having any idea whatsoever of what I was getting into.  So I see the 9% ABV, and Im thinking, is this a barleywine?  Its quite light and clear, perhaps the palest color Ive ever seen from that strength of beer.  It tasted quite wheaty, almost reminding me of a hefeweizen.  Kind of strange but very nice.
Cloudy and highly carbonated.  Nice foamy mouthfeel.  The alcohol and sweetnest jumps out at you and leaves a strange film on you tongue and throat.  Reminds me too much of Champagne.

This would be a first-rate blonde ale if its aroma and flavor werent dominated by alcohol. As it is, its not bad, and I prefer it to most blonde ales that Ive tried. The taste is on the sour side, but not excessively so, and I like its yeasty qualities. It feels good in my mouth. If only the alcohol were covered better...

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2008 2008-03-24,  7-3-7-3-14=34Blond color, with a turbolent perlage; frothy big head. It’s a quite simple Triple, with a light canned sardines aroma, a rather sweet body, some spices (cloves...), low bitterness and some alcohol warmth. The final is mellow and spicy. Drinkable.2002-06-03, 7-4-7-3-14=35Appearance and flavours similar to a Belgian wheat beer. Cloudy, perfumy, fruity, sweet and spicy. Difficult to believe it’s so strong.
I typically dont dont like the lighter/white belgian beers, but this is the best I have ever had. Cloudy yellow color. Smelled of sweet spice, tasted of sweet celery, nice finish.

Its rather hard to believe that this brew contains 9% ABV. Pale, pale wonderfully pale. Fruity must and spice nose. The moment you notice the sweetness a rush of mellow bitterness tugs your buds for attention. At the End of the World there lies a brewery that turns out some fantastic beers, not to mention a few happy French-Canadians. Quality, Eh!
Slightly less alcohol taste is apparent in this fine beer than in the Unibroue 10.  Rather winey.  Good.  Floaties in the beer.  I liked it.

The nose off this was very nice.  The typical yeast smell was present, but I got a stong characteristic of apple-cinnamon, very nice.  Colored strangely orange.  The apple cinnamon theme was continued in taste, and the brew finished with a presence of carbonation and a certain sweetness.  In my opinion, Unibroue has always done well to make the alcohol content less noticeable, and this is s a fine example.  Nice.

Well, I had to pull out my recording of Olivier Messiaen’s “Quatour Pour la Fin du Temps,” “Quartet for the End of Time,” which is simply exquisite, written in captivity and performed for the first time at Stalag 8-A in 1941, with the composer playing the piano, unfortunately, this beer does not live up to that transcendental work, this is a pale, light color, diminishing head, mild fruit and malt aroma, very slight carbonation, but I find this a pretty dull flavor, it goes nowhere on the palate, it just lies there, a kind of dry, unsweetened malt, slightly sour finish, not at all a transcendental beer, nor does it live up to the overwhelming grandeur of the title.

Strong but watery, quite a fast paced drinker, with a frictional element. Its got a rock-mellon, Papaya edged tinge on ambient evaporation within the oral aperture..blah, blah wank wank.. yep, we can rate beer like you too (Mr Apricot and Apples). Look its nice, its tastey, its a lot better than the other beer out there and well have another. End of Story.
Spicey, apple and pear aroma. Cloudy, golden, a few floaties. Strong sweet malt, wheat after taste. Extra zingy on the tongue. Terrific.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2004 Bottle conditioned. Amber gold, poor head and moderate condition. Excellent heavy malt in the nose with hints of fruity jam and some background hop traces. Sweet thick malt in the mouth with a suggestion of Horlicks and a touch of good oxidation. Finish is oily with malt dominant and spicy around the edges.

Cloudy orange colour, medium head, some lacing. Bit of citrus in the nose. I didnt get much spice or pepper, must have been masked by the sediment. Very smooth with yeasty sweet malt flavour. I will buy more of this.

Cloudy, yeasty pale yellow color with a thick, smooth bright white head and some lace on the glass. Aroma touching on several areas: bready, yeasty, a zesty citrusy lemon and slightly spicy on the nose.Very spicy feel with the filling flavor of yeast and some pepper as well.
Very malty and the alcohol is very much up front. Almost like a fine wine.

Smells like a good German wheat, fruity, drinks like Belgian triple. Wonderful on the tounge, savor the sweet ending. Sticks around for a bit, kind of coats the mouth in a slight sweet oil, some refer to it as spicy, maybe I just go too much sediment into mine (this always seems to mellow things out). Solid Belgian 9% ABV, Unibroue are gods, they just dont screw around when they make a product. Fans should try cellaring it for a year, its got to get even better.
Similar to Lucifer, but with a slightly better flavor. Again, for a 9% alc. beer, the flavor is extremely smooth.

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2004 Apr 02:  750 ml bottle.  I have to say at the outset that this bottle was very flat.  I mean, no carbonation at all, no bubbles, nada.  So I was prepared for the worst, but happily it was semi-salvageable.  Opaque amber/orange color reminds me of apple juice; nose, too, is fruit-like for the most part:  lemony wit characteristics melding with apricot and apples.  Nice, but not strong enough.  Flavor & texture definitely hurt by the loss of spritz; it's intensely malty and sweet with virtually no hop character.  Drunk at cellar temp, tolerable, but as it warmed it became quite cloying and viscous.  The nice cider-like notes and faint herbal qualities I feel hallmark a special beer; unfortunately, my bottle was simply dead.  A mixed review, then, but I will certainly try to find a good bottle someday; given the brewer's other works, it will probably be worth it. 7/3/5/2/11=2.8

May 04:  Hazy spun gold, webs of yeast within, fully lasting creamy small head.  Lovely yeasty apple-bread nose, thick hugely malty body has notes of apple, lemon chiffon cake, pepper... I had a seriously bad bottle of this initially, sorry it's taken me so long to re-rate.  Wonderful stuff, loses just a bit at the finish but another top-notch effort from Sleeman, oops Unibroue still.

I had a 1997 vintage in the 750ml. It had distinct chardonnay characters with malty characters. It was well balanced and had a decent length that finished dry. I tasted a current vintage after and if anything it had a bit more sweetness. I think I might put a few more in the cellar!

Very cloudy appearance with a few dark flakes of yeast in there. I wonder how many yeasts they actually use: the French on the bottle says a special strain of yeast and the English says a blend of special yeasts. Anyway. I got peanuts, orange and alcohol in the aroma. Flavour has a lot of honey (of the strong weirdo flowers variety), buttered corn on the cob, and peanuts with the skins still on. Texture is strangely tongue-coating and fatty. Finishes dry. Overall a curious creature, not as hoppy as i remembered from last time - but then I had a 2 year old bottle this time round so it must have mellowed.
UPDATED: JAN 8, 2003 A great beer. Gets better every time you drink it.  If it was the end of the world I"d be slamming this stuff.

Do not open one of these in the living room when you are deep in a rich conversation and not paying attention.  Hosed down a stack of student essays with this one - I hope they dont mind a little FDM patterned across their efforts!  Anyway, what you find at the end of the world is a sharp stab of peppery spices in the back of the mouth, where most of this beers taste will settle after it rides ebulliently across the tongue without raising much attention.  It is the end, the finish, the conclusion of this brew that stands out, appropriately.  Feels and tastes like a decent wheat beer until it gets to that dark and electric close.

Pours with a light honey/dark golden color and produces a thin head of white foam that dissipates farily quickly. Nose: banana, butter and clove aroma.
Flavor: butterscotch, coriander(?), a doughy banana bread, lightly yeasty. Reminds me of Duvel.

This is my favorite beer that Ive ever tried I think Very nice aroma with a kind of apple taste which was very nice and refreshing the after taste was a little like a wine (dry) but all around this beer was very impressive with its 9% A.C. Only problem with it is that I have to go to New Brunswick to get it they dont sell it here on the Island.

Slightly better than i remember ( the bottle i had had been aged for a couple of years), very nice, hints of wine (chardonnay), peach, malt, hops, and nice and dry. But still had the characteristics from the other brews from Unibroue (perhaps a bit of sweet stickiness, very nice beer though.

UPDATED: JUN 12, 2005 I thought Maudite was  the top Unibroue, but this kicked its ass. Insane body ... I guess I stored it wrong because it foamed all over the damn place. But a deliciously spicy flavour, clean finish and drinkability, and the perfect sweetness made this the king of Quebecois beers. Also enough alcohol in one bottle to crack your head open.

Large lasting head, cloudy orange color, smells of orange and caramel. The taste has a big alcohol domination with a sweet fruity/citrus/caramel flavor. Dry finish with alcohol again predominating. VERY tasty!
aller toute chier !!! criss vous vous connaissez pas...on cote dla bière chaud criss !!!!! parole de beauceron hohhooh !

A fine trippel aroma much like Chimay Premiere, my favored Chimay. Spicy, heathery, Bretty, subdued citrus, complex fruit acids, semi-dry, zesty, alcohol piquant. Its much better when I shake out some effervescence and it becomes a bit more yeasty, sweeter. An excellent fruitier remix of Chimay Premiere, the best of the Chimays.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2003 Wonderful maltiness, and I feel the fruitiness is subdued. But what clinches this as wonderful for me is that the piney spiciness I often get in triples in nearly absent...just a hint. For my 'slow' palate (it had to ride the 'short' bus to beer-drinking school), that gives the citrus, and sweeter fruit flavors, a chance to shop up, especially when warming. I love the malt/yeast in this one.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: UPDATED: FEB 6, 2003 What a wonderfull tasting triple ale. Definitely a must try.
I would expect to taste more alcohol in a beer with this high an abv%. Smooth, little bit of fruit, nice beer!

2000 vintage: Gently yellow colour with high carbonation. Some apple & peach notes in the taste. Alcohol flavour is right up front (good thing, people). Very dry wine-like aftertaste. Heaps better than Duvel.

Had this beer for the first time at a beer tasting party.  Bought my first 6-pack (they sell 6-packs in Canada, 4-packs in the USA) while in Niagra Falls with my family.  Very nice, fruity beer.  The complexity changes wonderfully as it warms in the glass.  I love that Belgian candy sugar influence, whether used in this brew or not.
A full fruity flavor, good head, good lace...real easy drinkin for a 9% brew. Good beer!

Like a lot of strong Belgian blondes and tripels, the alcohol sometimes emerges a little too much (though some people on this site are obviously hyper-sensitive to alcohol as the ratings of Trois Pistoles would indicate).  Dark beige, pure white foam, aroma of fresh bell peppers, yeast, orange zest, dark german bread...aside from the alcohol the palate has a fair bit of malt, a somewhat thick finish, white pepper, almond skins, yeast (and lots of it), finishing dry with alcohol.
A wicked good tasting brew! Very smooth for a 9% abv. Citrus notes, fresh fruit smells for sure. It is recommended!
Wow this is really smooth.  A bit of granny smith apple (but in a good way) liquorice, honey, and anisseed as well.  The finish is still fairly dry.  This is very good.
Very unique. Never had anything quite like it before. Very good, but too much carbonation for me.

This beer is truly amazing. A one of a kind--much like its originator (and its province of origin). Remarkably drinkable for a biere of its forte. Drink as an apres ski or at each Winter Carnival bar stop. Ive loved this beer since I first tasted it 8 years ago in Chez Son Pere in Vieux Quebec...

Kind of thin bodied, massive effervescence. The alcohol flavor is a bit too prominent, as theres really not much of a malt body to cover it up. The yeast flavors come through powerfully as well, predominantly giving up a strong taste of cloves not unlike a Hefeweizen. Faithful to the Belgian golden ale style, but not its greatest representative.
Good beer but Trio Pistoles is still my favorite of the Unibroes.
Had this last night at the brewpub, golden, fizzy, boatloads of spices and a unique citrus character. Very well balanced. Alcohol was masked very well. Tasty triple and one I will seek out again.

tart citrus aroma.  straw colour with a light lacey head.
very zesty sparkling beer. yeast  gives it a  clove flavor.
easy drinking for a 9% beer. only the thin fizzy palate distracts from a fine brew
UPDATED: JAN 18, 2003 Flowery aroma, slight citrus taste that goes down smooth.  Very easy drinking for a 9% beer.
Tart, bitter, alcoholic.  Way dry,like a bad champagne, and out of balance for beer.  Didnt enjoy nearly as much as Don de Dieu or Maudite.

Another great product by Unibroue !
I may not have all the fancy vocabulary like some beer experts on this site, but I can tell you that this beer is GOOD.

Vive le Québec !
Nice hop aroma.  Malty taste with slight hop bitterness.  Very sweet taste though somewhat balanced by alcohol twang.
flavourful but a little immature (my bottle at least)
Its all right, for something from Canada.
Blame Canada!
Watch out for this one...numb pretty quick.  I injoyed this from sober to seeing double.
Didnt taste like 9%, but it certainly is.  Much better than Maudite, but not complex enough to taste like a true belgian blonde.

This was a good beer overall.  I was slightly disappointed though.  I probably had my expectations set too high, as the only other Unibroue I have had is the amazing Tres-Pistoles.  This has a strange fruitiness too it, that I didnt particularly like.  I enjoy some fruity beers, but this was different.  Also, the alcohol was a little too obtrusive.  Still a good beer though.

Nothing subtle about this beer. Everything about this beer is in your face, Belgian style. Be very careful, I mean it. This stuff tastes so good you wont want to stop drinking it... at this level of alcohol the beer will stop you before you decide youve had enough.

Ah! Where to begin? Unibroue could be one of the best breweries in the continent..  This truly evil beer is overwhemingly strong and fruity.. Dont give this to your Bud drinking friends or else theyll chug it and get hammered with only half a bottle! Superb appearance, slightly cloudy blonde on a bed of foreboding dark red sediment.
Good. Lighter then most belgium blondes but strong.
Nice powerful beer, excellent with a churchill-size cigar.
I had this right after a Victory Golden Monkey and this just wasnt up to the challenge. Still very good though.
Slightly sweet with a spicy palate.Very good!

While not quite as good as Duvel or Victory Golden Monkey, this was very tasty. Slight earthyness and yeast flavoring which gives it a bit of a spiciness that the others dont have. I really enjoyed this one.

Cloudy, blond, with a white fluffy head and light lacing.  Spicy, bubbly, and slightly tangy, I couldnt find any negative qualities.  There is a distinct alcohol presence that is slightly warming, but it is NOT overwhelming (like some other trippels).  The most interesting thing about this brew is its aroma, which reminded me of a raspberry tart. Blows Westmalle Tripel out of the water.

UPDATED: MAR 17, 2004 Succulently malty, fruity aroma.  Very appetizing opaque rosy-gold color.  Serious head retention.  Flavor profile starts off with a big malt hit, and then the faint bitterness and yeasty fruitiness take over.  Smooth, lightly effervescent, soft and creamy palate.  Very nice interplay between the ingredients.   An excellent Tripel.
not sure if i got a bad bottle, but my initial try at this one was terrible

Drank this directly after drinking Duvel, which was a nice comparison. It fell just short...a main difference I noticed was a lot less flavor in the malt. Probably was smoother though, nice balance of hops and malt. Could have used a little more in the malt flavoring for perfection, but overall a stand out beer.
I gave some of this to a friend who did the moster fondue, she declared it the best she ever had. It was great with this food and alone for all sted reasons.

Another in-betweener from Unibroue: this one borrows from both the triple and strong golden styles.  The result is flat-out terrific.  I cannot believe how smooth and clean this beer is.  Very complex.
Strong with a nice sour bite.
Wow.  Very nice, very smooth beer.  Fruity and refreshing, smell great.  A little sour on the palate, but that I suspect is from the high alcohol content.

Unlike Don De Dieu, the alcohol overpowers
the other flavors of the beer.  Underneath is a nice
citrus flavor.

UPDATED: OCT 12, 2011 Pleasant beer with nice yeast flavors and aromas. Hints of white pepper, spices and herbs create a delicate complexity that complements well with the malts and warming alcohol. Could do without the twist-off caps on the 12-ounce bottles ... who would drink this beer from the bottle anyway?
Very drinkable and good flavour for such a strong beer.
Nice beer. A bit sour smelling and tasting. Very carbonated.

Great smell, like sour green apples and grain alcohol mixed together.  Sour flavor with a nice alcohol warming, carbonated a little bit too much which made it a bit rough on the palatte, but overall a fine beer.
too sour and too carbonated.  Detracts from the quality of the beer.
Not one of the better ones from Unibroue, but still a fine beer.  This one has more of a sour (alcohol?) taste and high carbonation.
Light and cloudy in appearance, similar to Blanche de Chambly.  Alcoholic aroma, yeasty, warming flavour.
Maudite has a bit more flavour but this still is a first class beer.Not quite as dense as other Unibroue beers-due  perhaps to the higher (9%)alcohol content.
This beer would have been better had it not been for the alcoholic aroma
very yeasty and warming
This was my first strong Canadian beer.  I must say I was not disappointed.  It has a beautiful aroma and taste, truly an exceptional beer.

Hazy straw color; very fizzy to style; malty / spicy nose; 9% alcohol comes through immediately on first sip; wide complexity of flavors from spices, vanilla, clove, lemon and banana with mild lactic sourness; moderate late hop presence with long spicy hop finish. A beautiful and complex ale. What a treat!!
I really enjoyed La Fin Du Monde.  Full flavored taste, with very little bitterness. Oui!

Strong but very easy to drink.  
Big beginning.
A very good triple; however, I did notice a bloating sensation. (Ive noticed this bloating effect with all the Unibrew beers except Trois Pistoles.)
orange colour, caramel and lemon aroma, sweet caramel flavor, slightly spicy
Another great beer from Unibroue.  Very strong tasting though, hard to drink more than one in a sitting.  Not Unibroues best work, but certainly not bad either.

This beer looks great in the glass.  Its that perfect wheat malt and yeasty cloudy color.  It tastes somewhat like a highly alcoholic Paulaner Hefe-Weizen, though its actually a triple.  Not bad, but its not a guzzling beer, or one you can likely drink more than one of.  I prefer Maudite over this.

Nice golden yellow cloudy appearance.
Pleasant malty aroma.
First sip is alcohol and yeast.  A very
powerful beer.
It remains yeasty and malty.
This is a very good beer, but its definitely
hard to drink more than one.
Probably would not pair well with food.
wow.
